I tried removing the plugs and the smart assistants and tried just my tablets and phones but when I would get to the 6th device it would connect then immediately disconnect until I took one of the others off the wifi. I also tried using a combination of the 2.4 and the 5g but that didn't work either even tried it with no wired devices connected and still had the same 5 wifi connection limit.I spent hours in the various menus in the UI but even in the advanced settings its missing a lot of basic settings like manually setting device IP and even basic connection diagnostic.I contacted support and after 3 days still haven't gotten a response other than the generic auto Covid-19 telling me there is a delay in support issues but at this point I just decided to send it back and try another brand.
title: Wifi has a small device limit!

author: NewYorker55
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2018
review_content: Excellent router for the price, so far this gives me 200mbps if speed on my 150mbps plan (I haven’t tested what hard wired connection speed would be), setup was a breeze.  I primarily wanted to get this to add an external hard drive which to use as a media server.  This was also easy to setup Howveer the hard drive crashes and lags the router if doing too many tasks (downloading something while simultaneously uploading to the network drive). However doing one task at a time like uploading to the media server works fine and Won’t crash the router.I still think this is the best value router out there, not however that with this version you cannot load custom firmware, unlike the C7
title: Can’t do custom firmware’s but best router out there for the price

author: Alex
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2018
review_content: I bought this thing only a week ago. For sone reason the internet died and on the router all the lights are off except for the internet which shows a dim red. No other lights cone on. Modem has internet and reseting the router does nothing. Returning and hopefully will get a working router.
title: Router died after a week.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
review_content: I really want to love this router. The range is excellent and the connection is a whole lot more stable than my last router, with one exception; QoS. This "envisioning" of QoS as we'll call it, is frankly a joke in terms of limiting access to certain devices on my home network. I have a very unstable connection which relies on a satellite to get my internet, so making sure that I can get the most out of the amount of bandwidth I'm limited to is crucial. With my old TP-Link router I was able to throttle speeds of certain IP addresses to whatever speed I wanted which made the internet accessible to anyone who came over and didn't let bandwidth hungry devices like streaming boxes make everyone visibly upset. This amazing feature got replaced with QoS, which in theory is somewhat better because this goes by MAC addresses rather than IP addresses, so I don't have to keep going into my router settings to make sure someone isn't being throttled. But the implementation is complete utter GARBAGE. When I enabled QoS I'm not able to set speeds but rather a "priority" list for certain devices, which isn't that big of a deal as it should probably do a good job of limiting bandwidth to certain devices as I see fit... but no... this completely throttles your own connection to make everything else "smooth" which is a complete utter joke. I went from having a stable 40MBPS to just 10MBPS when switching this feature on, which completely defeats the purpose of using it. Why would I enable this feature when it ultimately makes everyone's speed worse rather than just one or two devices? I seriously hope TP-Link can tweak this feature in the future and let the user have that controlled functionality back because if it wasn't for this crucial flaw, I would be extremely happy with my purchase. This complaint thankfully can be fixed with a firmware update, but I seriously doubt they will implement this back
title: Great router with one main flaw

author: The Sus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: If you own a MAC don't buy. After my 2TB AirPort device fizzled I bought this hoping it would work as an wifi extender and print network but it has been a pain to try and set up. Didn't work with my 15" 2017 MacBook Pro or my new 16" MacBook Pro I just got in Dec 2019. It has never worked properly as I can tell. Doesn't extend wifi at all. Their "TP-LINK USB Printer Controller" doesn't install correctly on a Mac and I downloaded the correct and latest driver from the convoluted circle you are directed in at their site. Talked to customer service which said if all the lights are lit up then it's working and automatically set up as an extender. If that is true it must only extend 3 inches. What a waste of 57.00 and my time.ALSO, and this is a huge ALSO, it installs multiple things in "login Items" that have created problems with shutting my computer down and messing up my desktop and appearance. Those 2 problems went away as soon as I uninstalled all the TP-Link software. I will never buy from TP-Link again. 0 Stars
title: Worst purchase of my life

author: Sashy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2020
review_content: Like some others reviews say, I had frequent WiFi connection problems with this router. At random times one or another device would appear to have a strong signal but wouldn’t get any throughput or would get very slow. I know it was the router and not my ISP, since I could fix the problem by disconnecting and reconnecting the WiFi connection of whatever device was unhappy, but the problem would recur soon enough. I checked to make sure I had the latest firmware to see if that could be the issue, but it said I did already.In other respects this product was good, setup and mgmt were easy to do via the web interface and iPhone app.I’ve since replaced it with a Netgear Nighthawk router and haven’t had any more issues.
title: Stutters and chokes

author: JAS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2018
review_content: This is a perfectly adequate router if you lan configuration is a simple class c address such as 192.168.1.1 / 255.255.255.0.  However, in my lan, I need devices addressed from 192.168.0.1 to 192.168.1.254.  This required a custom subnet mask.  I configured the lan for 192.168.0.1 / 255.255.254.0.  I general this worked ok.  All of my devices were able to operate on the lan.  However, I found that management interfaces of some of my devices weren't able to be accessed.  For some reason, when I tried to access a wifi access point at 192.168.1.2, the connection failed with a time-out.  However I was able to access a camera at 192.168.1.20.I reported this to TP-Link, and got the response that "1. The 192.168.0.1 / 255.255.254.0 is different subnet from 192.168.1.1 / 255/255/255/0, different subnet can't reach each other, which is right.2. If you want to reach all those fixed IP address devices, you need set up same subnet's IP address for them."This response make very little sense to me.  Their suggestion was to use a subnet mask 255.255.255.0 which will limit my address range, and move any devices into that address range.I would have expected that they would have been interested in the failure so that they could report the scenario back to their development staff.Aside from this failure mode, the router is a good router.  I've had to reconfigure my network to accommodate the addressing failure, but I like some of the features the router provides.  I particularly like the ddns feature.  In the past I've used a free ddns service that requires periodic confirmation.  With the tp-link service, you set it once an don't have to reconfirm it.  I also like the ftp feature that allows external secure access to the USB flash drive connected to the router.Bottom line is that this is a good router for most home lan configurations.  But beware if your configuration is more complicated.Update 11/13/2019:  I have discover a new limitation that seriously limits this router.  I upgraded my connection to gigabit.  If I connect directly to the modem, I see speeds in the 700-800 mbit.  When I connect through the A7 router, the best speed I see is 350 mbit.  I haven't found any valid reason for the speed limitation.
title: Don't attempt to use custom lan subnet mask / Don't use with gigabit internet conection.

author: FairweatherNine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2018
review_content: I have used this router for over a year, very happy.  When a friend told me about her wifi issue (log cabin big thick walls) I said(retired tech..),  I would take a  look  She had a very old device, signal 15 feet away was almost nonexistent.  I hooked this up (easy install) and in a matter of seconds a nice steady signal all over the cabin.
title: Still a nice choice

author: cindrloo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: Have been a loyal Netgear user since my first, many years ago. That ended abruptly a year and half ago when I purchased my last router from them. Had nothing but trouble with it and absolutely no tech support after 90 days unless I was willing to pay them more than I paid for the router! Their 1 year warranty is useless, after they “scan” your router, they tell you the warranty only covers the hardware and there is nothing wrong it, that they need to connect with it and that is tech support which is not covered and you have to pay for it. With help from a tech friend got it to work but consistently dropped the connection.  Suddenly it lost connection with my modem and I couldn’t get it back, I decided I was not going to mess with it any more.  In need of another one fast, I searched Amazon and hit on this one which was half the price of my last one, had very good reviews, from the description “free 24/7 technical support” and available with next day delivery!  I received It the next day as promised, installation was a little glitchy but managed to get it up and running on my own. Checked the speed in my bedroom which is on the other side of the house and it registered at 225mbps, my service from Spectrum is 200mbps. Have had absolutely no issues connecting all my devices to it.  It’s only been 2 days now but very happy with this purchase.
title: No more Netgear headaches!

author: E.P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2019
review_content: Initially, the TP-Link AC1750 seemed like a great fit. Easy to setup, nice app, good speeds.  Over 6 months later the router is hardly usable. Throughput is poor at best and seems to fluctuate at random times of the day.  The 5Ghz band doesn’t retain a signal and drops totally when used. I have to constantly reboot the router to ensure it will work for just a few hours at a time.Upgrading the firmware is a joy as well.  You have two ways to access the router - via a cloud account or directly via a browser.  When you update you are fully logged out of the device (in the mobile app) and if you fail to recall your password you might as well factory reset. This process could be made smoother by connecting cloud account to the actual router account.Look elsewhere for a more reliable router that is consistent with speed and bandwidth.
title: Don't waste your time or money...

author: Mrs. Dee Kelly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
review_content: TP-Link AC1750 Smart WiFi Router - Dual Band Gigabit is the actual thing I bought.I have 60 Mbps service, which is more than I need. I have Dish for TV, so I just need 5-10 Mbps for internet surfing and Youtube. If I was watching a video on my hardwired computer my wife would complain the video she was watching on wifi would buffer. WTF?? I would be doing a Youtube sax lesson and have to keep stopping and waiting for buffering. AARGH! I would do a speed test 60-100 Mbps. My neighbors are 200-300 ft away and I tried different channels, but nothing changed. I did notice there was nobody on the 5 gig band.I didn't want to spend a lot of money, so I was looking at the $30-40 dual band routers I could tether for wifi. I went up to this one for $60 because it has Quality of Service Archer 7 and I can assign different devices to each band. I have my roku, security system, and computer hard wired, the two iPhones on 5 gig, and the printer and other laptops and tablets on 2.4 gig band. NO MORE BUFFERING!!!!  Happy wife, happy life!It was pretty easy to set up and the Tether app makes it all easy. I can see my internet status and all the clients' status. I can assign clients between the two wifi bands and also block users. I can assign clients priority status and see the current upload and download speed of each client. There is also a guest network for visitors to use without access to your entire network. I have not used the USB port and I am not a gamer, so I cannot testify to their usefulness.Do I recommend the TP-Link AC1750 Smart WiFi Router - Dual Band Gigabit for normal internet and Youtube use? Yes, I am very happy with it's speed, flexability and powerful signal. The Tether app is very good and gives good control without having to log on to look at something. LARRY
title: Big Improvement over Comcast's Arris modem/router

author: Lee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2020
review_content: Last week I decided to return my Xfinity rental cable modem. So I had to buy a new cable model and a router. Originally I tried NETGEAR Nighthawk AC1900 Dual-Band Cable Modem Router. The activation was a breeze but there was an unexpected issue - the latency spikes. I could see the ping latency (to google.com) varies from 10ms to 400ms. My kids started to complain about the lagging zoom sessions and online games. So I had to return it and find a different solution. I switched into Arris SB6183 + Archer A7 and I concluded that (1) we don't need to have a faster modem than SB6183 if the cable plan is slower than 100mbps, and (2) we don't need to have a router better than this for a house of 2000 sqft (if the router is at the center of the house, the coverage will increase). However, let's say that the wifi coverage is not good enough because of the weird layout of your house or simply because your house is bigger than 2000 sqft. Then you can buy RE330 extenders to form a OneMesh network with A7. It will be fast enough if you don't have to play online games from every different corner of your house.
title: Damn Good Affordable Router

author: Foristell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019
review_content: Replaced an old non-TP Link WiFi router with this. The old one was old... user interface and setup was a bit difficult and coverage was only mostly adequate with one range extender added. Eventually the old girl just got tired and decided to retire.I have only had it running for a day, so I cannot speak to the longevity. However, setup was a breeze, almost too simple. Really quick and intuitive setup process had me online with it in just 3 minutes from box to service. That's always something I appreciate.Coverage is excellent. I do not need an extender anymore. And performance is noticeably improved as well. Pages load faster, and clients connect to the wireless faster.Overall very satisfied, especially for the price point. If it dies an early death I will update accordingly, but so far very happy and I do recommend it. Not much else to say at this point.
title: Early impressions are excellent

author: Jane K.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2020
review_content: When outside on my patio, and using wifi, I was no longer able to stream a podcast without it stopping and starting.  Was the problem my ISP, the modem, the router, or ???  Astonishing they haven't built tech by now to identify what the problem is.  Anyways, my router must be 10 years old (Cisco E2000) so I decided to try replacing it and the problem seems to be gone.  Signal strength in my one story 1300 sq ft. home seems decent.  I also was able to stream audio in my backyard w/o problems.  Had a my old router mounted on the wall behind my TV and of course the the industry can't get together to standardize mounting, so I got to fill and drill more holes in my wall.  (I wish they just make these thing hook on a nail - they are so lightweight.)  You will also need screws with a very narrow shaft to fit the wall mount.I downloaded the app, but was unable to change the router name or password for the the 5 GHZ connection.  The app seemed slow and I'm still not sure what benefit I get by having it on my phone.  I set up the router from my PC and that was much easier.  I wonder if the antennas are functional or just a marketing gimmick?Regarding all the other stuff, it will take way too long to figure out what it all means (what is "binding"?) and instructions and user interface is awful like all tech stuff.  I won't be buying a dot or other mesh products since fooling around with it isn't worth the time or effort.If it lasts as long as my Cisco router has, I'll be satisfied.  Will it tell me when it is failing?  I doubt it and I'll be back to guessing what to buy again.  I'd be willing to purchase more tech stuff to get everything working together, but right now it's too time consuming and messy.  And they only get 3 star ratings - mediocre because of user interface design and customer service.
title: It works and *seems* to have solved my problem

author: Clarksound
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
review_content: I purchased this item 3 months ago & successfully installed it. Then all of a sudden it stopped working due to it no longer recognizing a valid internet connection from my cable modem. Spent 2 days going around with my service provider before verifying that the modem had a valid internet connection. So onto the router! Did the normal rebooting of the unit (a number of times), replacing cables .. ect.  Finally did a full factory reset & setting it up from scratch. Same non working condition. All this took many many hours over the course of 3 days (I have time on my hands as a lot of us do these days).  So onto tech support at Archer (TP-Link). NO SATISFACTION! Went thru the website gauntlet & finally had to settle for a website chat (their customer support is no longer taking live calls). In which I explaining all the trouble shooting I had already gone thru. They totally ignored all that & wanted me to take back down my original router (which I had reinstalled so I could get back onto the internet) only to do the whole trouble shooting process all over again (which takes A LOT of time). In starting all over again they were asking me to do all that I had already done. Finally after going thru a number of steps I let them know this was enough & that I was willing to take a working replacement unit. They refused. This is not a company that is willing to take responsibility for their faulty products. Considering what I went thru I would definitely not recommend this product.
title: No satisfaction or support of faulty unit

author: Denise Martinez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2019
review_content: So my older router went out and I do not know why I did not buy another one of the same because I regret this dearly.  The signal is week,  I couldn't get this to work now my internet is for ever buffering which I had not seen this since dial up.  I have spectrum Internet with 100 Mbps  speed.  I had spectrum come to the house and troubleshoot the connection and the only part not working is the router.  It was not user friendly to hook up. I called customer service and they have only 1 service rep I called about 4 times and I got the same guy.  Instead of staying with me he while I do the steps he has indicated that will fix the issue nooo he has to hang up I do the steps he gave me  on my own and then he says  call again if I need him. I was about 20 min on hold waiting for him to pick up the call and then he tells me to monitor my connection. What ????  I am calling with issues and he wants me to monitor the connection.  He was going to send me some instructions thru email again instead of waiting for me to receive the email he hangs up again.  I work 14 hr days so my time past so I can return this device however I would like to go home and enjoy my internet. If at least I could have gotten excellent customer service the review would have been different.Long story short do not buy this device.  I strongly recommend netgear I have had 2 of those and love them. I will definitely get another NG device soon.
title: The worst WIFI devise I have bought in years

author: Brian Hughes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2020
review_content: I really want to love this router. I really do. But...The pros: fantastic coverage, through all rooms in our 3-bedroom apartment, past obstacles such as the HVAC, even a fair distance outside. Handles a huge number of devices; we have 2 desktops, 3 laptops, 2 phones, 4 tablets, several video games, and a multitude of smarthome devices, and this router handles them all. Great speed, easily passes through the max speed provided by my ISP's modem, both through the ethernet ports and wifi.The cons: the software/firmware is lousy. As such, it doesn't deliver on several features promised. I don't have menu options referred to in the manual, despite the router telling me I have the latest firmware. I do not have the options for either smarthome or (almost any of) the ones for USB. As a result, I can not control the router with Alexa (minor issue) and can not access the hard drive I attached as a media server (big issue). Half the time I can't even access the router software at all, even if attached with an ethernet cable. Also, it seems to have a problem with some social media sites - I usually have to turn off the wifi on my phone and rely on mobile data when accessing those sites.Overall, as a router it provides fast, wide area coverage. But it does not deliver the features advertised. I'm not returning it because it does the important things well, especially for the price. But I wouldn't recommend it because it does not provide the features that convinced me to buy it.
title: Mixed feelings, but can't recommend

author: KeecatGirl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020
review_content: Did my research, read the reviews, and figured I'd try this router out anyways due to the great overall ratings, affordability, and high esteem that I hold TP-Link under for many years preceeding.This router worked great for 1 month then randomly decided to stop working and after 2 hours on the phone with my local ISP, I happened to have their stock router in-hand and their router worked promptly...very disappointing and honestly, rather upset that I have to bash TP-Link's reputation into the ground like this, but the return window (7 days after it expired of course) closed on me and I'm out $65 and a router.
title: PLEASE do not waste $65/your time

author: KatieJo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2019
review_content: The reason I got this router was to set up a home network with printer sharing.  I got a new computer and wanted to use both desktops and have access from one to the other--both have ethernet connections.  I told the customer rep what I had and wanted to do before purchasing.  I am fairly tech savy, I happen to be a mechanical engineer, but I had never done this before.  I spent nearly 3 weeks on the phone and emailing tech support and nothing ever worked right.  It is such a long story but I don't know that I have EVER been this frustrated with a product.  They kept sending me emails with the same instructions that did not work the last time they sent them.  The experience was so unpleasant that I don't care if I have a home network, I will purchase a printer switch and just back up my data on both I guess.
title: Worst Customer Support

author: Jd Mitchell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019
review_content: ANOTHER UPDATE: I’ve decided to stop giving this thing the benefit of the doubt. I keep trying to make this thing worth the money, but it isn’t even worth $20. It’s now typical for it to convey half the speed of the original ATT router (ATT=178 Download & 57.6 Upload, TP-Link=82.8 Download & 36.6 Upload). Absolutely ridiculous. Just don’t waste your money and time like I have.UPDATE: 3 months in and I’m back to where I started. It’s now clear that this is no better than the basic att router. I suppose I’ll just try to sell it off on Facebook and try a WiFi extender at this point. Oh well.UPDATE: I have no idea what I’ve done but the speeds are now better with only about a 40% degradation through walls. I had to move my PS4 outside of the tv cabinet as it would seem that particle board is akin to lead when it comes to WiFi. Either way, I’m happier and updating from 3 to 4 stars. Although if this becomes a routine thing, I’ll reduce to 1 star and go ask the neighbor with the big truck if he wants to run over this router a couple dozen times.While the router is better than the one that comes with AT&T service, it’s not $60 better.Using this to actually provide WiFi and not as an access point or range extender, I typically get 10-20 mbps better than before when sitting right next to the router. However, with every step I take from the router, the speed drops 5-10 mbps, mind you this is still line of sight and no new obstructions.This brings another interesting bit. Once you go into another room, maybe 30 feet from the router, the speed drops from a little over 100 to around 60. I live in an apartment with thin walls.. THEN it gets better. If you have anything like a PS4 which sits inside of a tv stand, you get about 1/2 of what you do in the adjacent room meaning lagging is sometimes nonexistent and other times you lose connection altogether. So now I get 50 mbps download at best and typically 4-7 mbps upload whereas sitting next to it, download is over 100 and upload is over 60.On the brights side, the app is helpful if you have pesky neighbors who like to try to steal WiFi as it allows you to block certain IPs and easily change the password etc.Overall, I’m decently irritated by this purchase as it wasn’t terribly cheap especially when compared to the added benefit.
title: Meh at best

author: James
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019
review_content: Good router for the price range, distance is great for 2.4ghz frequency 5ghz falls off sooner as expected. If you are having an issue where computers connected with Ethernet cord work but not wifi, check the default IP address of your "CABLE" modem. My cable modem and router both used 192.168.1.1 as default addresses, making WiFi connected devices have no internet (due to improperly assigned IP addresses), to fix this i simply changed the DHCP Server's default gateway on the router from 192.168.1.1 to 192.168.2.1 applied changes and Wifi devices are now running flawlessly. Router has been stable for over 2 weeks with constant seeding and hasn't went down yet. Glad I went with this instead of a more expensive one.
title: Best bang for buck

author: Binder_MD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2020
review_content: I spent 6 hours today trying to find out how to set up this router for remote (away from network) access with my Comcast ISP). Comcast, like most ISPs, have dynamic IP addressing, which means that the address will change from time to time. In order to access this router remotely, you need to know the IP address. If it changes while you are away, you are out of luck. It took 6 phone calls and one chat to find this out. The TP-Link web site lists this router as TP-Link cloud compatible. Don't believe it.  The router will be returned tomorrow, unopened!!!I spoke with TP-LINK customer support (by chat) and was told that NONE of the TP-LINK routers have automatic update clients for DDNS built-in. In other words, in order to access the router, one has to leave a computer running on the network with their Windows (or other OS) update program always running. NETGEAR apparently does have a solution. TP-LINK has a twentieth century product, not twenty0first!
title: The router is well made and quite reliable. I had significant issues with TP-LINK customer support.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2020
review_content: I just finished installing the A7 TCP-Link 1750AC router replacing a 6 year old Linksys E2500--having had to replace my modem earlier in the week after it failed and went into a reboot loop. The Linksys worked but not reliably of late and it was slow for a dual band router.  I opted to use the quick install and then tweak later using the full featured web interface.  The install using TP's Tether app from my iPhone worked but not without a few missteps--a failure to connect to the router at first using the 5G SSID worked once I tried with the 2.4G.  A second hiccup occurred when binding the router--it froze and I had to go back and repeat the step.  I could have just logged in to the router from a laptop but wanted to see how well the app worked.  I highly recommend this approach for newbies--as the steps involved and required knowledge of how routers work could prove a bit daunting for a total novice.  That said, once installed and configured with the same SSID and password as my old router to save having to reconfigure a lot of devices (including a Netgear extender) everything worked and the entire process took less than 45 minutes.  Once I had everything working I logged in to the full web app giving me access to the router through a thoughtfully designed interface .  I made my security tweaks, set up a guest network, enabled Alexa control and tested every device to be sure all was in good order and then made a backup of the configuration--having been forewarned that a firmware upgrade would cause me to lose what I had just done.  As it happened a firmware upgrade was indicated so I chose the automatic upgrade option but to my surprise everything stayed intact iso I did not have to resort to a restore from the backup--still I am a belt and suspender guy having sent too many years in IT and learning the lesson early on that what can go wrong will.  So--the big payoff was the throughput.  I used an app called Speedtest and was a very pleased to see a 3x improvement in download-regardless of which server I selected.  Upload was slightly better but that is not generally an issue.  My TV, Sonos products, 2 iPhones, extender, 2 computers and 2 Kindles all worked without any changes needed ( the virtue of keeping my SSID and passwords the same as before).  Performance is obviously much improved.  I would have given this a 5 star but for the two hiccups and a little more clarity in the basic quick setup about a few functions.  Otherwise as the title say it was a near perfect install and if this router lasts as long as the linksys.  Range has also improved greatly and I may not need the extender to get from the router to the most distant room but as the router is in a utility closet where the modem, Sonos bridge and a few other devices live I'll keep it up.  Our house is about 2,500 sq. ft if that gives you an idea of range.  The signal is robust from every room.
title: Almost perfect

author: Abradolph Linkler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
review_content: I installed this router to replace an old Linksys that was working but had a very poor UI. First thing I noticed was after updating the firmware the first and subsequent reboots took about 3-7 minutes. My Linksys takes 1 minute. Second, the router throttled my bandwidth from 360 Mb/s to 24 Mb/s. I contacted tech support and after spending 21 minutes on hold and a further 6 minutes identifying myself. was able to ask for help. I first asked why the reboot took so long and the tech told me to change the AC outlet that the power adapter was using. He was implying that the voltage was low and was slowing the router.  I actually got a good long laugh out of that.Anyway, after trying to get support form their web chat and being given a bunch more, but less humorous, nonsense I've decided to return this.
title: What a piece of junk

author: Brian E.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2018
review_content: Wow! This wireless router is impressive! I have switched from a 4g Verizon Mifi pack, so I'm probably easily impressed, but just had Charter Spectrum 100mbs installed. Hooked up and speed checked this wireless router on 5ghz and showed a download rate of 228mbs while I was streaming HD video on another device at the same time! Stupid easy to set up via android phone app. Less than 15 minutes from box to blazing fast wifi!Can't speak to longevity, but if you're reading this a few months from now and there are no updates, then it is holding up great!
title: FAST, strong wifi, Simple setup. What more could you want!?!

author: Mimbly Bimbly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2019
review_content: I just have to say....it is about darn time someone made a wireless device that was user friendly and actually works without having to troubleshoot for 3 hours.  For real.  I have an aneurysm when I have to troubleshoot anything dealing with wifi not working because the software / firmware on wifi devices is so atrocious.  This is the router that I have been dreaming of for the past 10 years.  The setup was so easy it was a shock.  I was in disbelief that I was finished with the setup, no lies.  It was so easy to get this running that I am skeptical that it will keep working.  There has to be a catch22 to the world's easiest router to setup right?  As soon as I go to bed, my wifi is going to cut out?  When I wake up, I am going to be on the phone with tech support?The signal is amazing, the smartphone app works, the setup worked, the price is amazing...this is a dream come true.  I have had this thing for about 3 hours and it is already the best router I have ever owned.
title: Hands Down Fastest Setup Ever

author: James Ivie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2019
review_content: I'm not sure how this can be recommended by anyone.  There is no local DNS, so you won't be able to share files between local computers unless you use static IP addresses or provide your own DNS.  TP-Link admits that this is just how it is for this router.  Huh!!?!  I can't imagine what they were thinking.  Every single router I've had for the past 10 years (about 5 of them) has supported local DNS.If that weren't bad enough, it's flaky.  About once a week, one of my PCs can't get to the internet.  It can get to the router, including the configuration page, but can't get out at all, despite the router saying that everything is fine and other PCs and devices work fine.  Rebooting the PC did NOT work.  Only rebooting the router fixed the problem.  I've now seen this four times on more than one device.  Unfortunately, that means I've now had the router just over a month and can't return it.  I guess I have a new paperweight now.  I suppose it's theoretically possible that this could be fixed with a firmware update, but I won't hold my breath.
title: No local DNS, have to reboot weekly

author: Robert A Warren
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2018
review_content: I had read this had VPN support, but it seems only on the server side and not as a client.  In other words you can't use it to connect to a VPN server such as NORD-VPN using the openVPN protocols.  I had also read that you could upgrade the firmware to DD-WRT, but this is version 5.0 and is not supported.
title: Doesn't work as a VPN Client.  Can't upgrade firmware to DD-WRT.

author: G Tyler Mills
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020
review_content: I bought this instead of using the FREE upgrade with my internet provider. It works great WHEN IT WORKS! It literally drops the internet at least ONCE EVERY HOUR.After contacting technical support I finally spoke with someone who was completely incomprehensible. I have absolutely no issue speaking with someone who uses English as a second-language. I truly enjoy their interaction. This representative had no business being in any phone with any customer. I could not understand any part of their speech whatsoever.After literally 30 minutes (screenshots to prove it) I was informed that I should log into the router administrator, install the upgrade if available, and email them the system log. I did that two days ago...guess what still is happening...INTERNET DROPPING CONSTANTLY.I contacted my service provider multiple times and they ensure me that there is no issue with their service, to which I agree.I am seeking a refund.
title: DO NOT PURCHASE IF YOU TELEWORK.

author: Scott S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2020
review_content: Within 3 mo of purchasing this router it kept on suspending my internet connection because of it's security protocol. Generally after several hours of leaving it unplugged it would start working again.  I learned from Dell tech support this is a common problem and that tp link should be able to help me clear out the cache that keeps filling up and causing this problem.  It turned out support couldn't do that but determined it was a hardware defect.  They were willing to replace the router but I had to jump through hoops through email to get this done.  Of course with no internet it was impossible to get to my email to go through the hoops.  I managed about 3 weeks later to borrow this laptop which is junk.  After a week of trying to get my Outlook on this computer to access my email to determine that this laptop didn't work with outlook.  Then the internet provider support finally tells me about their email web portal which was a problem too.  I had to change my password to use it and then a day later I was having trouble with the password.  I finally get to my email and start trying to jump through tp's hoops.  First email wanted me to validate my user ID.  The email said that I had one hour to do so.  This was today, over a month later.  I contact support to try to get another link but they can't send me one.  They send me to a link to register my equipment which keeps telling me to activate my ID.  This was 40 minutes.  Then I call back again and they tell me to go through sign up again which tells me my only email address was already in use and to call support. The guy asks me if I have another email 4 times and I keep on telling him I've already answered no and the answer is not going to change.  Typical of Philippine support from other companies asking multiple times if I have alternatives to whatever we were discussing and going crazy telling them I just don't have any.  TP runs me in circles on this and keep saying there's nothing they can do.  I ask him to ask his supervisor who activates my ID and sends me the link I'd been asking for all morning to the final activation of the ID.  Then the guy just wants to jump off the call and I stop him saying we're not done yet.  I needed to make sure the activation worked.  It did but then there were problems with registering the router.  This guy gets me through this in a tolerable fashion of sorts.  I spent over 4 hours on what should have been about 30 minutes.  I believe part of the problem is Filipinos thing differently.  They speak excellent english but don't get the concepts.  Their support is also poorly trained and TP has some messed up procedures and policies.  Stay away from TP line.  It' will only turn out to be a nightmare.
title: Nightmare

author: Ryan Moth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: I purchased this router to replace the aging 2.4ghz only radio in my CenturyLink modem. Our 40mbps connection was frequently being reduced to sub 5mbps on wifi, making streaming and oftentimes simple browsing impossible. To diagnose the slowdown I hauled our iMac into the living room and tested speeds on a wired connection- and easy 35-40mbps every time. Clearly the router half of our router/modem combo had given up the ghost.I pruchased the A7 based on the myriad of excellent reviews and the superb write-up on Wirecutter. When it arrived I quickly tore into the box and found the instructions a bit too simple for what I ended up doing, but assume they'd be helpful for simpler setups (typical use-cases like AP setup is covered in the paper instructions).Long story short, I disabled the router functions of my modem, connected the A7 to my computer, used the tplinkwifi.net site to input my CenturyLink PPPoE email and password (had to go through customer chat purgatory to get that password- cmon it's 2020 CenturyLink, we want better customer support), set up the SSIDs and passwords for the two wifi bands, rebooted, and plugged the router into my modem.After testing, my wired speeds were unchanged and wireless speeds on the 5ghz network are finally hitting 35-40 mbps. It's a real pleasure browsing and streaming without issue.Pros:-Quick setup with multiple guides online-Excellent speeds on the 5ghz network, maxing out my current plan's speed-No issues with reliability so far-Loads of interesting settings to tweak on the router's site-Comes with additional ethernet cableCons:-The app has limits on what settings can be changed without an 'Cloud' account. That sucks.-The Alexa integration on this is barely passable. It is essentially "turn off the LEDs" or "mess with Guest Network". No QoS control or anything useful on this (admittedly low-end) model.Conclusion: If you want an easy setup and a capable device, buy this! It's great!
title: Easy to Configure, Durability Unknown, Alexa Integration is Nothing

author: Sheila Avery
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2020
review_content: I purchased the Archer A7 model.  I was under the impression that all I would have to do was disconnect the present router and install the new on in the correct outlets.  I was without internet for a week trying to get this router to link with the modem I have and the internet.  I several time attempted to contact the customer service dept for this new router.  At one point their notice was, "Because of coronavirus we are experiencing a heavy volume of calls, so our line are out".  Or something to that effect.  My frustration was great.  Finally with help from a family member I was able to go around their system to get connected to the internet, and then sign into their TP-Link company.  Very frustrating.  It is working now.  But sometimes I log into my computer and have to go and reconnect to the internet, still.
title: This should not be so difficult to get connected

author: tech_dad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
review_content: Purchased to replace a NetGear AC1000 that is 3 yrs old. The NetGear still functions fine but had terrible range and 100 mb cap on it's down stream.Set up was easy. There's 2 ways to do it, I chose the traditional web portal approach. I was able to get it set up within 5 minutes of unboxing. Speaking of unboxing, this router is huge. The specs on here didn't do it justice. The size of this one makes my NetGear look like a child's toy.Upon setup, the signal's default setting is a smart signal which combines both the 2.4 and the 5 ghz band into 1 name and "intelligently" connects to one or the other for the device. I haven't had a chance to split the signals yet. I'm hoping that it will be easy since having just the one seems to be prone to problems.After connecting to the single wifi name, SpeedTest.net reported I was getting roughly ~205 mb. This was a huge improvement to my old NetGear of which on the 5 ghz connection I was maxing out at ~93 mb. This was very promising so I started switching over all our devices and checking the speeds. All the devices within line of sight and 15 feet radius was also reporting higher bandwidth. Some devices similar to the ~200 mb end where the worst was still hitting the ~90 mb range.The better bandwidth is the exact reason why I went with this router, the other being the router's advertised range. Up to 2500 sq. ft. - unfortunately I was not able to get the advertised range. In fact, this unit only extended my range a matter of several feet. My kids' pcs couldn't get a solid connect to the wireless signal and require a range extend. I was hoping I'd be able to get rid of the extender because the advertised range, but that isn't the case.Over all, the better bandwidth is the only win in my experience. I may have to play with the router more to see if I can get the advertised range. If I can improve the range, I will amend this review, but until then, the best I can give it is 3 stars. Too bad..this router has a lot of potential.
title: AC1750 - couldn't get any where near the 2500 sq. ft. of range

author: Matt Cappleman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2019
review_content: It worked perfectly for the first week and then I started to notice that my internet speeds were barely 5 MB/s. This is not due to the cable company or modem because my internet speed was fine when connected directly and not using this router. Within a month the router stopped receiving internet from the modem all together for hours at a time. I purchased this just over 2 months ago and the internet port no longer works at all.
title: It just doesn't work

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
review_content: I purchased this router 4 months ago, one month prior to moving to a new place. Until today, it was a decent purchase. Not wicked fast internet, but you get what you pay for, so I was content. Fast forward to today -- LESS THAN THREE MONTHS AFTER USING -- and this router would not turn on. I woke up this morning and no lights were on. I unplugged it, plugged it back in, nothing. No power outage secondary to storms or anything; it was plugged into a surge-protected power strip along with my printer and laptop--none of which had any issues suggesting an outage. Basically, no reason for this router to have been fine 24 hours ago and then dead as a doornail today. SO, I called their "customer service" to troubleshoot this issue. I was emailed a list of instructions on how to "request" a "replacement." Here is where I decided to go with a different company. The website I was directed to did not appear secure. I was instructed to create a profile with my personal information (phone number, email, address, money info, etc.) which I did not feel comfortable doing. After reading the fine print on one of the "FAQ" pages on said website, I learned that they have 3-5 business days before accepting or rejecting a request, plus the replacement router won't arrive for 1-2 weeks AFTER they receive the defective one. In other words, I was expected to input personal information into a shady website, wait 3-5 days for them to approve the request, go to a post office and PAY to ship the defective router back to the seller, wait for the seller to receive the defective router, THEN receive the "replacement" in 1-2 weeks. NO WAY. I would absolutely not recommend this router.
title: WOULD NOT PURCHASE AGAIN

author: C. Heartwell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020
review_content: When it works, it's fine as a WAP, but I've never had a WAP that lost connection to the router as frequently as this one does.  It goes offline constantly making it virtually useless.  It is connected directly into my WAN router (Xfiniity box) but loses internet several times a day and does not recover without unplugging and replugging either power or ethernet cable.  No other devices that are connected to the ethernet or directly to the router lose connection (or at least they recover seamlessly, so this isn't a DNS issue on the router).  I'm replacing this piece of plastic with something NOT TP-link brand.
title: Only works when it works

author: The Reluctant Critic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2020
review_content: I bought two of these, one the C7 5.0 version, the other this A7 5.0 version. The C7, for whatever reason, outperforms the A7. The C7 can reach 5 Ghz speeds of well over 120mbps, while this A7 struggles to reach 95 mbps. I updated the firmware and it made no difference.Other annoyances: The C7 is able to keep proper time by connecting automatically to an NTP Server. This C7, however, cannot connect to most servers. I did get it to connect finally to a Google time server, but the time was off by 7 months and 12 minutes, so I had to switch to manual time, which disables other options such as scheduled reboots. It drops connections randomly. It will just go completely brain dead. A reboot of the router brings it back to life, but like clockwork it'll go down in a few more days.It's interesting that this router is rated higher on Amazon than the C7 version. But my C7 has been a rock solid performer. It consistently maintains 2.4 and 5 Ghz speeds. I never have to touch it. The only difference, as I understand it, between the two routers is that one has a virtual server and the other doesn't, but I have to believe there are other differences in quality.Or maybe I just got one from a bad batch.TP-Links in this line are rock bottom priced and the quality reveals the chink in the armor. Don't expect to get more than two or three years out of them, which, given the price, isn't all bad. But this router that I am returning is just pure junk. Again, I don't know if it is indicative of the entire line in this class, but this one just doesn't pass muster.
title: Unreliable at Best

author: Lisa Antrobus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2020
review_content: I purchased this router because I was having trouble with intermittent Wi-Fi. The setup was easy and the Wi-Fi worked initially. However when working from home at least once a day my Wi-Fi would go out and my zoom call would drop. This would only last about a minute before it would reconnect, but this means that I would be disconnected from my zoom call and would have to restart. This was extremely frustrating and so I tried to contact customer service for support. I tried looking for a phone number and the first time I called it said that there were no customer service representatives available. I ended up finding a chat option, but the correspondence was frustrating. I was told that the intermittent wifi was caused because the router was not plugged directly into an outlet. I didn't think that this was likely, but was willing to try anything, so I bought additional materials so that I could plug the router directly into the wall outlet. Just like I thought, this did nothing to help. When I reached out again to get additional help, again it was very hard to get somebody on the line. I was so frustrated by the whole process that I decided to just return the product and buy a new one from a different company. I recommend that you do not purchase this product.
title: Intermittent wifi and horrible customer service

author: WhiskeyFellow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: Update 12/30/2020 - I finally gave up. I replaced my router with a different brand and (magically) all the connectivity issues are gone. TP-Link's Customer/Tech support was useless. I suggested a few times the router may be defective and suggested swapping it out for a different one but was turned down. Way to stand behind a warranty!  I've now bumped this down to 1-star.**********I have a love/hate relationship with this router. The interface is easy to use, I love the app. The signal strength is awesome. What's horrible, however, is it keeps losing connectivity to the Internet. I contacted tech support via online chat (about the only way to do it) and waited three hours before I was able to talk to someone who suggested I change the DNS to 8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4, which I did, and that did not solve the problem. After reading up on the 'Net with others who have similar issues, I shut off the Smart Connect which lets the router automatically choose 2.4gHz or 5gHz.There are times I can stay connected for hours, and then it will lose the Internet connection every five minutes. The only way to get a signal is to manually change my device from the 2.4gHz to 5gHz band (and vice-versa).  I've ruled out this is my modem - I have a computer that is connected via Ethernet and it never, ever loses the signal, even when both WiFi bands say "Connected, No Internet."I've changed the channel widths, which do nothing to solve the issue.  I would not recommend this router.I've stopped trying to reach technical support because I simply don't have the time to wait for hours in chat while I lose connectivity while waiting in line.
title: Signal keeps going out

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
review_content: I could not install this router after I received it.  I was in the middle of renovations and had complications.  The return window has closed and I cannot return it now.  This is supposed to be a highly rated router, but never could get it to connect to the internet.  I am more skilled with tech issues than the average person and I finally gave up after trying every suggestion and even watching a you tube video. Maybe it has something to do with the phone company I use for internet service, I just don't know.
title: Difficult to install

author: Jack Burton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
review_content: If you have verizon Fios you can run an either net cord right from the box and straight into this. Verizon charges $12 a month to rent their router and I didn’t know how terrible it was until I spent $50 on this one! The Fios router couldn’t reach our garage, or back yard and had weak signal to the far side of our house. This router, that will have more than paid for itself in 3 months, gives FULL signal to our entire house and nowhere on our 1/3 acre do we get less than 2/3s signal. I can stream from my shed or my car parked in the street out front. Stop paying Verizon their rental fee for a terrible router.
title: Return your Fios router NOW!!!

author: Lisa Marie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: I hate technology; but I need it.  A few days ago, I called Hulu complaining about bad service.  Their tech helped me trouble shoot... bad numbers from my internet provider.  So I called them and they reset my modem and fixed the bugs on their side.. Great!  I'm back up to speed except when I went through my router... less than 1/2 the bandwidth.  Then I called a local store (won't name them) who tried to sell me a $250 router... which Amazon had for $200 and I started crying... What router?  How do I decide?  Well... Amazon's Choice for homes... This router.  I hit add to cart, and buy... two days later, I... alone... without any help; hooked it up in less than 20 mins;  and now my wireless network is cooking at full speed.... and I hear angels singing
title: I hear angels singing!

author: Kingshopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2020
review_content: Have had this product 11 months. Thought I did enough research to buy a reliable longterm router. Much to my surprise in month 11, the wifi started arbitrarily dropping data packets, lowering the transfer rate on both bands. I had terribly severe connectivity problems. No amount of troubleshooting fixed the problem and the wifi eventually became completley useless with no data transfer to any device. I thought connecting via hardwire ethernet would solve my connectivity problems. However, the direct ethernet also severely dropped data packets. Eventually had to replace router with one from a well known company to fix the internet connectivity. I had connectivity issues for a couple of months before the router finally gave up the Ghost.
title: Gave up the Ghost

author: Sagerider
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2020
review_content: I was having trouble with my internet reception with my old wireless router. I call my service provider and they could not find any issues on their end. Having had my older router for several years I thought perhaps the router might be the bottle neck. Turns out I was correct and with the new router no more garbled phone conversations even on the speaker phone activated. I can now put my phone in my front shirt pocket and carry on a normal conversation while walking around my house. This is important because my phone connection goes through my internet connection. I have virtually not cell phone coverage out where I live and the only hope is through the wireless mode on the internet. With no land line my cell phone is my life line to the outside world. This router works wonderfully!
title: Boasted my internet reception!

author: DIY Enthusiast
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2020
review_content: I bought this for $56.99, and it is everything I needed in a home router.The Internet browser interface for setup is very easy to navigate in Basic and Advanced menu, with automatic setup in most key areas.  In my 2100 sq/ft home, the radio with both 2.4 and 5.0 ghz frequencies, will reach the very far corners of the home through two walls well without a repeater.Communication rate is sufficient for just about anything we do around here, with HD and 4K streaming content going across wireless fine. 6 smartphones, and 2 tablets on Wifi, and 2 Desktop office workstations all receive well over 40-60 MB/s wireless DL speeds, and 800 MB/s or better for CAT-7 wired LAN connections.Ours is paired with a Netgear CM600 modem attached via WAN, for Spectrum Cable Internet and 300 Mbps package, and it is feeding 320 Mbps or so for my wired desktop.There are far faster routers out there, but for an average home, this is as fast as anyone needs as internet packages don't really go past 300 typically without expensive Enterprise Packages anyway.And anything faster will jump in price to well over $200.  This is perfect at $57 bucks, and is as good as it gets for that range of average routers these days.
title: Superb performance for the price-point.  Absolutely reliable and easy to setup.

author: Papa Bill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_content: I have a old house and when I say old I mean between 1890 and 1910, my old Cisco router couldn't give me a signal in the back of the house and my house is 1478 Sq ft, and on the front porch I barely had a signal which was around 20+ feet from the router, Well it finally died and we got this archer and I have a 2-3 bar signal in the back bathroom now and well from the front its a totally different story, I can walk across the street to the taco truck in the store parking lot and while sitting there at their bench I have 3-4 strong bars still on my WiFi, funny thing is the store which is at the front of the building is giving me a very weak Xfinity WiFi signal.This thing puts out the WiFi.It was very easy to setup and monitor it.My daughter just got one for her house and had to use extenders for he house for her old Cisco router which was a newer one than mine, and now she has a strong signal to all her nest cameras with no problems.Would I recommend this again.... HELL YEA!Will keep updates if anything new happens.Talking about using my WiFi at the taco truck is making me hungry... Good luck to Y'all on your new great Router, I'm gonna go get a burrito.
title: If I could give the WIFI 10 stars I would

author: AshV8r
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2018
review_content: I was pretty disappointed with this item. Unboxing and set up was a breeze and before I knew it my not-so-tech savvy hubby had it set up and going.... on HIS phone that is. None of the other WiFi devices would work so I had to go through the reboot process. Well even that was easy peasy and all of our devices were up and running off of the WiFi within 30 minutes or so. Well, most of them. The reason we upgraded to this router was because we could not use WiFi in our bedroom and this one promised up to 2500 sqft range. Granted, the router is on the other side of our house, but with only an 1100 sqft home I feel like it should be able to handle going down a hallway.We ended up returning this item. Set up was good, signal/speeds were good wherenit actually reached but range was not as advertised. We switched to a mesh WiFi system (took a chance on the cheaper Nova) and have been amazed.
title: Range not as advertised

author: Jeff Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
review_content: It works as described, and increased our wifi speed from about 30 mbps to 70 on the 5ghz band.  We have a router/modem combo (b/g/n, I think) that seemed to max out around 37 mbps over wifi.  I turned off the router functionality on that unit, and connected it to this router, and the speed increase was instant.  Setup was easy, too.The Tether app makes running things from your smartphone pretty easy, too.  We have since received a speed increase from our ISP, and I have tested speeds as high as 400 mbps on the 5ghz band (100-160 is the normal average).  The 2ghz band is significantly slower (maybe around 50 mbps), but that's the nature of that band.The range is also greatly improved.  I would lose signal in various parts of our yard, but I can now go across the street and get high speed (I've tested as high as 63 mbps before our ISP increased our speed).If you're looking for a budget-friendly way to upgrade an older (especially if you don't have an AC router) setup, I recommend this router.  We have about a 2500 square foot house, and signal is great everywhere.  I imagine you could have a much larger house and still get great signal with this router.The only issue that I've had is that, after a recent firmware update, the name of the router changed.  I had to reset security options and save the password again.  This was a minor annoyance.  The LED indicators can be turned off via the Tether app, and after this update, the timer function for this seems to have lost functionality.  Again, just a minor annoyance.  I just decided to keep the lights off all day, instead of timing them to be off at night.
title: Easy to install,  this router upgraded our wifi performance and range

author: sunnydaysahead
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2020
review_content: edit: another positive thing i notice is that before, whenever i opened my asleep laptop, it would take many seconds for my computer to find the network, and it would always try to connect to the wrong network etc - a constant source of frustration. now that i have this router, i open my computer and it successfuly connects to the right network in a much speedier way :-) big difference.We upgraded Spectrum service to get 200 mb/s but when we did speedtest.net we saw we were only getting like 30-50 and also we kept getting booted off the network/intermittent internet. Spectrum advisor told us to get a router that was Spectrum compatible and could do 400 mb/s - this fit both bills (i saw from reading other comments it works with Spectrum for most people.)  We just got it today and now we are not getting kicked off the network and our mac laptops are now doing 200-220 mb/s  :-) And it connects to our phone.My desktop computer which is older connects to the network too but it is not going much faster, now it's at 50 and honestly I dont notice much of a different between 40 and 200 speeds anyway - you think there would be a lightning fast huge difference but my husband and I both notice a smallish yet noticable happy difference. *We both just use internet for watching YT videos and doing online research. no heavy downloads etc  I guess 40 would be enough for us.  We re both just glad we're not getting kicked off the network anymore, no more intermitten problems, and we are getting the speed we paid for. You could also get a router from spectrum for $5 a month they say (they give u modem for free) but I figure this will pay for itself in less than a year. So I'm happy with it :-) and hope this review helps someone!
title: Works with Spectrum, got our download speed up from 30mb/s to 210 mb/s

author: Cronologic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2019
review_content: Signal is good but data speeds are SLOW on this out of the  box and I'm not sure why.  It might be a configuration setting in the router.  I am going to try to resolve it myself as well as contact tech support.  If I'm able to improve the speeds then I'll update my review but until then, I can't recommend it.  It’s significantly slower than my old router which is over 8 years old and doesn’t even support ac.-------UPDATE----------Updating this to 1 star.  I've never been able to get this router to work as well as it should.  I've updated the firmware, tweaked the settings and changed the location multiple times.  It's slow with ALL of my devices (multiple laptops, a phone and multiple game consoles), even when some of my devices are in the same room.  In addition to this, this signal is quite weak.  Initially I thought it was strong but after some testing I've found out it's not strong at all.  I'm just really disappointed with this router overall.  I see it has decent reviews here on Amazon so it must be working well for some people but this has not been my experience with the product.  It is pretty inexpensive so I guess you get what you pay for in this case.  I wanted to like this router a lot.  If I figure out anything that improves the performance at all I will definitely update my review again but so far it's only been a disappointment.
title: Slow out of the box

author: VOLTAGExDT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2019
review_content: First I was nervous haven’t heard much about tp brandDid some research figured well amazon will back me up on my orderSpeeds are insane.This is from a swap out of a netgear routerThen I messed around with it’s app. Way better.Ok so IFTTT huh?  Let’s see what that can do. Warm me if someone joins my networkAlready found a boy sneaking in to see my daughter as I have same SSID and pass from old router. BustedStill pour reception in bathroom and bedroomHouse it pure brick inside walls as wellSo what’s this OneMesh thing?Well if that ain’t a huge problem solver. 5g all over house seem less switching.ChoiceOk so let’s test this thingCurrently attached to router25 Smart Devices5 iPads2 Apple Watches4 iPhonesApple TV3 Smart TVs2 Xbox’sMy computer I use for a serverMy stoveMy fridgeMy dishwasher5 camerasAnd just for the heck of itA partridge in a pearl treeNot a single meg in net dropped50 up 50down
title: Don’t let the low price fool ya it’s a power house!!!

author: Crazy Diamond
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
review_content: Everything about this router is pretty good, especially the configuration screens.  I ran into two big problems with it, however.  First issue when switching between router mode and access point mode (because I was evaluating this against another router), if you try to switch back to router mode it won't connect to the internet and requires a factory reset.  I tried this twice and had to factory reset it both times to get internet connectivity.The other big issue is that the 5Ghz connection randomly loses internet connectivity...  It'll still show connected to Wifi but there is no connection to the internet.  Reconnecting to 5ghz will solve the problem for a while but I can't make it a day connected to the 5ghz.  The 2.4ghz wifi works fine, 24/7/365 with no problems.  Apparently this is a known issue with Archer A7 and C7 routers, even for folks running ddwrt.  There are very few reviews here on Amazon that bring up this issue.
title: Works fine except for 5Ghz

author: XxAmazon$hoppeRxX
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2020
review_content: If you are specifically trying to use this router for NordVpn services (to be anonymous on the internet), this router is not for you. NordVpn uses a different feature in the routers called "VPN Client." This router only has a "VPN Server" feature. They are not the same. ExpressVPN or iPVanish might work with this router, but I prefer to use NordVPN. You might try calling NordVpn technical support if you are trying to use this router to set up VPN services.
title: This is not for NORD VPN.

author: kalon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2020
review_content: First router we ordered had it setup by our service provider since he was at the house when it arrived, the router lasted 3 hours till all the lights went out and never could get it to turn on. After few rounds with the tech support finally got a new one delivered to replace the faulty one. Now after using the replacement for 4 months quite often have to reset the router because it stops broadcasting internet. Internet light turns orange and all stuff plugged in with network cables stop working also. Have 2 netgear routers and they never miss a beat. Disappointed in this one being it has good reviews and a Amazon recommended product.
title: Poor

author: SenseiPichu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019
review_content: I got this unit since it was on sale and not only that but it had great reviews on it, that and it was from TP-Link a great brand when it comes to networking. I bought this unit expecting a large upgrade over my previous modem/router combo and of course I wasn't disappointed....for the most part. The speeds are amazing and the latency improvement is night/day. However the only thing I don't like is the speeds on the 2.4G, it's CONSIDERABLY slower than the 5G. Which would be fine but I only have an 100MB connection and I only get around half of that on the 2.4G, websites take longer to load and again it's considerably slower. Even at farther ranges the 5G will always be superior in terms of speed. More likely than not I will be switching over to another router that has good both 2.4G and 5G performance however this unit is still a great buy and highly recommended. The app that it has available to it makes things so simple to set up and use it's amazing along with the modem's website.
title: Good router but beware of the 2.4G signal strength

author: Bill Ross
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2018
review_content: The modem/router I was using was one we rented from our service provider for $8.00 a month. At the time it worked fine but over time I noticed there was dead spots in the wifi in the house and it literally dropped off once we stepped out into the yard. My cell phone kept flashing on the that my wifi was disconnected and then it would say "Reconnecting." Finally I decided to get a new modem and we settled for the TP-Link Archer A7. It was easy to setup and works so much better. The back of our house is about 100 ft. from the alley and the modem is maybe 35 ft.  in form the backdoor. There are 2 walls and one of them has kitchen appliances lining up along it.  This is a nightmare situation for wifi. Our new Archer A7 router blasts thru the walls and out the back yard thru the 24x30 garage and gives me prefect wifi in the alley with cellphone or tablet. I am very satisfied with the way this router is working. At this time I would recommend this Modem and router setup to anyone that wants to replace the rented setup this is a good one to use and the cost at $114.00 for modem and router is well worth it.
title: Works great so far

author: Aleks
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
review_content: Issues to consider before buying:1. Devices in the same room prefer to connect to a range extender on the other side of the house. Guess they don't like being too close to the Archer. Not sure if this is something that can be fixed through firmware upgrades, or positioning.2. It is impossible to assign more than 32 (!) reserved IP addresses via DHCP Address Reservation. That is not nearly enough for a smart home with 4 family members, because most SmartHome devices (such as Amazon echos, Chromecasts, smart bulbs, smart switches, etc) do not have the option of assigning a static IP. This is not a difficult issue to fix, and I'm sure the developers are aware of it, so here's hoping they will at least double the number to 64 (or even go up to 256) in some future firmware upgrade.3. The 5G has a relatively short range and minimal wall-penetrating power. Purchasing additional (Dual-band) Range Extenders is a must for larger homes. The TP_Link RE200 seems to work just fine with the A7, but has similar shortcomings.4. The range extenders will change the first 6 numbers of the MAC address of connected devices. Although I understand the need for this, it is still alarming when unexpected MAC addresses start appearing on the router, and makes monitoring online devices more difficult than it needs to be.5. The Tether application is useless for anything but performing a quick basic setup. The web application is much better, but lacks some simple conveniences such as the ability to sort the various lists, or increase the lists to show more than 8 devices at a time.6. The Alexa app could be better. On the plus side, having Alexa understand "Teepee Lynx" instead of TP-Link can be both frustrating and amusing.
title: Not as great as it seems

author: Voiceguy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
review_content: Review originally titled, "Plan to Buy A New One Every Few Months"Here's what I originally wrote:  "When this device works it's great.  Mine failed after 8 months, and trying to deal with TP-Link for technical support or warranty fulfillment is an exercise in futility.  Yet at this price I guess the "rent" for this unit is about $8 per month."So I will just buy another one and hope it lasts at least that long again."I stand by what I said about TP-Link technical support.  However, I was able to get this box to work again.  I did buy a replacement unit but have not opened it.  If my current one continues to work, I will probably return the replacement unit to Amazon unopened.My problems originated with the cable internet provider, Spectrum.  Somehow, my internet modem "fell off the grid."  Although we were getting internet service at home, Spectrum reported that our modem was "off line."  Then after the sixth day in this status our service stopped altogether.  It turned out that our modem needed to be "provisioned" again -- basically set up as though it was brand new service.  Spectrum used obsolete information to do this, so it took several phone calls and two technician visits to get a working internet signal to come out of the cable modem.  I could get internet service with a single computer plugged directly into the cable modem.  But the rest of the household was dark.The problem was that this TP-Link router would not "shake hands" with the cable modem.  The router could see the modem, but would not engage with it to deliver internet service to the router customers.  None of the troubleshooting advice in the TP-Link manual or from their chat-based technical support made the slightest difference.What finally did make a difference was this:  Holding the reset button in (with a bent paper clip) for more than 30 seconds.  The manual says more than 5 seconds is enough, but that's wrong.  After 30 seconds of reset, I was able to navigate to the router's setup screen from my laptop with a hardwired ethernet cable and re-initialize everything (language, time zone, type of service, etc.).  The router finally made a successful connection to the internet signal being provided by the cable modem, and now everything works.Things have been working now for a bit more than a week, so I suspect they will continue to work with this current box.  Clearly the initial blame for everything lies with Spectrum, which messed up our service by somehow un-provisioning it.  But the process of getting this router to work again was needlessly difficult, which is why I offer only four stars.Performance-wise, this unit is quite good, and better than a more expensive Motorola unit that I used previously.  The three antennas on the back seem to generate a very powerful wi-fi signal that easily covers our household.  The wifi signal is servicing two laptop computers, two iPhones, an iPad, a Kindle Fire tablet, an Apple TV box, and a Sony Blu-Ray player's online streaming functions.  They all seem to coexist happily.  The unit is also servicing a Brother printer/scanner and a third computer via hardwired Ethernet (there are four outlets on the back).For the price is seems pretty hard to beat.  And if I run into this kind of problem again I expect to be able to solve it much more quickly.
title: Works Great When It Works, Which Is Most of the Time

author: D. O. Kashinski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2020
review_content: BLUF: I would buy again. I do recommend it to others. Works as advertised.May 2020:Used this router to replace the Verizon FiOS Quantum Gateway router.  I connected to the ONT with existing CAT5e cable, plugged it in, it grabbed an IP, and we were off to the races...400/400 Mpbs (usually).I don't do heavy network use at home. We have two iPhones, a laptop, and an AppleTV.  I can't claim I've pushed the limits of this router.  Its likely overkill for what I need.I did have to update the Firmware. It came with 2018 Firmware installed.  It now has the latest (2020).  Needed the update to do smart 2G/5G switching under one SSID. They call it "Smart WiFi".Might be getting higher upload than download speeds at times.  Not sure if that is a function of the router or the service.  Topping 380Mbps always.  Uploads have gone over 550 Mbps.I used this router for a few days THEN called Verizon to have the rental router removed from my bill making sure the tech new I was using my own. I wanted it off the bill, with a return order number in-hand, before returning the Quantum Gateway Router.Power has been out several times since first hookup and it comes right back on within 2min of restored power.Will post back if my assessment changes.
title: Replaced Verizon FiOS Quantum Gateway Router (already connected to ONT with CAT5e)

author: 𝗡𝘆𝗮𝗻
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
review_content: This was to boost our 5GHz signal from our other TP-Link which wasn't reaching the other corner of the house.  This also caused our Nest camera to disconnect frequently so ended up using a long 100 ft Ethernet cord to connect the router and place it in the basement.The signal is very strong now and is helping the bottom half of the house.  I may get another one down the road as the 5GHz's nature of bandwidth of course means it doesn't really reach far including my yard towards the shed.  The setup is very simple and explained well.Very happy with the overall quality from TP-Link as always!
