title: Excellent router to extend our signal!

author: Steven H. Leibson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review_content: Bought this router during Prime Day for $40 after discounts. Needed something to work as a secondary router to back up my AT&T DSL router, which has WiFi radios that are a decade old and does not support 5GHz WiFi. Studied ways to make a router into a secondary router on YouTube, but it wasn't necessary. You need to access only two settings to make this router work as a secondary router and auxiliary WiFi. The first is setting the password when you first access the AC1750 router's Web-based interface. The second is to set Access Point Mode with a drop-down menu. At that point, you just plug the AC1750 router's "Internet" (WAN) port into one of your primary router's Ethernet ports and power it on. In about two minutes, you'll have two new WiFi Access Points listed on your computer's networking list. I've had the AC1750 router for five hours as I write this and it has already proved its worth in my application. My WiFi is faster going through the both AC1750 and the AT&T router than just the AT&T router. It's the radios.
title: Super simple access point mode

author: Amanda M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2020
review_content: I liked this router while it worked. It was easy to set up, the wifi signal was good, and the app was handy and easy to use. But the router died in the middle of a firmware update about a year and two months after I purchased it. At first customer service seemed great--they quickly acknowledged the device was faulty and said they'd send me a replacement since it was still under warranty.There were different shipping options--I could pay to send it back myself and then once they received it they'd ship me the replacement, no other charges, but that sounded like it would leave me without wifi for too long. So instead I chose to pay $15 immediately for them to ship me the replacement in 3-5 days, plus a prepaid return label, with the condition that if I didn't return the defective unit within 25 days of the date I submitted the request, I'd be charged the full price of the replacement router ($65). This was on 11/18. A week later the status of my request still said "Preparing Shipping." I was working from home and needed reliable internet, so I decided to get a router through my ISP and was quickly back online.I immediately sent a message asking TP-Link to cancel my request for a replacement router since the status indicated it still hadn't been shipped yet anyway, and I received a reply acknowledging receipt of my request. I also chatted a couple days later with someone through their website who told me that I just had to wait for an email letting me know the replacement had been canceled. Then this past Monday 12/7, 20 days after I had submitted my initial request for a replacement (which was supposed to be shipped in 3-5 days), a box showed up at my door with the replacement router I told them I no longer wanted.I received an email that same day telling me they had to receive the faulty router back BEFORE 12/15 or I would be charged full price for the replacement. So after they took their time shipping me the replacement even after I canceled, they left me with approximately 1 week to get the faulty router back to them, meaning I had to rush to get it to FedEx and now have to hope it will be delivered fast enough (something I have no control over) so that I don't have to argue with someone in customer service about removing the charge from my account.Based on this experience I cannot recommend this router or the company, and would not purchase from them again. The guy from my ISP who set up my new router told me if you're going to get a third party router, NetGear is the best, so that's what I'll probably go with next time.
title: Unfortunately Cannot Recommend

author: SumTxDude
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2019
review_content: Needed to update my old aging router so I picked this up on black Friday.Super easy installation, simple phone app to walk you through. App shows you what all is connected, easily name your network and devices, change passwords, control connections.. block, time limits of usage (parental controls), set-up guest connections.. and other things I haven't explored. Haven't used advanced functions.. USB port, flash drive, etc can't report on those features. Have everything hard wired at our living room TV.. Roku, TV, Blu-ray with ethernet cords. Cell phones, Chromebooks, bedroom TVs, etc wirelessly.. five or six connections at once no problem. Strong signal.. reaches out to my shop, my old unit wouldn't do that. Both 2.4 and 5 connections available and seen separately by devices to choose from.All I can say is it works well for me as a basic access point at a fair and modest price point compared to whats available and setup was simple.For the way I use it anyway.. it's easy to recommend. Good Luck!
title: Easy Install. Easy to use. Works!

author: Jessica Paredes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2020
review_content: 7/24: I purchased a different router brand and I have had NO internet/WiFi issues. I even get speeds of over 350 Mbps, something I couldn't reach with TP-Link.7/22: Changed from 4 stars to 1 star. My ISP connection is fine but the router will turn off WiFi and hard wire connections 3 to 4 times per day even though all status lights are on, showing it is working. I contacted their customer service who told me to hard wire my connection directly to my ISP modem to determine if the disconnect was from my ISP. I hate when companies don't believe you when you know how to troubleshoot. The connections were completely disconnecting because the router is malfunctioning, not because my ISP was down. The speeds are not consistent. You will have to disconnect and reconnect to the router's wifi several times per day to maintain 250+ Mbps. If you don't, within an hour, the connection will drop to 20 Mbps. Returning and purchasing a different brand.7/4: I had a little difficulty setting up but after resetting my modem, it was able to recognize the IP to finish setup. I was able to set up the router right from my phone. There is a QR code available to download the app. Very happy with my purchase!
title: Doesn't work

author: Richard
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2020
review_content: A couple years ago I tried to install a router.  It got so complicated and confusing I returned it and reinstalled my old one.  Finally the old one gave out and I purchased this one.  So much easier!  That is important.  But there are a few things that will help eliminate some smaller frustrations that I think remain. First, you have two options for installing the router.  The first one is by phone app.  The other is by browser.  If you go by browser just make sure you have internet access.  I chose the phone app.  Be aware that if you do not already  have a TP-Link account you will have to create one before installation.  Be sure that your email is filled in at the top of that form.  The other thing is that you will need your SSID password which is at the bottom of your router.  If you have trouble with seeing small fonts it might be wise to have a magnifying glass handy.  When I went through this I noticed that there were two SSID's listed.  These are the numbers preceded by AD.  One had a _ (underscore) 5G after it and the other did not.  In my case (and probably yours) the password applies to the SSID with the 5G.  Once learned, the process to complete was quick and easy. It is also wise to follow the directions carefully which are very clear and well illustrated.  Be aware that if you have a modem with a backup battery, you will be asked to take it out when you are  disconnecting it.  Remember to reinstall it when you start powering back up.  Also, you are told to verify that the four LED lights are on.  Just know that this can take a few minutes when powering up. When you first plug the router in it will look like nothing is happening.  Be patient.Although I just installed this router, it seems to be doing a great job.  I had a lot of "loading" issues on my streaming channels with my old router and now they seem to have disappeared.  That said, I think you will be happy with this product.
title: VERY EASY TO INSTALL IF YOU ARE AWARE OF A FEW THINGS

author: Desarae
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2020
review_content: For the past 4 months I’ve been paying for amazing internet and never experienced the wireless speed until I got this router. With my previous router, an internet speed test on my phone said my download speed was 2.7Mbps and upload was 4.0Mbps. After setting up this wifi (in less than 10min), my download speed was 225Mbps and upload was 10.9Mbps.If your wireless connection is slower than what you’re paying for, I recommend troubleshooting with an internet speed test.1. Connect your lap top directly to your modem and check speed. This will tell you if you need to contact your internet provider.2. Connect directly to your router via Ethernet. This will tell you how much slower your router is sending the signal.3. Check the speed with your phone or PC without direct connection to the router. You should know by step 2 if you need a new router.I am no expert. In fact, I asked a million questions to my internet provider and friends. This was based on my experience.
title: It works. Buy it

author: Donna S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2018
review_content: Didn’t work as expected returned.
title: Didn’t work properly with Xfinity

author: jackbnimble
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
review_content: Let me start by first saying I am really peeved with TP_Link over the fact that they roll out products with very, very, very short shelf life.  Specifically, Archer A20 routers which are very expensive and are already "end of life" and no firmware upgrade for OneMesh.  Hence why I was forced to purchase the very much less expensive A7 to hook it up to the A20 and get OneMesh from by Tp-Link RE220 extenders.  The A7 is an excellent router; works perfect with OneMesh; familiar interface; lots of great features for home use and small office, and has vastly improved and simplified my life as to not continuously play IT support for everyone in the house with respect to connectivity, availability and signal strength during this unfortunate, pandemic time of extremely heavy usage of Internet.  I highly recommend the A7 and shame on you TP-Link for sticking us with the vey, very expensive A20 and then dropping the ball on longevity.
title: excellent mesh router

author: Carol Brundige
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2020
review_content: Kept trying WI-Fi gizmos and getting stuck and giving up. Had to over come headaches and send them back. Tech support from Spectrum finally sent a man. He blamed the new device. Did not know why it was not connecting.One router  company upper echelon tech support walked me thru all the steps again. Checked my computer.They are not sending you a signal!  No internet after trying to install several different new routers. Old modem alone worked fine.Finally got mad and bought budget (simpler?) version. This terrific router. Called Spectrum different number and received serious tech support. I was coded wrong. Not me, not the routers. I live in a converted old school brick and stone,aluminum studs in new walls. Side of a mountain. Excellent reception all thru my apartment and down the halls and down three flights and outdoors. Might try the extenders next. See if I can get up the hill, good reading spot.
title: At last!

author: Irina Chukhray
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
review_content: I bought this because router was still in excellent working condition but my internet service was faster than the router could handle. I saved the old TP router for emergency. This new one is really great! Super easy installation instructions. We have 2 laptops, 2 smartphones, an apple TV, and an iPad...all now work great!TIP: if you are changing both your modem and router, start by changing out just one of them. Then, after things work, change the other one. I found that using this method, I did the setup for a new router and modem in about 20 minutes total with zero technical issues. In years past, I tried switching out both at the same time and that really caused time, headache, and problems...costing several hours of frustration.
title: Beautiful movie picture quality

author: jplcom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2019
review_content: I've been running this router as my primary Wi-Fi and routing device for the last 24 days.  I purchased it to replace a TP-Link N600 that was finally giving up the ghost 5 years later with almost daily restarts to get wireless and internet routing functional.Pros:1.  Does as good or better job than the N600 it replaced in terms of Wi-Fi performance.2.  Interface was straightforward to program in.3.  Familiar design aesthetic which is unobtrusive.4.  Plug and play with good host of options.Cons:1.  No long able to set bandwidth limits on guest network.2.  User interface completely revamped from older UI and more mobile phone friendly.3.  Only 1 USB port compared to the 2 USB ports on the N600 it replaced.Unexpected bonuses:1.  The night time setting where it turns off all lights on the router is a MUCH appreciated quality of life I wish ALL electronics had.2.  Initial setup from phone app extremely easy and I could walk non-tech people through the setup.
title: Another solid entry for TP-Link

author: Merlynus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2020
review_content: I bought this as my service provider's modem / router just didn't seem to have the signal strength. I kept losing the signal watching TV in another room, etc.  I received this today. Set up took about 10 minutes initially. It took perhaps another 30 minutes in advanced settings to set up Mac filtering, change WiFi names, etc..  I did not set it up with the cloud or Alexa. Still the set up was fast and easy.  I ran a few speed tests and the improvement is amazing. With the old wireless I rarely pushed over 60 Mbps download, even though I pay for 100. As can be seen by one of my tests this thing is at 99.93 download and 100.41 upload. Both are vast improvements. This was ran from a laptop in another room from the router. I am very satisfied. Also after set up there was a firmware upgrade notification. No need for the cloud,etc.. I clicked on the manual update. It downloaded and automatically installed. If you are looking for a good router for a great price this is the one to get.
title: A great router for the price

author: R. Simmons
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2020
review_content: My old router was failing so after looking around I ordered this one. I have been very happy with this router everything has been working very well. It was easy to setup and is much nicer than the one it replaced which was a Netgear N600 WNDR3700v4. I edited and named all my clients so I can easily know what they are. This was something that never worked on my old Netgear, on my old Netgear most of the clients I would edit and they would revert back without staying how I named them. But this TP-Link edits well so now I am very happy.Everything is working top notch and the user interface is much better too, very easy to use and understand and everything works well. I also was able to mount it to the side of my cabinet using the eyelets on the bottom which was something I wasn't sure it had or not but it did, so I am glad it was easy to hang on its side since I did not have a good place to just have it sit. Great router I am very happy with it.
title: Very Happy With This Router

author: GK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
review_content: My trusty ASUS router finally passed away after six years of service. I considered getting another ASUS, but decided it was time for a change.On a whim, I purchased this router. I had it setup in about 10 minutes. I used the same SSID and password, so all my devices connected again without issue.I was getting about 50 Mbit~ on the ASUS over 802.11n (for some reason, 802.11ac would not work on the ASUS). With the TP-Link, I averaged 200 Mbit~ via fast.com and speedtest.net. This is on 802.11ac using an 802.11ac USB wireless adapter.I would strongly recommend this router to anyone looking for something that is easy to configure and perform well. With over 20 wirelessly connected devices in my home, the TP-Link handles it all beautifully.
title: Wicked fast speeds!

author: James B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2020
review_content: I have Verizon FIOS and want to replace the old Verizon router with something new. Archer A7 has a very good reviews on the  internet as a cheap replacement. But no luck... The Wi-Fi signal is a pretty good and cover my home, but the router constantly lose access to internet, and I need to reboot it 3-4 times a day to solve the issue. Remote management is useless if you lose access to internet, you cannot reboot it remotely. And, if you on Wi-Fi now, you even don't receive notification that you lost internet. That is annoying, so returning.
title: Constanly lose Internet access

author: J. Baylor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2019
review_content: I purchased this to replace an outdated router that I had given my mom years ago.  It has a good strong signal. The house is  a 2,400 ranch with the router on one end and the signal is strong at the other end of the house. It has nice features and an easy to navigate interfaces.The issue came when I connected her Roku smart tv to the 5ghz band. It lost it's connection at least once a day and the router required a reboot to re-establish a connection.  I switched it to the 2.4ghz band and it has not disconnected once since.
title: Good but not great

author: BrianW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2020
review_content: If you google Archer C7 dropped signal or wifi disconnect you'll see that this is a constant problem for this router, and it looks like other TP Link routers. Some people seem to have luck with a factory reset fixing the problem, but I've done this and had no luck. There doesn't seem to be any resolution provided from TP Link on their site, either, just customers talking about it and what they've tried to resolve it.It's an incredibly annoying problem. My devices will stop playing music all the time because it looses single. Smart plugs get disconnected. Videos on wireless devices will stop if they didn't finish buffering. I've been trying for 6 months to figure out how to fix this since it's far too late to return.
title: Do not buy, constantly drops signal every few minutes

author: Beth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2019
review_content: Typically i dont leave nearly negative reviews but this was just horrible. Would have left a better one because i finally got it working but read more for info:Replacing a wifi router that we have been using for almost 10 years (netgear 28 dollars new) to boost the wifi a bit for live streaming.First: Took forever to find a support number and was forced to call three time. The first time the woman could not understand my accent (kentucky) so hung up. Second was a young man, began telling me how to set up my NETGEAR router, which was unneeded but i let him finish cause he was so excited to help and just tried to cut my losses and tried amazons support number. I tell him my name, and he continues to call me stephanie throughout the call, while people are screaming at me to hurry up and while that is what really was pissing me off, his calling me by the wrong name set me off and i hung up.Second: giving up on any help i start going through questions on here, an hour in the no wifi and people are yelling and screaming at me while im tryijg my best to figure this stupid thing out, i reread the instructions and take it a little slower, have to try every single set of data on it before just giving up.Third: after giving up completely, all of a sudden the netflix on the tv just suddenly hooks up. There is a lot of buffering now, but im going to give it a day, if this keeps up, sending it back without question.Will update tomorrow. But right now not very pleased.Update: Little better than I thought it would have been, and the more research I do, the better it seems to get. The price is okay but will definitely be getting a extender soon to get to the farther parts of the house
title: Worst setup ever.

author: Scott B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2020
review_content: I now own two of these for full coverage of the house. This second one replaces the Sagemcom router that the cable company supplied. It is plugged into the modem and configured as a router with the second Archer configured as an access point. I set both units to use the same SSID broadcast name at the 2.4Ghz band and tacked on _5G to the name for use with the 5Ghz band. In this case there is only one SSID name shown on a device for each band even though there are two routers providing coverage. Devices will automatically switch if the signal strength becomes too weak at one or the other. There is an additional feature available that combines the 2.4Ghz & 5Ghz bands as well so that a single SSID name provides all coverage but I did not implement this. It is supposed to allow devices to switch automatically between 2.4 & 5Ghz bands.
title: I own two of these and they are reliable

author: V. Kumar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
review_content: update 5/13/2020===============Working fine. There is a bug in the Dynamic DNS. Please be aware of this problem.The TP link Dynamic DNS works so long as you are accessing the url OUTSIDE your LAN. However, if you try to use the Dynamic DNS url INSIDE your LAN it does not work. It took me long time to figure this bug. Yes I disabled all firewalls but it is the same behaviour. Looks like  Some consumer routers do not support NAT loopback (based on googling - not a network expert). I had no such problems in netgear router. This is definitely a bug and most likely the tp link folks will revolve this in their next update (tp link are you listening?)Don't get me wrong. This router is good for average user.  Setup was easy.I had the following issues:(1) TP link DDNS SERVICE is not working(2) ADDRESS RESERVATIONS for ALL my IP CAMERA'S does not work - Complains that the MAC address is invalid. For the record, I was able to use the SAME MAC address  in my previous netgear router and it worked like a charm. Obviously my MAC address are correct!(3) The wall mount holes are not well designed! I want TP LINK to really test this with REAL USE CASE of wall mounting with regular screws that MOST US persons will buy from the hardware store. I stuck it with a double sided velcro (not the ideal solution for product that will heat up)Today (4/19/2020 around 5 pm EST) I did chat with TP Link support (Id of the person is 15693875) . The person was "not very knowledgeable" on the "most popular product in Amazon" (a Shame) and unfortunately the person was not able to resolve my issues. The support person did confirm that my email was registered for the DDNS to work but was not sure why? He did request me to enter the MAC address in ALL CAPS which I had already tried and it failed. I will update this review if I get a response from TPLINK.[4/21/2020] CHANGED MY REVIEW TO 4 STARS(1) NOIP DDNS is working not TPLINK(2) Address Reservations works - The format of 'dash' instead of 'colons' and all CAPS is enforced. However, the reservation comes into affect only after next recycle - it is not immediate (takes time) - Interestingly when I uploaded the screenshot to Chat support they did not correct me!!!Since I am able to solve all my issues myself I changed my ratings to 4 stars from 2 stars.  Not sure long term have this performs. But for the money this is a GOOD VALUE though the Web Interface is clumsy
title: This is good AVERAGE router for the Money

author: Volodymyr Kleban
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2019
review_content: In contrast to its slightly more expensive C7 brother, A7 is not supported by stable version of OpenWRT yet, but snapshot is installable just fine straight from its factory firmware upgrade page.I bought it to use as WDS client of my existing C7. Just followed the WDS guide from OpenWRT.org, and it instantly connected to the C7.I wasn't actually looking for a router. I just needed an AP client (WiFi bridge) for my WiFi incapable hardware. Paradoxically I wasn't able to find any cheaper and better rated bridge in AC1750 category than a full blown router!If it proves to be reliable option, I will replace the other AP client I have with another Archer A7 to complete migration of all wireless hardware in my house to 802.11ac
title: The best OpenWRT router now got a cheaper brother

author: Hillary Hunt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2020
review_content: SIMPLY the BEST router right now. This was recommended to us by the brother-in-law and The Wirecutter.We have: XFinity Comcast cable internet base internet PLUS speed boost for $15 a month for a total speed of 175 Mbps. This router supports these speeds. We use a Motorola Surfboard modem. We have up to 13 devices connected at any time.Before replacing our old af Netgear W100 or whatever it was, we were getting 13-19 Mbps.After ordering this and setting it up (which was easy and fast), we are achieving 180+ Mbps. This is more than what we are paying for! These speeds are from two different speed tests (SpeedTest app and Xfinity Xfi speed test).Highly recommend. We thought our slow internet was because of congestion due to COVID-19. We were totally wrong. Replace that old router!
title: This is the router you need for lightening fast internet!

author: Bob S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: Purchased this for use as an addition Access Point for a clients Guest Lounge.  Called tech support for a setting I couldn't find in the menus and they said I couldn't set the WiFi channel I wanted when it was in AP mode and Smart Select is on (auto selects 2.4GHz or 5GHz channel for the connecting device).  Sadly, tech support really wasn't up to speed on the router.  I found the solution by taking the router out of Smart Select so that the two WiFi bands are separated.  Made the channel selection I wanted and then back to Smart Select mode.  The channel selection stayed at the channel I selected. Documentation is lacking and tech support couldn't answer any of my questions.  Menu's are somewhat confusing.Decent router for the money and no problems with speed on 300/300Mb/s service.
title: Decent router

author: chemao
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: I have a pretty extensive home network at my house. In the past I've used predominantly Cisco/Linksys or Netgear devices. Lately however, I have stop using Linksys devices because their reliability is not what it used to be. This router is replacing a two year old Linksys router. Routers utilize solid-state circuitry and shouldn’t be failing as often as they do.  Netgear router‘s seem to be reliable although my reason for not using Netgear is due to their awful firmware. I had a pair of Netgear nighthawk router’s set up in my house. Those routers were purchased because they supported OpenDNS which allows you to have very reliable and easy to configure content filtering for children and for advertisements. Despite the fact that the router Is advertised as supporting OpenDNS, Netgear pushed out an update which rendered OpenDNS unusable. Netgear partnered with Disney and are forcing you to use the absolutely awful and practically useless Disney circle content filtering for children. Not only does it not work and ends up filtering just about everything, rendering the computer useless, but there’s no way to turn it off and return to using OpenDNS.  I called tech-support about it and not only did they not even understand the terminology that I was using while discussing the problems with the router, but they were truly slow and stupid. For a simple question, it would take them five minutes to look up an answer when anybody with a grade C in high school computer science should be able to answer those questions.  They were idiots and I was stuck with a router that I purchased for a specific advertised function which they removed less than two months after I purchased the hundred dollar router brand new. That’s pretty pathetic and I won’t support Netgear any longer due to their unfair business practices. On The front and rear of my house, I employ two TP-Link WNR841N routers. They were only $20 when I bought them about five years ago. These two routers cover my front yard and my backyard for when I have guests over or am doing yard work.  These inexpensive routers have been running for all of this time, protected only by old candy boxes which I painted and sealed for exterior use. That being said, these two TP-Link router‘s have been outside in the weather at temperatures as high as 103 in the summer and as low as 15° below zero. They have never failed once. I never have to reboot them [although the firmware has an option to schedule automatic reboots which I do once per week to refresh DNS and NetBIOS entries], I never have to do any updates on them, and so far I’ve never had to replace them.  Over the last six or seven years I have been purchasing almost nothing but TP-Link  router‘s for people that ask me to help them with their network or computers. I have never gotten any complaints from anybody about their router, and the oldest one that I bought is about seven years old and it still works, although I’m not using it anymore because my two main routers need to support 802.11 AC. This is the second router of this model which I purchased. The first one was purchased for a friend of mine who had problems at his house with a D-Link router that stopped working after just over a year. That was about a year ago so far and he's never called about it. No news is good news; I assure you.  I bought this to replace my Netgear Nighthawk which I mentioned earlier. I installed it about two weeks ago and so far have not had a single issue with it. The interface is very fast and the WiFi signal is very reliable. The way they laid out the GUI Is nice but the menu on the left has a pretty big flaw.  The menu on the left employs a collapsible menu design which extends past the bottom of the screen if you open any of the menus, rendering the other options impossible to see or interact with. There is a scroll bar for you to use but the scroll bar is tiny and automatically disappears into the background so you don’t even know there’s a scroll bar there. TP-Link should re-think the menu design. I would also like to see them allow you to save changes per page without restarting the router. I experienced some minor inconvenience while setting up my router because on a couple of occasions I wanted to make multiple changes to the settings before rebooting the router and enabling those changes, however the router doesn’t provide a method for you to save changes without rebooting right away.  Despite the couple of firmware design mistakes, I am quite satisfied with this router and would definitely buy again. It's undoubtedly going to be an even better (damn near perfect, probably) certainly be more satisfied after I install open WRT on it. I will continue to be a TP Link customer for as long as they keep their prices low and quality at or above where it is now.
title: Better than Netgear; better than D-Link

author: Larry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2019
review_content: I had a different brand router, NETGEAR, that kept dropping out and not connecting to some of my peripherals through wifi.  I kept struggling with it, the user interface was very good, and eventually got it to work but it just kept happening and I ran out of things to trouble shoot and just got fed up with it.  So, I did some research and listened to my son-in-law and got this TP-link router.  It was relatively easy to set up, the user interface is not as nice and clear as the other router I had but it has worked since I set it up.  So, that's a big win for me and sure cuts down on the frustration.  Of course I had to reconnect everything that had wifi with the other router but that was relatively painless.  The lights indicating connection status are on the front of the router and very clear and helpful.  I'm very happy with this new router and as I said, the user interface and software for troubleshooting leave something to be desired but they do work.  Maybe it just takes some time to get used to the different menus and logic of the software.  I would recommend this for those that need a dependable, simple and fairly inexpensive router.
title: Very good router with nice display

author: R. Muhammad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2020
review_content: I purchased this in 2018 and never had an issue until 10.9.2020 when it suddenly started smoking. I have a home network and use surge protectors I have no other power issues with devices plugged into the same protector. i contacted support who were very courteous. first i was told the device was known to be defective and they would replace it after providing POP and S/N i was then told my warranty expired and there was nothing more they could do but offer a lousy 15% discount. I am done with TPLink products i have another product 8-port hub that also stopped working which i will be reviewing as well.  BTW i purchased an ASUS wifi router the same time as this one and it is still going. I will purchase an updated model since i am leaving that at my other office.
title: 2 year product lifecycle (WARNING)!!!

author: Alabama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2019
review_content: Doubled my speed on interent wifi speed test over my old router.Setup was kind of clumsy , I stumbled through it and got it done but I  was never sure during the whole process if I was doing the right thing.But so far so good now that it is up and running .My old Linksy was slow as wagon wheels but it was reliable and stable, I hope this new one is as reliable.
title: Doubled my internet speed.

author: JM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2020
review_content: (UPDATED REVIEW TO REFLECT SUPPORT EXPERIENCE)This router has great reviews in the tech press and comes with a nearly unheard-of two years of technical support. The WiFi signal is consistently excellent, even in the crowded airwaves of an urban apartment and in the challenging environment of thick plaster walls and steel girders. Configuration is easy and intuitive for basic features, albeit somewhat limited in terms of configurability of advanced features. The ability to have the same SSID for the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz networks and for devices to switch back and forth between bands seamlessly depending on which signal is better is great. (That also applies to the Guest networks.)The major caveat is that this is a budget router. It's a great value for the price, but it's still a budget router. If your needs are simple and your network is reasonably uncrowded, there's nothing not to like about the Archer A7. Unfortunately, my network has a large number of devices on it with high inter-device bandwidth consumption (video streams, etc.), which overwhelmed the Archer A7's single-core processor and limited RAM. This caused my wired network speeds to slow down to 60% of the speeds I got with a different, more powerful router.TP-Link technical support is fair. The front-line agents are based in Asia, and hold times were long at times. The agents tried to be helpful but had limited resources at their disposal, particularly for my atypical situation. When I was finally told that a Level 2 technician would call me back, the promised time for the call came and went three times. Eventually, and with much persistence, I was able to get hold independently of an empowered, technically savvy manager in the U.S., and he was extremely helpful, knowledgeable, and supportive. He went out of his way to make up for the earlier difficulties, and he made everything right. After assessing my needs, he was able to guide me to a more appropriate, more powerful router, and he made all the arrangements for me. He went above and beyond.I wish the experience with the front-line agents hadn't been so difficult, but the manager (C.M.) made up for it and convinced me that TP-Link is a good company that, in the end, cares about its customers' satisfaction and wants to see its products performing well.
title: A excellent budget choice, but possibly not for the power user

author: B. Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2019
review_content: I bought this router because of the speed and reviews, but it's been a pain since I received it last Friday evening. It's dropping the internet anywhere from 10 minutes to one hour after each reboot. Called their support desk, had bad connection at first, then with a little language barrier problem, the lady did help me connect back to the internet fairly fast, but my internet connection only lasted about 10 minutes. So for the weekend and New Years I hooked my old Linksys wifi router back up and have had no problems. I thought I'd try it again this morning and I got 20 minutes of internet before I lost it again. Thought I'd give this review before I lose my internet connection again. I did update my firmware, as it showed I had a update when I logged into the router. The router automatically did it. I am thoroughly disgusted, because I thought this would be a great and fast router. It is fast when it's working. UPDATE: TP Link engineers contacted me and thru email in a couple of days my internet dropping problem has gone. It's been up now for going on 2 weeks and no problem, working great. Thanks TP Link support/engineers
title: TP Link AC1750 A7 router keeps dropping internet: UPDATE

author: Varsha
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2020
review_content: I had a confusion between Netgear NightHawk and TP Link Archer A7 which have really few differences but very different prices. TP Link models are relatively cheaper than Netgear and honestly, I have been using this router for more than 2 years now and have no complaints whatsoever. The Quick Setup makes the router configuration extremely easy and you can also use the generated QR code to connect to the router. It also comes with one Guest connection each for both 2.5GHz and 5GHz frequencies. This is compatible with my 1 Gbps connection. Have not experienced any issues with the speed and have not observed any hangs with more than 7-8 devices connected to it. There is complete coverage in every corner of our big house with download speeds of around 300-400 Mbps. So, there is absolutely nothing to complain about. I would always recommend it.
title: Satisfied!

author: Jenni
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
review_content: This router was SUCH a disappointment! I researched for weeks because my family wanted an upgrade to a router that supported 5G. After much research, this item seemed to be the best deal, so home it came.I will say this, setup was a breeze! Their user interface is outstanding.  However, after getting everything up and running, our signal would intermittently stop working. My son loves Roblox, and he wouldn't be able to play for more than 5 minutes before he would get a connection error. Ugh! Happened on every device in the house... just spinning wheel of death. Even just to shop on here, I'd have to turn off wifi, or every other page was a cute picture of a dog with "Uh oh" on the screen. So. Frustrating!I searched to troubleshoot, did a factory reset, everything to no avail. Happened every single time it would be up and running.I guess you get what you pay for. Needless this router went back, and I purchased a different brand and have had ZERO issues. Buyer beware.PS. The return process was wonderful as well. Might be worth a shot... but only if your Woosah game is strong. I have kids. That went out the window 9 years ago.
title: Intermittent Weak Signal - a BUST

author: fitnessguy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: I bought this router to replace the basic N*tgear one provided by my cable company at $5 per month rent.  I’m able to use the WiFi at the edge of my backyard which I couldn’t do before.  After using it for a month I haven’t had to unplug/power cycle it at all.  With my N*tgear I regularly had to unplug it once a month or more.Parental controls are easy to set up after installing the TP Link Tether iPhone app.  I can pick and choose which devices in my house to apply internet restrictions.  Both of my hdtvs will not connect to websites with “y*utube” in the web address or any other search word I pick such as “f*cebook”.I can pick what hours to allow internet access for each device daily.  Another feature I like about this router is the smart WiFi option.  Instead of two separate WiFi networks one for 2G and one for 5G we only have one network.  The router will pick the fastest network for each device 2.4 or 5 GHz and switch when needed.  Inside my house I get max speed on 5 GHz.  When I go outside my iPhone switches to the slower 2.4 GHz since that signal reaches farther than 5 GHz.  No more switching networks manually.You don’t have to spend a lot of money for a good router.  I highly recommend this one !
title: Strong WiFi, good parental controls

author: Captain Anonymous
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: This thing is nice and fast most of the time, but will occasionally just stop working.  When this happens, the router maintains its internet connection, which can be tested by using the ping or traceroute diagnostic tools on the router's web interface.  However, connected devices will no longer have access to that internet connection.  In some cases, only one connected device will be allowed to connect to the internet while others, connected to the router via cable or wifi, will not be granted internet access.Until recently, this has been a once-every-few-weeks occurrence, and a router restart has fixed it.  The past few days, it's happened multiple times a day.  This morning, it took multiple reboots and a manual (via the paperclip button) factory reset (which didn't actually seem to change any settings) to convince it to let any device but my primary PC online.  I'm running the latest firmware update, have a simple dynamic IP ISP connection, and have not made any major settings changes aside from a mostly-default wifi configuration.Seeing as it is particular about doing the thing I bought it to do, I have a hard time recommending it.
title: It's not always in the mood for routing

author: Angel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2020
review_content: I had this product about 2 months, when I first plug it in it was working how it should be, wasn't kicking me out of the internet at random like my old router. And was not having slow internet speed, just amazing.Then the beginning of the second month and I'm having trouble with my internet speed, mainly my upload speed and having packet loss issues.I contacted my ISP to see if they had an issue but they went step by step with me and I hardware my laptop to the modem and I was getting the internet speed i should have. They recommended me to contact the providers for the Archer A7 so I did with the app. Right now they're not taking calls but they have a live chat.So I was texting with the robot they have and it was no help at all, telling to do things I already did, rebooted the router, unplug the router, check for loose wires etc. I wanted to talk to an agent so I was on a waiting list which is understandable. As soon as I texting with the agent, I explained everything I've done and what's the issues I've been having and all she said was, "the router only supports download and internet speed not upload". I thought the internet speed was the download and upload speed itself. I searched up on multiple places even explained the upload speed issues to my ISP which he didn't tell me routers only support download speed.I've tried explaining to the lady again but it was looking like she didn't know what she was talking about and just giving me a run around. She even said try plugging another router to see if you are having the same issue! I don't have multiple routers only the one that was provided by my ISP which the upload speed works perfectly fine it's was just kicking out of the internet at random. So I was pretty frustrated Because the lady was no help and I still have low upload speed and major packet loss mainly around 3pm-8pm my time. At first I would've recommended this product to my family and friends but now it's a different story. Wish someone could help me.
title: Low upload speed and packet loss

author: MaddMax
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2020
review_content: A solid general use router for many small homes or apartments. If you’re a power user, look for something slightly better.When I purchased this router, I was looking for the best bang for my buck. And this fit the bill! It performs well, provides high-speed throughput, and serves as well as a good general use router.What’s missing is MIMO. My previous router that died cost twice as much and had MIMO as well as a few other features. And it is specifically am I am oh that made it a great router.What’s missing is MIMO. My previous router that died cost twice as much and had MIMO as well as a few other features. And it is specifically MIMO that made it a great router For a power user. It was only after having this router in service for a couple of months that I realized how important that missing feature truly is. Hence I can only give this router four stars. But please know, it is a solid generally use router for the casual user. If you were watching movies on two TVs simultaneously, For a power user. It was only after having this router in service for a couple of months that I realized how important that missing feature truly is. Hence I can only give this router four stars. But please know, it is a solid generally use router for the casual user. If you were watching movies on two TVs simultaneously, Getting your cable over the Internet, answering emails and surfing the web this router is fine. But if you want instant access to the Internet every time you open something that’s been sitting for a few moments, and upgraded router with MIMO will better serve your needs.
title: A solid general use router

author: Doc1
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2020
review_content: We used this model in our house for 3-4 years on Cox service between 100-350mbit down and 30mbit up. It served us well. Then we moved to another house and we were really stretching coverage of the unit. Then we dumped Cox and went with a local fiber company 1gbit / 100mbit service which required a firewall / router with more I/O. We went to an AX3000. But this model still sits in my mom's house in rural America on her ancient aDSL service. Boom proof for that!
title: Excellent for small homes / < 300mbit

author: Fred Berfel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2020
review_content: Purchased to use as wired access point.  Was disappointed to find out that the manual, which I read fully before purchasing, was misleading with respect to what features were disabled in AP-mode.  First, I use Mac filtering as one component of defense.  Manual failed to mention this is disabled in Ap mode.  In fact the entire set of advanced security features in the router is disabled because they just don’t display that entire tab when in ap-mode.  Would have been nice to know.  Second, you can’t specify a channel for 2.4 ghz band in ap-mode unless you also disable the ability to do band switching on the router (using a single said for both bands).  Also, and this one baffles me most, tp-link wants you to input all MAC addresses with hyphens instead of colons.  Not a big one, but I have never seen a MAC formatted that way.  Of course they don’t document it...took me a bit to figure it since they just kept saying “invalid format”.  Oh, and names are not allowed spaces.  Given we are in 2020, that is just lazy.The good? For $60 this seems to have good power even thru 2 wood studded walls.  But it would not punch thru even 1 ciderblock wall at all.  Speed is acceptable for a very inexpensive device.  I have not checked 2.4 distance, but I was getting a strong signal from 5ghz after 2 walls about 25 feet away, which is what I wanted,,,to extend my Wi-Fi into the shop and garage which are outside the cinderblock house and not reachable by the router within.  All in all, a usable cheap router for occasional used in shop.  Not happy about Mac filter, but what you gonna do?
title: Minimally configurable as access point

author: Michael Joseph
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2019
review_content: Have a D100/U100 connection with Verizon, had previously been getting between 60-80 up/down with my 5ghz connection.  I live in a 40 story building with 40+ competing wifi signals overlapping through my unit, so connection was spotty despite a relatively small amount of space covered.  This router bumped by 5hz from 3 -> 4 bars, and from 60-80 -> solide 101 up, 110 down.  Did not expect such a big improvement, but maybe that third antenna actually does something.The TPLink web interface + phone app are also solid - very simple, easy to use.  They also improved the firmware updating process - previously you had to download the firmware file, then upload it to your browser.  Now its just 'search for uploads' then 'install upload.  Fantastic!  Hard to imagine you can beat this at the ~$50 price point.  Next upgrade will be in a year or two when WiFi6 is more accessable.
title: Solid Router for Busy Apartment

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_content: First, just let me say that I don’t do reviews but this one was worth the praise. I bought this to replace an old cable router that I kept having to restart. Right out of the box it’s an easy quick setup with the Tether App. It worked great right from the start except I do recommend if you have a lot of different devices that will be running off of this router and you don’t usually have the fastest speeds, that you stagger your devices between 2.4 and 5ghz. The default settings for this device is for it to run as a smart router which means it will switch back and forth from one ghz to the other for whichever is the fastest. That’s fine if you have a significant speed to keep up all of your devices easily but my internet isn’t like that. Mine fluctuates too much for that to be reliable so I turned off the Smart choice in the settings and chose to separate with a different WiFi name. I try to keep the same amount of devices that I run regularly on each ghz in each room. For example if I have my PS4 running on 2.4ghz then I’m going to have my Firestick in that room on 5ghz. I have less buffering that way. The best thing that I can say about it, is it really does work just as well in the basement as it does upstairs and easily covers a 2000 sq ft house without any dead spots. I was using an extender with my last router but I don’t have to with this one.
title: Extremely long range

author: Kaushik Ghose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2020
review_content: In general the router is fine. My only point of comparison is the Verizon G-1100 router, which it replaced.The router was extremely straightforward to set up and the user interface is fabulous. My only complaint is that there was a bug - I switched off both Wifi antennas and could not switch them back on using the switch on the back of the router. I needed to reset the router.After climbing three stories the signal from this router is still decent, and looks to be the same strength as the Verizon G-1100.Importantly, the router has a "smart connect" option. Activating this "merges" the two radio identities, allowing a device to pick the faster band automatically.Overall, this $65 router replaced a $300 router and works just as well. Two thumbs up.
title: Replaced a $300 router (G-1100) and works just the same

author: AC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: I purchased this specifically for my system in the upper-corner of the house, to compliment the main router in the basement and the first-floor router in the family room. The main draws of it were its reasonable range, decent price, and gigabit Ethernet jacks in the back, which allows me high-speed access to the NAS. I have been using it for almost two months now and am quite satisfied with its performance. I run mostly Ethernet up there; the WiFi is only for the smartphone and the tablets, which I rarely use while at home. So I can speak to the performance of the router's hardline connections more than its wireless ones.I am an IT professional and work in system administration, among other domains, so setup for me was easy. The Archer offers more than sufficient customization options for a standard household, I found, but the basic guided setup option also seemed to me to be easy enough to follow. I don't think I'd recommend it as the primary router of a household of more than, say, three people or more than two floors, especially if data use is high, but it works as a secondary unit. I ended up setting it up with its own subnet, rather than making it a mere extender of the primary. I can send documents to the downstairs printer (all printers run via Ethernet to the primary router), but all traffic in that part of the house is kept local, which is fine for my purposes.Would recommend.
title: Great for a small apartment or upstairs WiFi router

author: sunsean
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
review_content: I'd been using a cheaper ($25) router for the past year and a half. Worked well for about a year then starting going in and out. It was intermittent at first so I dealt with it - but last couple months it has been getting worse and worse. Sometimes it would say I was connected to wifi but the internet connection would drop (while wired devices worked fine) and other times it would just lose the wifi connection until I reset the router. Also none of the lights on the front were lighting, making it very hard to diagnose issues or status.Anyway - this isn't to review the other router but just to say that when I plugged in this new router I was instantly blown away by the improvements. Not only did my connections all improve dramatically (after several hours' use have not lost connection once) but it also bumped my speeds by a good 50mbps. Before I was getting about 70 (on a good day/connection) now I'm getting around 120...all with the same internet service.The coverage also seems superior - easily stretches to all corners of my 1BR. Another improvement is that this has 4 ethernet ports, where my last router had only one. Now I can hardwire both my ps4 and HDTV for better performance. Also has a companion app that made setup a breeze, as well as a healthy array of status lights on the front.All in all very happy so far. Just hope it works longer than the last one!
title: Big improvement over previous router

author: JT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
review_content: The problem I was having with my Spectrum internet... my security system has 3 cameras (door bell, above garage and back patio) plus add in TV, 2 phones, Alexa, laptop, tablet. The cameras were not pulling up most of the time creating the need to close and reopen. Very frustrating.I paired this router up with my Spectrum router and split up the connections seperating out the security system+TV from the phones, laptop and tablet. Not once have I come across an attempt to access the cameras that failed since the addition of this router.It's super easy to hook up with a fair price IMO. If your Internet/ wifi isn't functioning properly day in and day out, then this router is definitely for you.
title: Solving a major problem- and it works!!!

author: James C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2020
review_content: This TP-Link router is turning out to be a good buy.  After reviewing my cable bill over the last several months, I noticed that my cable company started charging me monthly fees for both the router ($12) and modem ($10).  After consulting with Optimum, my cable provider, regarding compatability, they reluctantly walked me throught the procedure to convert my rented equipment to my own equipment.  This TP Link router came highly reccomended here on Amazon and it is thus far working very well.  This router broadcasts seamlessly on 2.4 or 5ghz for increased reliability.  Since I keep my router in my attic, I had to swap out old for new and configure my WiFi again, but this was a relatively simple for anyone tech saavy but could pose a problem for others; that said I am far from a computer guy but was able to do this hookup in short order.  The other issue was relinking any devices to the new WiFi; again a simple process but depending on the extent of your WiFi devices, it could be time consuming.  Since I had a family's worth of cell phones, a Ring Alarm system, Nest thermostats, a few Echos, a Playstation and two smart TVs, (I'm sure there are others), it took a bit, but overall this was worth it due having a more modern router and mostly for saving the $12 monthly rental fee which will have this router paying for itself in about 5 months.  Good luck.
title: Review after two months: No more rental fee!  Simple installation and a reliable signal.

author: Adam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: It’s a very good router once you get it working. I had to send my first one back because it wouldn’t work. But when I got my new one; I had the same problem. The problem was that the router wouldn’t read the internet signal coming through the modem. Prior to hooking the router up my old router was working just fine, and the modem showed internet. So I know I had internet but this router was receiving it for some reason. So I figured it was a settings problem within the router. I have my internet and modem thru Charter. So if you have those you may experience what I had too. I called TPlink support and had to wait a long time. After a while I ended up just using the chat feature in support. Which I had to wait quite some time as well. While waiting for the chat to come on I searched online for solutions and found two. So I gave up my 15 minute wait and just tried to figure it out myself. Thats why I gave their customer support a low rank because it took way to long to get an employee. The first was to change the DNS, which worked for a day. So then the next day I changed the LAN IP address and so far that has been working. Its been 2 days so far. If it goes out again I am sending it back and washing my hands of it! Hope this helps anyone with these issues.On a positive note I love the paired Tether app that you use as an interface. It works great and is quite intuitive.
title: It works great when it works.

author: Sammy the Bull
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2019
review_content: UPDATE after 2 weeks use:My initial review was glowing because this thing works great when it works. And the 2.4 Ghz band works great. But the 5GHz connection just won't stay. I'm finding myself rebooting all the time and it just has problems. When it works it's great, bet i'm finding myself now having to reboot every day. Not worth.I get 100 Mb down, 10 up from my ISP. My old router (a lower end TP-Link ) got maybe 25 MB down, 5 up right by the router. Now, I get 100 Mb down and 10 Up from the upstairs bedroom (router is in basement).This thing is solid for a mid-grade router. I'm glad I went with this and didn't waster $200 to get some super fancy high end one. This thing also has guest network, network drive, parental controls - basically all the high end features that the average consumer needs.If you want a SOLID router for $50, this is it.Now my remote play works better on my PS Vita too. :D
title: (update, 5GHz problematic) ethernet connection speed, but over wifi through a floor

author: NorCal925
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018
review_content: Great router for the price! A little bigger than expected.Almost no lag with many consoles running simultaneously***Edited***Bought two of these, one is working fine, while the other one died (recently purchased)The problem started after i turned it off by unplugging from a power surge, after that it started to work for a day until i unplugged it again and this time it stopped connecting to the internet.I talked to customer service (which is joke btw) They asked me to spend my money and time to send their defective item back and i have to wait approx 9 days AFTER THEY RECEIVE MY ITEM- thats cost prohibitive!!! Standard Shipping alone would cost me about $10, and if i express it to them it would be $25 while they will just 1 week standard ship back to me and i would not have the internet for a couple days. The unit itself costed me $50. Why not spend another $15 and get a new one?I dont know how TPlink got an award for customer support
title: Bought 2 of these one DIED in 3 months!!!

author: Elena
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2020
review_content: Overall a solid wifi router with a lot of options. A few small issues which are mostly just things I want to work a certain way.  Worth the price.Pros: A lot of good features and options, not hard to find or figure out how to use. Signal works well.  Options for separate SSID and a guest network to have in, or keep separate from your network as well as not allowing guests to see each other. QoS, profiles, and parental controls for devices is nice and works well.  Several other options I haven't even used or needed yet also available. Overall a solid performance for a wifi router and it's come a long ways from the original ones which just did signal and security.Cons: To be fair most of this is going to be a bit of nit-picking on my part.I wanted more than 8 devices per profile, and I wanted more than 4 profiles (we have a lot of devices). I wanted more options in QoS, so that after work hours we could swap it out. Maybe connecting QoS with profiles and parental controls.
title: Good, just shy on features

author: clamarama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review_content: I bought this to replace a Netgear N600 that I'd had for years. It was still working, but had inadequate range for my 900sf apartment. Then I upgraded my internet speed to 100Mbps from 75 (Comcast), and somehow my connection ended up much slower - I'd been getting around 50 when I was paying for 75 and it went down to 20 when I was paying for 100. Comcast said the speed to the modem was good, but speed to the router was bad, so I got this one to see if it would improve things. I now consistently get the speed advertised for my service - and get it in all corners of my apartment. I didn't have any trouble with the installation and like that the bands use a single SSID.
title: Great upgrade

author: mm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           DO NOT BUY IF YOU WANT TO TRUELY TURN OFF THE WI-FI. When u turn off the WiFi from the on/off button or when u disable it from ur computer it just hides the network so ur wireless devices don’t see it. The WiFi signal is still being broadcast at full power throughout ur house 24/7 from the router!The only reason I bought this was to be able to turn of the WiFi signal as I just use the wired connections and want to have the option to turn on WiFi if needed for visiting guests.If you are sensitive to Electro Magnetic Frequencies  (WiFi) emitted by these devices don’t buy it. The only way to turn off the WiFi is to unplug it. If u unplug it the wired connections will not function.I read responses from the manufacturer of people asking questions if the WiFi can be turned off. They said it can be turned of with the on off WiFi switch or from your computer or the app. That is a complete lie. I tried all 3 and it still emits the WiFi signal.Will have to return this. I never write reviews but I have to warn the people who are sensitive to EMF’s and think the WiFi is can be turned off.
title: WiFi SIGNAL CANNOT BE TURNED OFF!

author: Steve Hanson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2019
review_content: This was fairly easy to install (my home network is a little more complex than most so I ended up skipping all the "easy" installation options and did just about everything manually). So far this is working very well in my smallish house with good coverage on both bands.  The  throughput seems zippy and I appreciate the gig ethernet on all of the ports. I have attached a 1 TB USB drive to the port and that seems to work as expected providing both SMB connectivity and ftp. I am considering installing dd-wrt firmware for the extra functionality, but at the moment it's doing just about all I really need and is being well-behaved.
title: So far I am impressed

author: anteres
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
review_content: Everything was working fine when I bought it. A few months later the internet light would turn orange and I would loose connection. It would come back on again after a while For the past couple of weeks however, the orange light has been on steadily. The camera that I have connected to the router via the ethernet cable has not been working.. I thought it was a ISP issue. I upgrade my service and bought a new modem and the internet light is still set on orange.  I tried to get help but after waiting and waiting and waiting for help via chat, the person didn't seem motivated to help me and left the conversation halfway when I was still not able to get it to work. This is now a piece of junk to me. Don't buy it.
title: Stopped working after year and support is useless

author: AJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2019
review_content: I looked at the reviews and they were saying this was one of the top routers at the time. I will tell you this is not as my old TRENDnet router. I actually bought this for a friend and it would not work for him. So I took it and gave him my TRENDnet AC1900. Boy I have been shooting myself for that one. This one does not have the range. I have internet TV and it is constantly cycling. I am ready to go buy my old router even though it is considered old now. I do like the fact it still gave me the two speeds and a guest network.  I guess it would be okay if you are just doing computing stuff.
title: Not as expected

author: Online since 1995
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2020
review_content: I replaced my older N300 Netgear router with this TP-Link and am blown away by two things:(1) wireless speed(2) featuresSPEED:I ran a speediest from my desktop computer (new Mac mini) using wired ethernet (135Mbps downstream/18Mbps upstream). Then I ran the test from a MacBook Air using wireless ethernet (121Mbps downstream/20Mbps upstream). The results vary slightly if the test is run multiple times, but overall the takeaway though is that this router's wireless performance is unbelievably fast. [Network Setup: Zyxel C3000Z DSL modem -> TP-Link Archer 7 router, and then wired and wireless connections from there.]FEATURES:(1) It supports both 2.4GHz and 5GHz wireless connections but has a nice feature (unlike the Zyxel modem) that lets you pick a single SSID (wireless network) and it automatically balances your connection between the two bandwidths. (The Zyxel makes you pick one bandwidth or the other).(2) And it has a built-in VPN server.(3) And you can connect an external hard drive, memory stick or other USB storage device to use as a network drive.(4) And of course lots of security features, integration with Amazon Alexa (if you're so inclined).
title: Amazingly Good!

author: philz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2020
review_content: This is my second TP-Link Router/Wifi box.  The first one I actually got at a brick and mortar store when helping my parents move into another house, and I have always been a fan of Linksys routers, and I had this notion in my mind that Netgear was pretty good stuff too.  However, I had an open mind, and I pulled out my phone and started reading reviews.  Overall, I was seeing a general trend where TP-Link products are making very satisfied customers, and the others, not so much.So I got that one and really loved it.  So this here is my second TP-Link product, and I have to say, I am impressed!  For the longest time, I thought "what the heck is tp-link?  what a weird brand name."  Turns out these guys are like the prize winning underdog in the game.  Great product, great build quality, and great firmware.I think this one might be able to do DD-WRT, not really sure.  That actually was one of my selection criteria when getting this second router.  I've read mixed reports, some people have managed to make it work.  I am still on stock firmware, and so far, I'm just fine with it.  But it's nice to know I could install DD-WRT at some later point if I need some advanced routing features.
title: Very impressed with the TP-Link brand, lesser known company but superior products.

author: Justin C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
review_content: 1. WiFi signal is weaker than my EoL Asus RT-N66U.2. Wired AND WiFi service and connectivity is UNRELIABLE - having to reboot the router frequently to keep devices connected and performant.3. Updates are infrequent4. Finally updated the firmware via the online update and cannot log into the router: Going to https://192.168.1.1 and get "No Such File or Directory" - can't log in.It's all but bricked.  This is what I get for buying a CHEAP router.Thank you, TP LINK.
title: UNRELIABLE ROUTER w/ POOR PERFORMANCE. Wish I could return

author: AUTISTIC WEREWOLF
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2020
review_content: Buy this garbage and soon as you try to set things up its asking you to download some smart phone app it needs to run from your phone. When the first thing a device wants to do is collect your personally identifiable information to populate a phone application I see RED! What's more a router that has a phone application interface is a security hole another point of access for potential hackers.Today we have ranges, refrigerators, cars and darn near anything else that wants a place on the smart phone they just know you have. What I hate is this router just assumes you have a smart phone and assumes you must want to control the router through your phone. The arrogant way the smart phone connection option is presented make it appear that you can not use the router without first linking it to your smart phone. I was in the market for a router not a smart phone application.Leave this garbage on the shelf because, it hides its true agenda of wanting another hook into your smartphone. I just don't like the big brother implications of having every aspect of one's life pulsing through some insecure phone application. If a refrigerator, a range, a dish washer or a router needs an app on my smart phone to work then its junk I don't need to buy.
title: ANOTHER DEVICE THAT WANTS TO LOAD APPS INTO THE SMART PHONE THEY KNOW YOU HAVE!

author: Matt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2020
review_content: I got this router about 3 weeks ago. It was working well until a few days ago until I saw a huge drop in connection speeds. The internet speed is like it was before if I use the modem only with cable, but anything that uses wifi including using airplay to watch videos on my tv has become impossible. I have tried restarting the device but now it turns back on it may take up to an hour to connect to the internet.This is just very frustrating. I really wanted to enjoy this router and it was fine when it was working. Although even then the range is nothing like advertised but it was fine for my apartment. I’m not sure if I can still return this to Amazon. I don’t want to wait and see the product die completely.
title: Beware it might malfunction soon

author: Molly Famous
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020
review_content: It claims it can handle up to 50 devices. I have a Smart home. If I connect more than 15 devices (far less than half of what it claims it can handle!) It kicks EVERYTHING off and won't let ANYTHING reconnect until I reset the router. Do you have any idea what a pain it is to have reset the router and reconnect 18 devices LITERALLY every other freaking day? This thing is garbage, and was sold to me under false pretenses!
title: 50 devices? More like 15, IF you're lucky!

author: Chad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2019
review_content: I'm so happy i found this router!! I love the 3 external antennas and the awesome android app!!.. i bought it to replace an old old Netgear router that would randomly shut off for no reason and a pathetic lil white cube thing the internet company called a router LOL!!.. pathetic range and slow... I was always tired of trying to stream live tv and movies.. only to find i gotta go reboot the old junkie routers.. and kept switching between the two.. and they were both only single band 2.4 ghz..I literally set up this new router in less than 10 minutes... plugged it all in... had the "tether" app on my phone already, set it up.. boom way further range and faster, and steady connection... i love it!!!
title: Big upgrade from old Junky 2.4ghz routers!

author: James
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
review_content: I bought this to replace a netgear nighthawk AC 1750 R6700 that kept dropping connwctions and the 55g radio kept turning off, or at least disappearing in my WiFi networks.I bought this router, had some issues with the setup not being very straight forward . I didn't really want to create a tplink account where it said thy could basically use as much if my information as permitted by law... That sounded vague and sketchy like they might raffle off my browsing history to marketing companies, so I did a factory reboot, and at one screen it was impossible on my old laptop's screen to click a button without going into chrome developer tools and removing a transparent footer overlay on top of the save or next button first (couldn't scroll past it either).That issue knocks down 1 star on UI. The other star got knocked down by only let you select hours to turn wifi off to full hour increments. I feel it should allow moregranular control like half hour or quarter hour increments, so I took one more star off for that.The router has been working like a champ for me. The speed has been great, even while streaming videos while working. I haven't even noticed when my kids are looking up items for school while I'm working. If I have issues later with this router I'll update later.
title: UI could use ux work, router is fast and dependable

author: bradw2k
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2020
review_content: This was great while it lasted, but after 4 months it is now causing us to have to unplug and restart multiple times a day. Strangely, one device will be connected to the internet via wifi fine, but then another device will connect to the wifi and have no internet connection.  So I know it is not our service that is being spotty, and it is not the wifi connection itself, but the router which is randomly failing to connect devices through to the internet.  Even another router that is daisy chained via patch cable to this one.  This has been happening over and over for several days.  Wife restarted this router 5 times today.  Have to replace.  Good luck!
title: Last 4 months

author: Clint Gilbert
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
review_content: This singe router replaced 2 Apple Airport Extremes and 2 Expresses, all extended via ethernet.improved our connectivity in the house (1200 sq ft), attached garage and back yard too. Simple to setup and administer. I used the web interface. I will install theapp it some point as a system monitor but so far everything is solid. we stream both music and videos and have 5 connected devices and 1 connected TV. Was considering one of the newer netgear or google systems that run 200-400 bucks and so glad i tried this first
title: changed our streaming  life at home and saved us a ton of money

author: Wyton1
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2020
review_content: After all the positive reviews on YouTube, Amazon and trusted sites on the net I decided to go with the TP-Link 1750. My only concern was the large number of recent reviews on Amazon saying their routers were DOA or failed within weeks. I should have listened to the negative reviews. My router arrived fast. I checked carefully to be sure it was new and not repackaged. Set it up and performance was dismal. Average internet speed tests were 2 to 10 MPS, dropping to less than 1 MBPS after an hour of playing with quick fixes on the net like changing NAT boost settings, etc. My ISP provides 200 MBPS, verified by bypassing my router and connecting my PC directly to my modem. When I went through my seven year old router my speed dropped to 90 MBPS, slower but still much faster than the new router. After a few hours I decided I wasted enough time playing with this new item that should have worked right out of the box. Never could get ahold of TP-Link support, another red flag for me. I now have serious concerns about the quality of TP-Link products. I'll go with another brand name for my next router.
title: I really wanted this to work

author: Guvnarrr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2018
review_content: If you are like me you are thinking this is supported by OpenWRT bc the model number (AC1750) is reused from Archer C7 to Archer A7 (this product).Archer C7 is fully supported by OpenWRT.Archer A7 is not yet.However, with some elbow grease, and creating a linux VM to build the firmware on, I did get OpenWRT installed on this Archer A7 and put some very detailed instructions on how to do it on a GitHub pull request (1462).
