I think you would need to search for that so that this review isn't deleted.Very happy with the product now that I have OpenWRT installed.
title: Not *fully* supported by OpenWrt yet(?)

author: MCOsteve
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
review_content: I have 300 Mbps internet and was only getting around 40 Mbps on my home Wifi. I had an older Apple air I was using and my internet provider told me to get a new 5 Ghz router that was 802.11ac and at least AC1600. Did I have any idea what that was? Absolutely not.I went to Amazon and saw this router had what I needed and was only around $70 so took a chance. Wow, what a huge difference is and made! I am now getting around 240 Mbps on my Wifi with 6 devices using the router. The router is also in an office and I am not using any extensions. It was a little hard to for me to install but if you just take 5 minutes to read the instructions you can do it. Make sure you turn off everything before installing it, that was my main mistake. Also you must install the app to set up the network which took a while to figure out but still had it up and running in about 20 minutes. Couldn't be happier with this router.
title: Really sped up my WiFi

author: IslandWitt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
review_content: I am one of the least "techno savy" people on the planet, but when our wifi router died (after many years of great service) I needed to get a replacement.  Did a bit of research : price & reviews, this router hit all the marks.  When it arrived I was worried I would be able to get it to 'talk' to all our devices, but my worries were unfounded.  It truly was a plug and play unit.  I followed the simple instructions that came with it and in no time the house was up and running again, family happy.  I didn't rate the Tech Support since I neither needed or used it.  We are an old small family of two, we're happy.  Someone else may need bigger, better, smarter, faster ..... but we are very satisfied with installation & capability.
title: Old Fart does the Plug & Play

author: Kristopher Nason
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018
review_content: I have a desktop ONE room away; and every week without fail this router requires a complete reset. This began roughly 4 weeks back; after of course I could return it, go figure. If you need a very basic router one where you don't mind losing internet every week and have to reset it go ahead.Edit: KEEPS LOSING INTERNET.......AT LEAST TWICE A WEEK. Garbage product.
title: Not good enough.

author: Jenny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2020
review_content: So I have just moved into a brand new apartment and I was really hoping that the wifi would be outstanding since my previous wifi was horrible. I couldn't stop dreaming about having fast wifi. Then I moved in, and it was so bad. I did a speed test the other day and it was 9mbps, which is pretty abysmal. We were using an 5 year old modem/router combo and I figured that might be the culprit so I looked into getting a new separate modem and router. And I am so glad that I did. I bought this router and a Netgear CM500 modem to give it a try and see if it would improve our wifi, and it totally did. Once everything was activated and connected, the service was incredibly fast. I just did a speed test and it just read as 116mbps. If your wifi is crappy and you know it should be higher, highly recommend this router and that modem if your current ones are older.
title: All I can say is WOW!

author: Dave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2020
review_content: So I'm using this router "Archer A7 v5.8" as a wireless switch for a desktop and server that are in another room, that require RJ-45 connection.  It's connecting to a router about 30~ft away, downstairs, has a line of sight almost, but there is a door/wall in the way, where the main router is kept.  In order to do this, I have to setup a WDS.  It's fairly easy to do, but the web interface is quite slow, which seems to be the trend for routers.  I also dislike how I had to connect to it.  Why didn't it just tell me the ip, so I could connect to it, like every other router I've had? ...  (I used the ip after setting it up, but originally I didn't know what the ip was for this router and it took trail and error) ...I would use the 5ghz WDS mode, but it keeps crashing anytime I use it for downloading or transferring files.  If it is a quick webpage load of a video stream it does alright.  If I'm downloading a game on my desktop, it will crash the router.  If I transfer files from my laptop to my server, it will crash the router. (laptop on the 5ghz wifi, of this A7 router)  It seems to restart itself, but it doesn't.  So I have to manually restart it, which takes about 2 painful minutes for whatever reason.I've tried to update the firmware, which was confusing on what version I was changing it to.  For a little bit I thought I had some super new firmware that wasn't listed on their website, but it turns out there was newer firmware.  But that didn't fix anything.  For now I am setting on the slower 2.4Ghz WDS.  I'm only connecting to my main router for internet, which is about 128Mb Down, at it's peak.  Which 2.4Ghz is good enough for, but it does seem like it needs to build up to speed, compared to the 5Ghz WDS.On this A7 router, I have transferred files from a laptop with 5Ghz, to a server with RJ-45 Gigabit at over 400Mb.  Although, to do this I had to put the laptop right next to it.  If I had it about a foot away, right below it, I got about 350Mb.  (MB = MegaByte Mb = Megabit same for GB-Gb, KB-Kb)I'm overall disappointed with the 5Ghz WDS crashing the router and the web interface speed/setup.Edit:  I decided to fiddle with it again after initially writing this review.  I thought the internet was just going slow because of the "internet shortage" I was hearing about.  I think it's just how slow this router is.  Doing a speed test, the 2.4Ghz WDS gets about 55 down, 22up.  However there have been times where I'm getting 32 Down.  But if I use my laptop and connect to the main router, I get the full 128 Down and 100~ Up speeds.  I was trying to get the 5Ghz WDS to work again and couldn't see my main router at all!  It didn't even see the 5Ghz repeater we have.  I kept finding other devices though.  I'm wondering if I got a dud or maybe it's just a bad product.
title: 5Ghz WDS keeps crashing router & Slow!

author: CoolBoomer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
review_content: I have had a few other TP-Link products (USB Lan adapters and smart switches) that worked great and gave this a try when a 2-yr old big name big-money router failed. This thing was very easy to set up following the instructions and the phone app. I love the phone app, it's easy to use and uncluttered. You can also easily manage this router from your PC browser.Like all good modern wifi routers, it has two available bands and networks on 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz, with the ability to have separate passwords and network SSID's. You can manage the connection to any of the clients on your network (as in kick your kids offline or set timers or web site blocks) so you get all kinds of perks for the money that work with the free app.I have had it in service a month or so and love it. No problems at all. It was half the price of the last name brand one I set up for friends that looks just like it.
title: Saved a Bundle of Money and Got a Great Router

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2020
review_content: For the longest time, I had been trying to figure out why my wireless speeds were terrible, and then I realized it was because I was using an ancient router. I have the spectrum plan and know that my internet speed is capable of about 300 Mbps so I was hoping to take advantage of that but knew that routers tend to deliver a little less since its through wifi (walls, interference, etc.) This router is exceptional though! Installation was pretty easy using the Tether App and after walking around my entire home, I was able to get internet speeds on my wireless devices up to 125 Mbps! All while watching Netflix on one TV and using multiple smartphones and tablets. It really does deliver the speed at the strength that you need. Its especially great that you can prioritize wifi connections through the app. I've been using mine to boost our TV connection during family movie nights so the dreaded buffer doesn't show up!Setting up the USB 3.0 drive has been a little tricky and I haven't fully gotten it going yet but I'm still playing around with it. The user interface starts getting a little confusing the more you go into it so that's been a challenge.Overall: Its a great product and I highly recommend it for anyone looking to upgrade their current router!
title: Exactly what I needed!

author: Lotus1922
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2020
review_content: I finally replaced our Spectrum rental router after they "upgraded" us to a new one, and wow I wish I had done this sooner. This router is AMAZING! Had it plugged in and set up within minutes of opening the box. There is an optional phone app for managing basic settings, but the real fun is the http login user interface. This interface has a "basic" mode for getting going in short order, and there is an "advanced" mode for those who want to really have fun tweaking the nitty gritty details. The wifi reaches our whole house and has even eliminated the dead spot on the far side that made watching TV there impossible. With this baby we can now stream via wifi on all three TV's plus phones and computers simultaneously with zero hiccups. This might be a budget router but it would be a bargain at twice the price. Highly recommended!
title: Get the speed you pay for!

author: Lrxst
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: Update 12/13/2020I have updated the firmware each time a new version has come out. This router continues to have some bad days where it just cannot stay connected to my Charter Spectrum modem for more than a couple hours at a time. It’s not the modem, as my old router still works fine with it, and fixing the connection involves rebooting the TP-Link router only. I’m cutting my losses and buying a Ubiquity Edge wired router, and demoting this thing to be an access point only. It's just not reliable, but I'm hoping it works well as an access point, as that part of it has never failed.Update 9/21/2020Just FYI - I am on the current firmware, that was the first thing I did after connecting to the router admin. The problem described below has subsided. I don't know if it just needed time to work itself out with the Spectrum modem, of if something I actively did fixed it. I did two things. I set the router to reboot itself nightly. It also seemed like my 2nd gen Apple TV may have been causing problems for the router. When I changed my DHCP address pool right after setting up the router, the Apple TV was insisting on keeping its old IP address, which was now outside of the DHCP pool I wanted to use. I unplugged the Apple TV, since it's old and I don't really use it. That also coincided with the router's problem going away. My router has the same SSID as my old one, with the same WPA2 password. All my other devices worked seamlessly with the new router, except the Apple TV. If I connect the Apple TV back up, I will try having it forget it's network settings and start from scratch. As of now, no problems, and the Archer has gotten a reprieve.I really wanted to like this router. The features are what I wanted, speeds are fast, and wifi coverage is excellent. It's just too flaky. The main problem is that it disconnects from my cable modem randomly, at least twice per day. When this happens, the WAN light on the router goes from green to amber. Sometimes it will be in the process of failing for several minutes before it goes to amber. The login for the router management interface can also become unresponsive. I have to reboot both the router and the cable modem (Cisco DPC3208 - provided by ISP), even though the cable modem still has a blinking link light to the WAN. I followed the setup routine after logging into the router. There's nothing special about my configuration. My network was very reliable with my old router, (Buffalo Airstation WZR-600DHP). Simply can't accept random drops with online schooling and Zoom meetings. Going to return and try another brand.
title: Will not stay connected to cable modem

author: Brian S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: I purchased this as a replacement for an older router and noticed that while I can transfer files internally between my home theater PC in my living room to my Network Attached Storage in my office at full Gigabit, my internet speed on the LAN was maxing at 200mbps (on a Gigabit internet connection).My internet coming into my modem was fine (tested with my Fluke Networks Handheld Cable Internet tester) I  was getting 1 gigabit directly from the modem to my laptop (using cat 6a) but if I connected my laptop directly to the router (with more CAT 6a cabling), I was getting 200mbps max.  Wirelessly I was maxing at 350mbps.QoS and NAT Boosting were turned off already. It's not the Modem. It's not the ISP (I work for the ISP and install / setup equipment all day long). It's not the LAN cable (all CAT 6a). It's not the Ethernet port on the laptop.Updated the firmware and rebooted, No change in speeds.Talked with Tech support and they were of NO help.  Kept suggesting things I already did (and I humored them and walked through their scripted responses).  When the issue was still happening, they said "well, just return it for a new one" and basically hung up.Yeah, no.After some testing with a multimeter and some internet research on the chips used on the router, it turns out that the router's CPU can't actually do Gigabit between the WAN and LAN port.  It maxes out at 821Mbps WAN to LAN in a perfect setting and in the real world it maxes out even lower than that!I ended up tossing the Archer away and buying an ASUS Nighthawk.I will never purchase another TP Link product.
title: The Description is Misleading!

author: Dustin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2019
review_content: I bought this router under the impression it would function like a true repeater bridge. I could extend my wireless network while maintaining some level of router capabilities with it, not that seamless WDS stuff where MAC addresses are exchanged. I want to maintain independent routing controls of my devices. People were saying yes, it could repeat natively in the reviews and that is simply not the case. I worked with tech support and I could not get it to extend my network as a repeater or bridge. I couldn't even get WDS to function!What ultimately worked was to install a beta build of DD-WRT on the unit, then use Client Bridge mode. Search for "WDS AP on TP Link Archer A7 not working" in DD-WRT forums and you'll find how to set it up. To install DD-WRT, you have to download the latest factory-to-ddwrt.bin and just use the firmware upgrade option on the router's default TP-Link GUI. I'm still working out the bugs, as the bandwidth is poor right now. But it is at least functioning.I would give it another star if there wasn't so much misleading about it's abilities out of the box.
title: Works as a repeater bridge, but not out of the box

author: ghowell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2019
review_content: I bought this WiFi router to replace the Centurylink Router that was leased with my home internet service. I was able to duplicate the settings on the CTL router, and this one came online and provides a great WiFi signal- I have a Ring camera that needs good WiFi, and this seems to fit the bill. Was able to get the $10 modem lease off of my bill. It's important to note- This is just a WiFi router, and does not have a modem built-in. If you have Comcast or CenturyLink DSL, you probably need a separate modem. I wired my house with Ethernet, but needed a WiFi access point for phones, iPads, etc.
title: Great replacement router for CenturyLink Fiber

author: MusicHound
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018
review_content: Not easy to set up. Had to reboot computers, router, and modem one after the other for at least three cycles before it would even work. Plan on over four hours for this process.After a few weeks, the internet connection gradually became erratic. Would constantly get notices "site can't be reached ... connection took too long." Repeating the search seven or eight times would sometimes get through. Tech support not available when I needed it. Wasted many weeks with this product and will buy a replacement.
title: A Disaster

author: shoji
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2019
review_content: I read some negative reviews, so I was worried a little. But almost every product had some kind of negative reviews with some kind of problems. So I just trust my own decision. And I hope that I will not be the customer who had problems...The reason I tried to buy new router is my old router which I bought few years ago seems getting slow signal, because of signal capacity. I just started use this day before, so I don’t know what will happen in future, but at this point, so far so good. The set up was easy by using IPhone app. Signals are faster and steady than my old router from other company. And price was more than half compared to my old router. And new functions for me is that I can choose which signals to use 2.4G or 5G, according to necessarily of small signal or large signal. So it’s much organized and avoid WiFi traffic jams to getting slow signals. My old router had same as 2.4G and 5G, but I cannot choose which signals to connect for each tablet, so sometimes it seems overwhelming and causing slow down by using many computers at same time with other peoples. Also I can choose to block any of tablet which connects to my router by monitoring from my iPhone app. And i can change my password anytime for security reasons. Nice!!
title: So far so good

author: VA1108
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2019
review_content: My old Belkin router worked fine for 9 years but I needed 5 GHz to run Firestick so I bought this one.  I can't say the set up was a breeze.  It took me 2 hours to figure out why the router couldn't be connected to the modem.  TP-Link's tech support was a joke and waste of time.  I considered returning the item but decided to give it a last try.  I finally got to the link where there was detailed instruction how to connect the router to the modem.  First you have to unplug the ethernet modem and connect the router to the modem making sure the router is not turned on.  After connecting, turn on the ethernet modem and wait at least 2 minutes to make sure all the lights are turned on.  Then turn the router power on and wait another 2 minutes or so until the internet light turns from red to green. It's ready then and you can connect from the phone or laptop or whatever.  I gave 3 stars for the difficulty in set up and lack of tech support.  The instruction sheet that came with the router was very confusing for some one like me who doesn't change routers all the time.
title: It works good now after difficult set up

author: Vladdydaddy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: Range:Definitely better than your Verizon/Comcast router but not by a ton. You're gonna need extenders and stuff for an upstairs/downstairs. Still trying out the official TP-Link extenders to see the speed.SPEED/PING:The 2ghz speed is kind of crap from what I've seen, but that's kind of to be expected. I don't really use it so I can't say for sure. Anywhere from 10-50mbps.On the 5ghz after optimizing it, I hit over 400mbps on my phone and laptop even in the room nextdoor, which is pretty good.  On my phone it's supposed to be technically capable of 1.2gbps but it usually shows 940mbps in my internet options. Still, it's not reaching near the amount. I'm not sure if the bottleneck is the router or my phone/laptop, as I've never been on a faster connection than my home network.Wired speed - I hit about 940mbps wired into the router compared to 1004mbps wired into my modem. This is reflective of what the wifi connection is showing under internet options, although this is wireless. Maybe there's something with the cable or my Verizon modem limiting the output speed. I'm using the provided ethernet cable. Still, not bad for something that's extended my network. Ping is great. I haven't done gaming on this router (yet?) but in all my speedtests I'm getting around 6ms ping on wifi and wireless. Should be pretty great for gaming because I haven't had any dips in the speed or connection.OPTIMIZING:You're gonna want to split the wifi channels, as it's set by default. Name one of them MyWifi 5G and the other MyWifi 2G for clarity. There's an automatic switching feature but it's not perfect, as it often bases it on signal instead of speed, so my Fire Stick was using the 2ghz.Use a wifi scanner like Vistumbler to find out what channels other people are using nearby. For me, a lot of people were using channels 149 and 161 (or 167 I forget) for 5ghz. I found that 157 worked best for me. You can do the same for 2.4ghz.Misc/Comments:I guess I hoped for a bigger range on this. It's great because not it works well downstairs, and it will work even better once I get the extenders running. It doesn't work too great outside with our smart plugs so I'm grabbing a cheap second wifi extender. The There are some $10 ones on ebay from Xiaomi that are supposed to be pretty good for 2.4ghz.
title: Pretty Great for the Price, 9/10

author: Mac Guy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2019
review_content: This A7 router replaced an old Apple AirPort Extreme.  Setup was fairly easy except a bit tangled, and having to use your smartphone, I ended up using their website to finish the setup instead. My main gripe with this router is the inconsistent signal, sometime it works great on the first floor other times depending on 1st floor location I get no signal or max speed or a 90% slowdown from the same location. This is not a big house, the A7 is located in an upstairs room against an external wall.  I did not have this problem at all with the Airport.  I’m using the 2.4Ghz band. It is not the modem, my Mac located next to the router is hardwired to the router and displays no slowdown when my iPad is slowing to a crawl at the same time on the 1st floor. After a few minutes the signal is good again and the iPad has no problem with web pages and the Speedtest app reads normal speeds.  I will try moving the router across the room 9’ away toward the interior of the house but will have to get a longer cable. Bottomline: inconsistent signal strength/speed.I use the Speedtest app on both the iPad and iMac.
title: Somewhat flakey on signal strength or speed.

author: Brian. R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2020
review_content: My older Netgear WGR614v6 router became a bottleneck when I upgraded to 200 Mbps Internet service. I bought this TP-Link AC1750 (Archer A7) router and am really pleased! When plugged into the Ethernet port I truly get Internet speeds of 200 Mbps, and when using 5 GHz Wi-Fi, I get around 150 Mbps (even higher, per included screen capture). Setup was easy, though I've a fair bit of experience deploying and managing other (older) routers.For the record, I'm using Spectrum Internet service with a Hitron Docsis 3.1 modem.
title: Dramatically improved my Wi-Fi Speed!

author: J. C. M. Bannerman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2019
review_content: I bought this because my ISP provide me with a terrible wireless router. The thing used to drop me with annoying frequency. I think the router was also throttled at 50Mbps when I have 100Mbps internet.Time for a new router that actually works.I was impressed with how easy this was to set up. I used the tether ap on my iPhone and it was pretty much a snap.All I needed to do was-- Set up the router.-- find it on my list of networks--log in to the routerAnd the network was up and running. It took longer to change the passwords on all my devices than set up the router!I had no need for technical support it was that simple once you figured out what to do.No dropping and all the streaming services are working like a charm. Toss in that using this with Ubuntu 14.04 was absolutely not a problem. In fact, the problem with all the network drops were the fault of the previous router.I'm hoping this thing lasts a good long time, but a few people have made comments about how long theirs lasted. But they are probably unsatisfied customers.I have something that works the way I wanted to to. I am happy as can be.
title: So far so good (and works with Linux)

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2020
review_content: I am surprised that there are any good reviews.  I tested my signal directly from the modem, (Netgear DOCSIS 3.1) and was getting 929.2MPS.  Using wireless you can lose up to 50% of your signal.  With this, about 5 feet from the router, I dropped to 300MPS, I connected my PC via Ethernet and only got 290MPS, about 20 feet away signal dropped to 160MPS.  I tried their tech support and all they did was say to look at help articles, completely useless.  I bought an ASUS GT-5300 and get over 600MPS.  Now it costs 4 times as much, but worth it!  If you want to save money and have a router there delivers really slow service, this is the one for you!
title: Signal drops off quickly

author: Kyle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2019
review_content: After having speed issues, I discovered my old router was shot. This had good reviews for a decent price, so I figured I'd try it.Set-up was super easy. In total, from pulling it out of the box, to having it set-up and everything connected, I spent maybe 30 minutes. There is an app you download that walks you through set-up, and then lets you control/manage the network.I didn't need anything fancy. I have a 1300SF ranch house, and the router is in the middle. This router is more than enough to cover that area (and it covers more than my old one did). As for usage, it's only my wife and I, but we do have all our TV through streaming. It's worked perfectly fine to stream multiple things at one time, and I'm sure it could handle more. While the router isn't the only thing that affects speed, with our 100Mbps internet service, I am getting speeds of about 90Mbps.I've had this a couple weeks now, and it's worked flawlessly. I can't comment on their tech support, since I didn't need them for anything because setup was so simple. If you're looking to replace a router, and you don't need a mesh network, I would highly recommend this one.
title: Replacing my old router

author: ADRStudio
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2020
review_content: I don't know if it's the best but it's pretty amazing !Without going into details, I will say it just that everything advertised is true for a very good price. Very good web interface to setup, a good app for your phone (TP-Link Tether), easy to setup.The great thing is that you can have separated logins for 2G and 5G, for regular use and guests, and you can individually turn them on/off, this is a sweet thing.For all the technical details just read the description here or on their website and enjoy. They have a more detailed manual on their website.Important note :  Intel Wi-Fi cards for laptop requires 160 Mhz band to reach 1300 mbps which AC A7 does NOT have. So, if you Wi-Fi card is Intel on your laptop you will be limited to 866 mbps at 5G even if the Wi-Fi card specification says it can reach more because it requires 160 Mhz band and T-Link Archer A7 does not have. This is a great router, but if you looking for 1300 mbps on 5G I not sure how it is possible.Another important note: On phones probably you get much less than 1300 mbps. In my case, a iPhone 11, I can reach max 550 mbps.Any way it improves the speed. Compared with my old router and my  Wi-Fi router provided by ATT, it was a big difference.The USB port works great for a shared drive, I could never make it work with other routers. If you install the app FE File Explorer on your iPhone you can easily save or transfers pics or any file back and forth to your computer through the shared drive without the hassle of clouds and emails, this app also works like a browser and music player on the shared drive. I particularly hate clouds :) , I prefer to have my private cloud.I ordered and will receive today a TP-Link Wi-Fi extender with OneMesh, actually a luxury for the size of my apartment :) , I will update later if it works fine.
title: I don't know if it's the best but it's pretty amazing !

author: Gabriela
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
review_content: I keep losing connection constantly. Happens at least between 10-15 times a day. I called my ISP thinking it was an issue on their end, they even came out here to fix a few issues we had, but the problem still persists. Now my modem says I’m still connected to the internet WiFi connection keeps losing signal.
title: Boo

author: clfplvw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019
review_content: I've had good luck with TP-Link routers and needed upgrade to handle hi-res cameras as well as install vpn link(s). In process of setting up and experimenting w/vpn and security systems.One thing I don't like is that I apparently have to connect to tp-link to manage the router instead of having direct access as I did in older router.  Not good if you want to run a private network for security cameras  & other controllers without any need to access internet.  Opens up router to unwanted outside access.  To me it seems like "control" like Microsoft & Apple as well as other mnfgrs
title: Ordered for dual band, bandwidth, and vpn support

author: Bondfamily2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020
review_content: I bought this router as a first time FIOS customer in my new apartment. I like the easy installation and accompanying app. The first day, it seemed to work fine. Then I noticed the next day that my computer and apps were moving sluggish. It would take time for the server on any of my devices to respond. Many times, I ended up using my mobile data to browse the internet. I could barley watch shows on my AppleTV without interruption or lower quality. It didn't make sense since FIOS is supposedly fast. My time with Comcast wasn't this bad.I tried installing its update, restarting, elevating its position... Nothing was working. It didn't matter that my TV was sitting directly across from the router or me browsing on my laptop in my bedroom away from it.I ended up spending a bit more on a Netgear router. I installed it last night and haven't had issues so far. I don't know what the problem is with this router. Maybe it doesn't work well specifically in my apartment. I'll have to return it and keep the newer router.
title: Wifi signal not strong

author: Darryl Lewis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2020
review_content: This replaced my old Apple 802.11n Airport Extreme. This router has the 2.4GHz and 5GHz bands, but creates a single Wi-Fi network that combines them transparently using a single Wi-Fi network name. You can choose to operate this device either as a router or as an access point. Of course you can set up a guest Wi-Fi network. There's USB for connecting devices (like drives) to share on your network. Of course it provides IP & MAC binding and port forwarding, supports IPv6, can act act an OpenVPN or PPTP server, and works with inexpensive Wi-Fi MESH extenders that also combine the 2.4GHz and 5GHz Wi-Fi bands into a single network name...and you can move transparently throughout your areas, moving from one extender to another without dropping the connection. It even works with Alexa...although I haven't used that feature. Best of all, it's inexpensive compared to better known router manufacturers, and my experience with TP-Link products is that they've been extremely reliable over many years.
title: Strong signal, easy to set up, works with inexpensive MESH extenders

author: SKFixer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
review_content: Just received this router yesterday and the results have been pretty amazing. I had a router at mu basement and had continuous interruptions and weak signal. Wanted ti fix the problem and got this router and two tp libk repeaters. Needless to say I dont  need the repeaters since the signal was good in my entire 3600 sq ft house. Even still at the basement, the top floors get a good signal which is amazing. There are more advanced settings which I so far did not need to touch so we will see. I also scanned my network with andry ip scanner and it came up as a cisco router which means it has the cisco chip abd teporting through it netbios which means the quality should be excellent (Cisco is one of the leaders in networking).
title: Excellent router for large houses

author: Mid-West
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: Haven’t called Tech support I bought this to flash OpenWRT had it working but likely misconfigured it. Why the low review? Because it’s dirt chip components, plastic and manufacturing. It’s made in Vietnam which I like compared to China. Don’t buy networking products from Amazon from China. I have been looking at various devices and in particular the smart lights that have ESP32’s in them such as the Tula stuff?They all strangely have connections to Skype.I use two firewalls to stop inbound threats and outbound traffic.Outbound stuff is VPN’d usually from device to router router then used a second VPN out. You would be shocked to see what some of these devices seem to connect to.
title: Cheap quality these cost $10-$12 to make + $5 shipping (if that). Don’t buy from China. I

author: andy tate
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020
review_content: The initial setup took 5 minutes. After that I switched from basic to advanced and was able to name the 5G and 2.4 different names and set different passwords.  The VPN Server is easy to set up although it would be better if there was a way to upload an openvpn configuration file since there is a way to download one. On the internet connection side of things if you want to do L2TP you can set user name and password, but if your provider requires an additional pass code, this is unfortunately not available. Also I really wanted to set up an internet connection using openvpn so that router connected to my provide via openvpn, which is different from setting up openvpn on the router which provides you with the ability to allow your users to vpn to you. If openvpn was available as an internet connection type with the ability to upload the openvpn configuration I would have given it 5 stars, but for now, for my requirements I can only give it 3. If you only want to use this for a standard internet router, then this is a great product for you (5 stars for basic use).
title: Easy to Set Up and Connect to but a few things lacking or missing

author: GentleSol
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
review_content: This product is a scam. I thought maybe my internet service provider might be part of the blame(which they are) but I’ve gone through steps to confirm this router is a piece of junk. Since I’ve bought this router WiFi has disconnected several times. The load times have increased dramatically. Never in 3+ years have I ever experienced lag trying to watch Netflix or YouTube until I switched to this router. I’ve switched back to the terrible router that spectrum provides upon service because this one was so bad. Initially I switched for a better hard wired in connection speed but it has failed to prove worthy. I’ve tried different settings from within the tether app to make this connection better but no luck. I pay for 450 MBPS and spectrums router provides about 200 MBPS WiFi speed with their basic router. This archer fails to provide not even 1 MBPS.Basically, I three my money away on this router and I’m throwing away the money I’m paying for my 450 MBPS internet speed monthly because I’m not even getting 1.
title: Scam. DO NOT BUY. YOUVE BEEN WARNED

author: S. McGrath
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2020
review_content: Talk about next level game changer. I have been converting my house into a smart home. I was having issues with certain devices staying connected. Had 29 devices on my Netgear router. So, I decided to try something new. Most of my Smart Switches are TP-Link. So I figured this was the way to go. Not only did this fix my problem, I'm getting almost triple internet speeds compared to the other router. I'm actually getting significantly faster speeds than I pay for. I'm highly impressed. Also, my microwave used to cut the internet out of the kitchen every time I use it. My Echo Show 8 would dud out every time I used it. Not a problem anymore. My house is a ranch with a finished basement. Bedroom is in basement. I used to have a range extender get the signal for the entire house. Not a problem anymore. I'm so impressed, that I am actually mad at myself for not upgrading a long time ago. I can't believe how much better my internet is now. The app to setup was super simple.
title: Super impressed with this.

author: The War Doctor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: Purchased for setting up a wireless security and internet in secondary home.I've set up several routers in the past and realized my new laptop had no ethernet port.  I must have searched 4 or 5 stores in vain for an USB-Ether adapter that no one had in stock.  All the seeking was based on a bad assumption as it turns out.  Unlike routers I've used in the past, this one did not require a direct connect for doing the initial setup.Despite choosing a mid range model based on planned use, the coverage was surprisingly good.  Remote access and monitoring also made it a great choice to monitor the system without having to be present at the property.TPLink peripherals also linked in with no challenges at all - mini cams, light controls, etc - making a do it yourself upgrade for the whole home simple and affordable.I will most likely use this brand and upgraded model should I need to ever replace the routers in our primary residence.  Thanks.
title: Great coverage and features

author: Hello
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2020
review_content: The router was working fine for a month, but after a single month of use, I notice a consistent drop in internet. I spoke to my internet provider thinking it was them; but it was not. The best and only culprit (i come to find) was this router. The customer service doesn't even know how to manage tech support. They first had me limit my own MBS to only 100 for stability when I am supposed to get 400+. I noticed the CPU fluctuating a lot. Mentioned this to the person on the phone. He said, it's nothing. Person on the phone kept trying to have me get off the phone because it was Friday at 5:00, so I did. I followed up with an email and that was of no help at all. They just simply moved me to the next person in line that may be of more use. I googled why CPU is important in routers and here we are. This router can't even provide a consistent 200MBS to your desktop, laptop, or tablets/phone. Would not get if you like consistent WIFI or Ethernet connection.
title: Horrible CPU = Disrupted Internet Connetion

author: Dennis L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2019
review_content: This is a great router for the price.  There’s probably better routers out there but some cost as much as 8x the price.  I’ve used this router about a month and it has been very stable - both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz connections.  The range is good, not as great as I had hoped, but an improvement on my old Wireless N router.Pros- Stable connection- A real bargain for 50 bucks- LED lights make it easy to know status- Aesthetically pleasing- Very easy to setupCons- Web interface could be better organized as the “basic” and “advanced” tabs have redundant content- Customer service for TP-Link is lacking. They respond in a timely manner to emails but give generic answers, managing to not answer your questions.
title: Great Budget Router

author: Amazon shopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: Going from a Linksys that I had for about 20 years, I needed an upgrade. My devices were running slow and the linksys could not reach some of the other devices. This upgrade was the best thing I did for all of my devices. It has two networks that you can use, the 2.4 G and the 5 G. The 2.4 works great for outside cameras and there are no signal interruptions or lag. The inside devices run super fast on the 5 G network. I am able to block devices, and I am able to block certain websites. I am also, with the app, able to see what devices are connected to what networks and control everything that is mentioned. I can also schedule the lights on the router to turn off at a certain time and turn on. There are still things to explore on this router, but when it comes to fast networking, reaching outside of the house, multiple devices with no lag, controlling whose on and what they connect to, it is stellar! It has only been a few months, but no hiccups.
title: This router is awesome!

author: JWH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2019
review_content: We have Xfinity  Performance Plus (160 mbps).My prior ASUS RT-AC56u (1200) router started having issues with 2.4ghz range where 5mbps was about my average speed while 5ghz was 180mbps.  Something was broken.Picked this TP-Link router up during the Amazon Truck flash sale for $44, and upon standard setup, the 2.4ghz bumped to 80+ mbps.Setup was simple and straight-forward through their router web application.Note that their URL is different to access the router.192.168.0.1 ortplinkwifi.net/webpages/login.htmlGot everything up and running in 15 minutes.Signal strength on inSSIDer (free version) is great.We have about 10 devices (FireTV/computers/smartphones/tablets/doorbell/thermostat) that need wifi.4 televisions5 computers4 smartphones1 doorbell1 thermostatNo issues with speed when most devices are on the network (we don't run all of them at the same time as 2 TVs are used as monitors, we're not using smartphone while on the computer, etc.).
title: Have slow wifi?  solved my problem

author: MG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: I bought this around two weeks back as I wanted to switch from a 4 year old router to a new one so that I get a better wifi coverage and reliable signals. It was a right decision to go with this router as it is quite amazing to see how good it works in this price range.I am not a hardcore gamer but work from home (along my other family members and schools being online). I just need my wifi to be reliable, able to handle multiple devices and give me most out of the bandwidth that my ISP provides. For an average use this product is excellent. I have not used it for network gaming but I use it to extend my computer monitor to a wifi display and it works amazing.I highly recommend this smart router that is affordable and is good enough for a regular use. Some of the features include:1. Dual band (2.4Ghz, 5Ghz) - router optimizes the bandwidth by automatically switching your device to one of the two bands that is less congested.2. Good coverage and good signal strength3. Guest Wifi - easy to setup and turn on/off when you have guests using mobile app.4. Mobile app to manage your network5. Worth for price tag.I was looking for a $100+ range router. Glad I stumbled upon it and bought it. Saved a lot. :)
title: Awesome for family internet

author: Amy-n-Dave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: We have two of these routers and they both work really well. One is in the basement, and one upstairs. We're able to get very fast and reliable internet connections which really helps with working from home. Set up was very easy and only took a few minutes. The app works really nicely. Our tech friend helped us find this one, and we love it. Very affordable. Would definitely recommend.
title: Great router and very affordable

author: Dragos
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2020
review_content: I bought this router after my former Asus RT-N12 started to show low performance. I had it for more than 5 years (maybe 7), and it did its job wonderfully.So, after looking at many devices and their corresponding reviews, I chose this one the Archer A7 or TP-Link AC1750 as it has one of the lowest 1 star rating (10%).Unboxing, and installing took a short time, and everything seemed to work as expected. I was looking through the menus and activated the ARP Binding feature which lets you manually bind an IP to a MAC, a rather common feature in all the routers I've had. Again, no problem, and everything was nicely working... or so I thought. Next morning, almost all my devices did not have internet connection.Imagine trying to fix the internet connection with all your family anxiously breathing down your neck. A simple reboot seemed to fix the issue, but after few hours, it appeared again. I ended up rebooting the router 2-3 time every day.The problem: although my computers could connect to the router they could not get an IP. To make it even more confusing, the router logs showed delivering an IP to each of the requesting computers every time one was asking for it.I decided to return it, and there were no question asked, I immediately got a return label.Next step, I ordered another router, a Linksys, this time. Pricier, and more powerful, but with problems, too. I could not set my preferred DNS servers, so I returned it, and went back to the initial choice (TP-Link AC1750). I still had my unit and decided to give it another try before send it back.After many attempts, I think I found the culprit: it is the ARP Binding feature. If you enable it, and bind one IP to a MAC, that computer will loose its internet connection after several hours. The moment it gets unbounded everything returns to normal.Now that I know the issue, it is more of an annoyance, and I decided to keep the unit. But still, for all the headache it gave me, I labeled it with 1 star only!#################################Returning after ~2 months of heavy usage, I can say that it works at an acceptable level of reliability. The problem is that the router itself temporarily looses its internet connection 2-3 times/week. From this interruptions one turns into permanent, and for that I need to reboot the device.
title: Buggy features - ARP Binding

author: peejmeister
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
review_content: Was using a cheaper TP-Link wi-fi router.  With the recent shelter-in-place orders, two adults on video conference calls and two kids streaming, the conference calls were experiencing intermittent glitches and reconnect issues.  Swapping in this Archer A7 seems to have resolved the conference call issues.  The main difference with this router is that you cannot name the two different bands (5G & 2.4) differently so if you have smart devices and other users connecting to the different bands, even if you name the new router the same as the old, some devices may have to be reconfigured.  Not a huge deal, but one worth noting.
title: So Far, Handling 4 Concurrent Users Successfully

author: TKay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
review_content: This router was incredibly simple to setup, powerful, and is dual band, all for a great price. There is no guesswork. I bought it because I needed wireless in my home so I could finally divorce cable TV and implement the firestick.  I live way out in the country where wifi can be sporatic and direct tv signals are a complete nightmare. While I realize a router is dependent on a good signal, this router is seems to effortlessly and intelligently manage signal to all my wireless devices, unlike my old unit which was hit and miss.All wires and components necessary for out of the box set up are included.  It comes with a card the size of a credit card with the name of both bands and password and fits great in my rolodex. Instructions are clear, detailed and step by step.  Contacts for tech support listed. With the ease of setup and detailed instructions, you dont need to even contact tech support.  So easy, anyone can do it, even those who are not tech savvy such as myself. The router is pleasing in appearance.
title: So easy, you will think you are an IT PRO.

author: Sticks-n-Stones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2020
review_content: Install was fine, easy.  Works as it should for it's router duties.One issue though and it's a small one, but it says a lot about a design.There are two hang holes on the back of this unit.  And that's GREAT.  I wanted to hang it on the wall rather than have to build a shelf for it in my cabinet shop.It didn't come with any screws to actually hang it from.  No problem.  I have a cabinet shop FULL of hardware.  ALL sorts of hardware.  Literally 1000's of screws of all shapes and sizes.NOT ONE OF THOSE SCREWS FIT.Drywall screws?  Nope, heads too big.#8 pan head? Nope.#8 Flat head?  Nope.#6 Pan head?  Nope.#6 Flat head?  Nope.Those are 99% of what the average homeowner will have at their local hardware store.  I can grind the heads down, but many, many people don't have the tools for that.So here's my deal and why I downgraded a star.  There's old stories about Van Halen's rider for their shows that asked for specific things in their green room.  Things like NO BROWN M&Ms.  They knew that if they walked in and there were brown M&M's in the bowl, there were likely going to be issues with the venue.Because if you can't do the simple things right, what are the odds that the stuff that matters was done right?Two slots that fit a commonly available standard screw?There's an engineer out there who should be hanging their head in shame.
title: Works well but......

author: JRinUSA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
review_content: Update: still leaving positive review since INSIDE ONLY works GREAT!!!!  My outdoor security cameras however were the casualty, so if you have outdoor need for wifi do NOT BUY THIS router.  I had to pay a tech to set it up and then three weeks later discovered wifi recordings were sporadic, unreliable signal.  So much for paying nearly as much as the router cost to cover labor.----------------------------original review:I canceled Netgear since they offer ZERO customer service with the app. plus it was my experience you must go higher with the square footage than what the box says as it's misleading. NO way did it cover what it said it did.  This one so far is accurate, and I'm glad I left Netgear.  Great app horrible customer service.  Netgear is horrendous.TP [inside only]  is most definitely FASTER than Netgear.  They both claim the same coverage, yet Netgear fell short.  I vote TP-link for INDOOR only.
title: horrible if you need outside wifi

author: Dan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2019
review_content: Excellent router for the price. I bought this so I could attempt to have greater coverage in my 2 story house and move from 2 routers and 1 repeater down to 1 router, and this unit did just that. I usualy get a new one every 3 years or so with the better reach and newer tech, and for $60 this is by far the best one yet. On the 5 ghz signal, I have 100+ mb/sec download speeds 70' away through 2 walls and 65 mb/sec on the 2nd floor at 75' away. To compare, the Belkin 1200 in the same location gave me 22 mb/sec and 12 mb/sec, respectively. I have Spectrum cable @ 100 mb/sec download speeds so, to see 100 mb/sec 5' from the router and 70' away through 2 walls...quite impresive. As a side note, with the 2.4 ghz signal expect about a 40% reduction in speed vs the 5 Ghz.
title: Amazing coverage and speed for the price!

author: southernlady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2020
review_content: My internet provider modem was causing me to drop my VPN connection when working remote. The technician stated that I needed a wifi extender...not so I just needed a better wifi router signal because this one is in the the exact location of the providers router. This also makes it so I won't need to reset all my wifi passwords when the internet provider has to replace my modem or I change providers.
title: Good signal strength

author: D. John Crannell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: Finally works Had lots of trouble with to-link tech support. The chat feature cuts you off and you have to start all over again. If you need support call. The lady on the phone was very knowledgeable but her English was only a little better than my Chinese but we eventually found the problem! Comporium network had not released the previous MAC address, so it took a visit from the ISP to fix the problem. 3 hrs on phone with Comporium tech support did not good but the on site visit got it all working . The router is defective in that the eithernet cable will not lock into the router. The cable will fall out. We replaced the eithernet cable connector same problem! Was a really frustrating experience starting up the router apparently all Comporium network fault! After getting working the router seems to have excellent range and functions well. Few instructions with router they have you download an app which works ok. Did not find my issue however without calling tech support and ISP on site visit. Router was well packaged.
title: Once it is working it works well

author: Amber
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2019
review_content: So i'm torn on whether i should return this router.  Set up was extremely easy. Took me 5 minutes.  However, I have 200/200 speed with Frontier and of course that's only guaranteed when hooked up directly and not using it wirelessly.I tested my speed 3 times with my old router and it measured an average of 51/54 with my wireless laptop.  I tested again after hooking up this TP-Link router expecting it to be faster especially when i picked the 5GHz and it's only averaging 48/49 so even slower than my Frontier router. Not by much so not a huge deal but i only have 2 devices connected to it now so worried it will get worse when adding other cell phones and wireless devices in the house.Are there better devices out there that are faster? I see this company has other routers just wondering if paying more for one offers faster speeds? Would be willing to pay more if can help with speed.In summary, if you are looking to speed up your internet connection i would no purchase it. If you are looking for an okay way to connect and drop the $10 rental fee that Frontier charges then yes, purchase this router!
title: Very slow but does work to replace Frontier router that I'm paying to rent monthly

author: Migraine Girl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: When we first bought this router it worked well, signal was strong.  After only a couple of months it would drop the signal sporadically about once per day and we would have to reset it.  At first we thought it was our service provider but after troubleshooting with them it was determined that it was in fact an issue with our new router.  Tried to address the issue with the tech support of the manufacturer twice (on hold for over 30 minutes both times), and each time all they could do for us was do a hard reset and call back if it happens again (WTF, no help AT ALL!!!).  At the end they said to connect my modem directly to my computer for a few hours to determine if there was a problem with my service provider (we already knew there wasn't).  TLDR:  Piece of junk that only lasted a couple months with almost ZERO help from company.  Amazon refunded us so we could buy a better unit.
title: Didn't last long, tech support was abysmal

author: Shannon Mccauley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
review_content: Our Verizon router was moving very slow. Even thought we had upgraded to the 100/100 package, Verizon did not send us new equipment and our speed was ridiculous. I was averaging 3 download and 22 upload. After reviewing products, we decided to take a chance on this and I am so glad we did. It was so easy to set up - just plug the included Ethernet cord into the old router and set up your login through their app. I'm a little bit of a techie, but this would have been simple for anyone. We went from 3 to 110 in a matter of seconds. Everyone in the house is happy - no more drops or lags! Thank you!
title: We're zipping along now.

author: Todd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2019
review_content: Set this up in my 2 Brm apartment to replace an inexpensive ($34.99) router to try and get better signal in other rooms of the apartment. Set it up according to directions and had worse coverage than my cheap Netgear unit. Went to tech support and had them walk me through set up to ensure I was doing it correctly...I was...still poor signal strength. It's now in a box and I'm using the old Netgear unit again.Frustrating because I did a fair amount of research on the AC1750 and it was given 5 star, glowing recommendations from several sources.
title: Don't waste your money

author: jd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2020
review_content: I have a Linksys WRT1200 that was slacking as I added more devices to the 5GHz band. I got this so I could disable the 5GHz band on my Linksys (to have it exclusively run my legacy devices on 2.4GHz) and use this as my dedicated 5GHz router. The setup worked way better than I expected. Easily getting the full bandwidth from my ISP (200Mbps) and even faster between devices. I have about 15 devices to this router on 5GHz (I didn't test the 2.4GHz prior to disabling that radio), and it works exceptionally throughout my home (and to my backyard). A very happy purchase!
title: Impressed!

author: hector ortega
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
review_content: I ordered received this June 15th, 2020 and it broke on June 24th, 2020. I have it sitting in the living room with WiFi going and a cat 5 cable connected to the Xbox. While playing some Xbox, it randomly shuts off. I did a hard reboot several times, it would get to where it would search for the network provider and then the lights just shut off. I was very happy with how well it worked prior to it crapping out, but I'll take a refund and go with something more reliable. The nighthawk looks promising.Edit: turns out my internet provider had a problem on their end which caused the router to shut off, in the meantime I was using my older linksys ac1200+ to fill in. I have gigbit internet and was curious to see my speed test. Linksys ac1200+ averaged around 400-500 mb per second in upload and download speed, while the tplink averaged 200-300 mb per second. Use this information as you so fit, but I'll stick with the Linksys router to later upgrade to a more newer Linksys router.
title: It was great while it lasted.

author: Russell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2019
review_content: I started caring about my internet speed a week ago when I received an email from my ISP advising they bumped me up to 150MBPS. I was dismayed when I went to speedtest.net only to find my connection was less than 20MBPS. I had no-one to blame but myself since we've been using Tamara's old WiFi Netgear router from 2003. On Monday I received a brand new WAVLINK AC1200 router that I bought for $30 on Amazon. I also talked my ISP into giving me their latest cable modem. Confident, I again visited speedtest.net only to be disappointed. The best I could do was 94MBPS. I was supposed to be getting 150MfreakingBPS. Nothing I did would get me above 94. Thankfully Amazon has an awesome return policy, so I instead purchased the TP-Link AC1750 router for under $60. Not only does this sweet little router give me the features I wanted that the other one lacked, but I'm now peggin 170MBPS data rates.Update: after a few days of use, I’ve noticed this router has lousy coverage compared to the $30 router.
title: FANTASTICALLY FAST BUT LOUSY COVERAGE

author: XEagleDriver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
review_content: Bought a TP-LINK AC1750 after extensive online research (beyond just AMA) and the positive reviews were spot on.  In my case, this wifi router was the only change made to cover a 3k sqft, 2-story home.  Farthest rooms went from 3-5 Mbps to 30+ Mbps.  Near rooms went from 10 Mbps to triple digits.  Being able to establish two separate guest networks (one 2.4GHz and one 5GHz) made managing signal to four FireSticks easy and reliable.  Setup user interface was simple, powerful, and logical.  Did not grade tech support, since I did not need them!Definite recommend from me.
title: Tp-Link AC1750 is a WINNER!

author: Critical Analysist
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2020
review_content: Update - ABSOLUTE TRASHCan see the WiFi router inside the house, signal range about 25’!Wanted to like this modem but the signal is so weak I can literally walk out side where I can see the unit and a 50' the signal drop out, Tech support saw my review about the need of a SMA connector for an external antenna and the poor signal. I have mused that next time I would go with mesh WI-Fi repeaters. oh we have those! (More Money!).No do it right the first time, would not recommend for a large (2800 sq ft) house. Its a dissapointment!
title: Very weak Wi-Fi signal

author: BarbDeBlois
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2020
review_content: I love it!!!! There are so many routers out there now and most are way out of my price range. I spent days reading reviews and comparing different specifications. I finally settled on this one, and Im glad I did. Half the price of most other routers but it had great reviews and I figured it HAD to be better than the older one I had.  I wouldn't say Im a tech guru, but I can usually figure electronics out and this was a snap. It was super easy to set up with the app, and I also connected a tp link wifi extender which I actually already had so they are both connected via the app. It probably took me a total of 15 minutes to set up. It cut my buffering issues down a good 90%. I have 4 tablets,  4 rokus and 2 phones connected via wifi, not to mention several alexa speakers with one in the basement and there is never an issue connecting with the wifi. I would definitely recommend this router!
title: GREAT router at a reasonable price!

author: william d.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
review_content: So with the router from spectrum I was getting like barely 100 mbps and with this  i am getting over 200. I thin k this is a great buy and very solid although I think there may be even more expensive models where it can be more lightning fast but at this price being around $50 or $60 you cant beat it. If you want something better youll probably have to drop at least $300 or more.
title: Very strong Wifi with this

author: moo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2020
review_content: Update 10/26/20I still hate this router. Every day I have to reboot it to get a device back online..Update 9/14/20This router still sucks!Update 7/6/20This Router blows. It disconnects one of my devices every day causing me to need to reboot the router daily. It claims it can do up to 50 devices but that's a dam lie.Would Not Recommend to anyone, which sucks b.c I normally like TP hardware.. :(Update 3/10/20IV had the router for almost a month now and I'm seeing a problem already. It can only handle 7 of my devices connected to it before it starts dropping a device to free up processor. A simple reboot of the router fixes it but I'm rebooting a few times a week. B.c of this IV dropped the score down a star.Very good wifi router. It has many configuration options to adjust your network as you see fit with good logging options. Setup was simple and quick. I'd like to see a few security features such as 2 factor authentication or alerts on new devices connecting to the network in future updates. I'd recommend this router to family and friends
title: Buy Something better

author: Tori
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: We moved into a new house and wanted just internet. I spent a few days researching routers and modems so we could save on rental costs. I decided on this router after reading reviews. We have a 2 story home with basement as well, 1900 sq ft home. I wanted to put the router upstairs but for some reason we only have antenna lines up there, not internet cables. Will address that eventually. For now it's in our living room on main floor. We have a college kid and 2 elementary kids doing online school with laptops. Mobile devices, gaming systems, other smart devices, and 4 Roku Tvs. Our internet is 600mps. First 2 days hooking it up, my daughter complained of spotty connection. After redirecting antennas on router, we haven't had a problem. We have no issues in basement or outside. It was relatively simple to set up. Only have had it a month but so far it's great!
title: Great Router

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2019
review_content: I have been a TPLink fan for a long time and have never had issues. I was buying this because my old TPLink router was starting to lose Wifi signal. It worked for about 10 minutes and ran some speed tests and all looked well at about 150MB/sec. Then extreme drops in speed occurred where I could not even get 3MB out of my tests, which by today's standards, might as well be dial-up. This was not just a Wifi issue either. My desktop is hard wired to my router and the same issue persisted. To ensure that the new router was the issue, I hardwired to my modem directly and all was good.After doing some research online, this is apparently a huge issue with this model which makes me wonder how the rating here on Amazon is so high. I highly suggest people look up reviews elsewhere before investing in this.To make matters worse, I attempted to live chat with TPLink support and was the only person in the queue for about 45 minutes before I gave up on that. Unfortunately, this has shaken my confidence in TPLink and now I may be forced to find another brand.
title: Constant drops in speed!

author: Adam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2019
review_content: Really displeased. When it works, it’s great and has wide coverage across our entire home... but it’s just very very unstable.Latest firmware at the time of this writing and nothing but problems retaining a stable  2.4 or 5ghz connection. Things work fine for a few hours than require a power cycle to correct packet loss, radios going up and down, disconnects and other unstable connection Issues with a myriad of devices (including IOS, Android, harmony ultimate and ip cameras).UI features are also way too basic. Debating trying a c7 firmware or openwrt to see if stability might improve.
title: Would be great if it could remain stable

author: Sam P
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2020
review_content: I've bought linksys and netgear nighthawk in the past. I'm shocked at the range and speed of this router. I figured it was an off brand. I had an old TP link EAP that has crappy software (no default security etc) but the actual signal has help up really well over the years so i figured i'd try another TP Link. At the tested range (of the other side of my house) the speed was 3 times that of the $200 netgear night hawk i bought 2 years ago.I'm still using this netgear as my primary switch. I disabled the wifi and am using the TP link to process wifi only. So my PC, work router and other hardwired devices are connected to the netgear. This seems to be the fastest set up so one router isn't doing all the processing for both  routing and wifi signaling.if you just want something simple with a great signal id say go with the TP Link.
title: This is the best wifi router by far

author: Thomas Gray
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2019
review_content: So let me start off by saying I did A TON of research before buying a Wi-Fi router. After reading reviews, doing research and asking techy friends. I decided this was in my budget and it has been the best router ever!!!!!It does have the 5GHz and 2.4GHz band which makes it nice to for the new electronics and phones that are coming out but still has the 2.4GHz band for the older devices. The 5GHz is super fast but doesn't reach as far. The 2.4GHz is fast but also reaches farther than the 5GHz. I am planning on buying a Wi-Fi extender for the garage which is a little ways away from the house.The app makes it super easy to manage the router and see what devices are connected and also makes it SUPER EASY to set up a Guest Wi-Fi NetworkOverall, I'm VERY HAPPY with this product and would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this router to ANYONE.
title: HIGHLY Satisfied with the Router

author: gail greeley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2018
review_content: Not only was it easy to use and at a great price but with the app on itunes or android it was super quick. Let me rename my network the same as the old one with the same password which made it easy to switch everything too. Price is great and this works with FIOS internet and saved me $14 a moth, which will pay for itself in 4 weeks.I did a speed test too and we went from 38 over 14 with Verizon's router to 87 over 78 with this one which makes a difference when streaming netflix, kids playing online video games, and numerous phones in our house at any given moment.I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a quick and easy product change that allows you to get rid of the cable provider's routers and save some cash.
title: WOW . . . took this non-tech dude about 20 minutes from start to everything set-up!!!

author: Nate
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2020
review_content: Initially I was quite happy with this router.  The signal was great and internet speeds fast.  Then one day it decided it didnt want to connect to anything.  Updating software, troubleshooting and attempting to contact ANYONE with the company proved fruitless.  In the end, I went back to my 5 year old router that works without issue.  I admit, I am no expert in these things but i cant for the life of me understand why it would just decide to stop connecting one day for no apparent reason.  Perhaps a call to customer service would have worked, but i couldnt speak to a human at all.  So, it sits collecting dust on a shelf while my old trusty slower, but more reliable, router keeps on keeping on without any issues at all.  It's a shame, because i really did appreciate the faster speeds and better coverage the few months this piece of junk worked.  Stay away unless you are extremly knowledgeable networks in the very least!
title: Stopped connecting after a few months

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2020
review_content: Routers are one of those things that are easy to forget about. You have yours for years and it works fine, but then it starts showing its age. Your ISP starts giving you more bandwidth, and before you know it your router just can't keep up.If this sounds like you, I would definitely recommend this as an upgrade. It has 3 setup interfaces: basic, intermediate, and advanced. This allows you to choose your exact level of control and ease-of use you need. I live in an apartment with way to many wifi signals, and this does a much better job handling interference than my 5 year old router, especially with the 5ghz band (a feature I was sadly without until this).I have 100mpbs down and 10mpbs up under my current plan. And with this router I actually hit download speeds of about 120mbps on 5g and Ethernet. I do some game streaming as well and have no problems with ping times or dropped frames. If you've got multiple people doing video calls at home right now, it should handle the traffic just fine (provided you don't hit a cap from your ISP).I've had this about 2 months and no issues so far. Definitely a great upgrade for a really good price.
title: Great Replacement for an Aging Router.

author: Cybernetic.Eve
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2019
review_content: Yay! I'm now getting half of the speed I'm paying Comcast for! :PSeriously though, with my old TP-Link router, I was getting 20MPS, sometimes as low as (I kid you not) 1MPS. I just ran the speed test, I'm now at a minimum of 50MPS, and when I use a TP-Link range extender, I'm at 75MPS. Awesome!That range extender piece: this router has 2-3 bars our of 5 at the far end of a medium sized house. Its range is OK but not awesome. I prefer to connect with no extender, since extenders are prone to dropping the signal and increase the probability of the signal dropping. I run a business at home and my telephony is internet based, so I can't deal with dropped signals.When I say "medium sized house", it's a 1400 square foot floor plan. I connect through a stairwell and laundry room (so lots of solid wood and metal pipes rather than drywall which lets wi-fi signals through more readily). YMMV, but that's my situation.
title: Great value. 2.5X the speed versus my old 2.4GHZ router

author: rpc.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
review_content: I just got this Archer A7 router today. Installation was a breeze, but product registration was a bear. So simple to put a notice on the installation guide: "how to register this product." Plus this router gets almost exactly the same speeds as my old Netgear N600: 25 Mbps download, 3 Mbps upload. I'm go to pack the A7 up and send it back, because I can't seem to find out why my speeds are so low. Unless somebody from TP-Link reads this and provides a way for me to talk to them. EDIT, LATER: I chatted with an Amazon rep, and got the straight story. Now  I'm happy.
title: Amazon saved the day!

author: Matt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2020
review_content: Purchased this on the Wirecutter recommendation.  Coming from an ASUS router this was a step down in terms of functionality which is expected given the price.  However after a week of use, this router would regularly have "hiccups" in terms of connectivity and speed.  The connection would periodically drop out.  Having run across this before in other routers a reboot would fix but I shouldn't be rebooting a brand new router.  The GUI admin interface is very basic but does the job for the most part.  I ended up returning getting a Synology router which has been light years better.  The old adage of "you get what you pay for" applies here.  Save your money and get a higher end router that lasts.
title: Save your money for something better

author: Mountain Man
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2019
review_content: I replaced my TP-Link C7 Router with this A7 after a lightning strike knocked out my C7.  I am pleased with the function and performance of the A7.  The signal strength for both 2.4GHz and 5GHz are very good, and I use the multiple networks (including Guest Network) for securing and supporting my requirements.The user interface is good, including the web interface for managing the settings, etc.  I would prefer the indicator lights on the front of the router to be similar to the C7.  The C7 provided better feedback with lights that would "flicker" in response to network and modem activity.  The A7 indicator lights are either "on" or "off" as indicators of connectivity.  The lights on the A7 are also too dim for my preference to be able to see them clearly from across a lighted room.Overall, I would highly recommend the TP-Link AC1750 A7 WiFi Router.  I would definitely purchase the same device again.
title: Excellent WiFi router in both performance and function

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2020
review_content: Let me start by saying that I originally owned the TPLink AC1200 (Archer C1200).  That router was the best I had owned and it allowed me to have a guest connection, 5G connection and the 2.5 connection.  This router does not allow you to choose what device gets what speed and it also does not have the larger range that previous model held.  This router also says that it is compatible with multiple devices at one time, but it cannot even run a Smart TV watching Disney+.  This router causes buffering issues that cannot be resolved through the tech support because quite frankly this router will not keep it going.  Another issues is the range.  I try to use the phone no more than an estimated 30 feet from it and it lags so bad that you cannot get an internet page or app to load.  Do not buy this model as it is not worth the headache caused from it.
title: Buffering.... Lagging.... Lack of Range

author: Gregory C. Schmidt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2020
review_content: Wireless management doesn’t work after updating firmware.I’ve tried everything from resetting the router, rebooting, disabling wireless and rebooting my phone.  I deleted the app and reinstalled it.  It worked perfectly fine from my phone until I updated the firmware, now it’s done.My phone sees the device but it says the “connection to it is unstable and to move closer.”  I’m practically on top of it!  I can manage it just fine via Ethernet, but not over wireless.It’s a shame an update broke the wireless management capabilities.
title: Works great after painful setup.  Wireless management doesn’t work.

author: Justin C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2019
review_content: I finally know what stable 100mbs feels like... Its powerfull enough to power all 6 of my ring devices, smart tv's, tabs and cellphone... Worth every penny till you upgrade your internet speed to 400+MBPS ...I recently upgraded my internet speed to 400+MBPS with spectrum. Hard wired I'm getting 450mbps thru the ether net cable from the router. But I'm barely getting 130 to 170mbps on 5g( once in a while 220mbps and only on 5g on wifey's Note 9 ) thru wifi and barely 50mbps on 2.4g ( at the best 80mbps ) ... Very disappointing.
