Ive tried working with TP Link and swapped out channels ... I even used the wifi analyzer app to narrow down which band had the least amount of interference. And still the best this router could muster is a sold 130mbps on 5g... I'll be replacing this thing soon ...9/11/19 updated review: TP - Link Tech Support is traveling at snail mail speeds. And now the Router drops 5ghz constantly !!!
title: Amazing ... then the new new wears out?!?! 9/11/19 updated DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY!!!

author: R. Copley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2020
review_content: We recently upgraded from 75Mbps to 450Mbps Internet service and my old router was limited to 100Mbps "fast ethernet" for both wired and WiFi connections, so I researched faster routers and decided on this one.  We've had it running for a month now and I have no regrets.  I use a wired Ethernet connection for work from home, which is just as fast as plugging directly into my cable modem, and the WiFi speeds are great too, around 300-400Mbps in the rooms nearest the router and around 200Mbps in the rest of the house.  Those speeds are plenty fast for even the most demanding streaming or gaming.  I have had no problems with slow ping, dropped packets, lagging connections, or buffering, even with 10 or more devices connected both WiFi and wired.  Would recommend for anyone wanting to upgrade their speed above 100Mbps.  For reference, our home is about 2400 sq ft, two story, the cable modem has to be in the corner of the house in the family room near the garage, so it is quite far away from the rest of the house and the upstairs bedrooms.  We do have a TP-Link WiFi extender in the upstairs bedrooms farthest away from this router, and that helps with the speed and stability upstairs.  Overall this is a very good router that handles faster internet speeds well.
title: Very fast, handles multiple devices easily, Tether app makes setup and maintenance easier

author: chili
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2019
review_content: I read the reviews about this thing being great and then crapping our after a few months. I did a lot of searching and even the expensive ones have that same issue for some. I came back to this one for the price and then right in front of me was the $9.99 protection plan for 4 years. This thing was as easy as it gets to set up with the app. Coverage of my house, 3500 ft, is stellar and lighting fast. It’s in the middle of the house so we get it everywhere. I did a speed test wirelessly from my MacBook outside on the patio, about 40’ from the router, and have speeds consistent from 160 to 180 mbps download and 20 mbps upload on the 5G. Running all 3 Apple TVs on the 5G and the rest of our devices on the 2.4 and no problems at all, no lag streaming anywhere. The $9.99 warranty was a no brainer, even with that it’s a cheaper router than the others and I don’t have to worry about it crapping out on me.
title: Buy the warranty

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020
review_content: This replaced my old router that just stopped working and needed reset several times a day.  I wasn’t sure what to buy since it had been about 4 years since I last got one.  I am glad I chose this one.  It was simple to set up although my only complaint is that you have to download an app to set it up.  I always find that annoying.  Anyway, this thing has worked for a couple months with no issue and reaches my entire house which was something my last router couldn’t do.  I have a basement office and was always working on a hot spot, but not anymore.  It provides Internet for all our devices; 3 tv’s, 3 phones, and 4 laptops/tablets, two Alexa devices and a couple google speakers.  4 stars and would be 5 if I didn’t have to download an app to set it up.
title: Simple to use and works great

author: Houseman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2020
review_content: Nighthawk app is useless if using two netgear routers coming from one DSL/modem/router. Then it's pressure sales from it's tech support "one time offer" for a year "for only" $$$$ if you sign up in 30 minutes instead of the free 90 days call support. I guess its like that everywhere, but I don't like it. Instead of sitting 45 minutes on hold to be transferred to another "specialized tech" and wait another 45 minutes, when you pay for the service you will automatically go to the "tier one" tech with supposedly with no waiting.It's a simple setup if you only have one router. But, if you buy two routers, that's another story. I can only recommend this product if you only get one router. For God's sake don't get the TP-link.  You need an electon microscope for the instructions and passwords are so cryptic.
title: NightHawk app will not work with two new netgear routers

author: Bear
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: We received the router very quickly and it was pretty easy to install. I did have to call our internet provider with a question or 2 but that's just because of my confusion.It was installed and working for us within 10 minutes of taking it out of the box.  It continues to give us a good signal though we did find that it worked better with our Roku TV after we moved the furniture around which put the router in front of the tv rather than behind it. When it was sitting behind the tv (which is where I have always kept our routers), we would have to connect to the internet every time we turned on the TV. After moving the furniture around, we found that the Roku TV was already connected as soon as we turned it on - which is the way it should work. Not sure if is a coincidence or not.Very happy with the quality and service of the router.
title: Easy to Install, Easy to Use

author: JAMES  L  SNITKER
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2019
review_content: As usual, Amazon delivered the unit in 2 days.  Love Amazon Prime.  This TP-Link Archer AC1750 wireless router was a breeze to set up.  Powered down my old Linksys EA3500 (which this unit replaced), powered down my Centurylink modem, connected my laptop to the TP-Link via direct Ethernet, connected the TP-Link to my modem, powered up the modem, powered up the TP-Link, brought up the wireless connections on the laptop, found the TP-Link wireless network, connected to that network, launched my browser and brought up the TP-Link setup program in my browser window.  Three minutes to set up the router (duplicating my existing home network name and settings) in the TP-Link setup program - and that was it.  Reconnected my two laptops, two desktops, and seven streaming media devices to the network and everything works - just much faster than before.  Ran Ookla SpeedTest and saw significant increase in both download and upload speeds from both my desktop and laptop.  Didn't realize that my seven year old Linksys was just that slow.  So far this TP-Link is great.  Let's hope it last.
title: Great Router for the Price

author: Jeff Rosner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
review_content: Our house setup was showing it's age. Had an AmpedWireless router basestation and a WAP (Wireless Access Point) that I setup using an early 90s Linksys router. Some of my cabling was still "10base" compatible (if you don't know what that is, look it up for a laugh) and was limiting the full use of our cable internet bandwidth (300Mbps) in the nether regions of our modest home.After updating the cabling with Cat5e (in the crawlspace...ughh) I bought an Archer A7 to replace the Linksys WAP (in my office/music studio). The setup was straightforward and the capabilities impressed me; I had never fully appreciated the benefits of 5GHz (despite being trained as a EE) and the automatic channel #placement freed me from navigating our VERY crowded neighborhood WiFi environment (adjacent to Stanford University).Upon this epiphany, I immediately ordered a second A7 to replace the Amped Wireless unit (only 2.4GHz channels). Now our entire 5,750 sf lot gets WiFi >>100Mbps
title: Extremely seamless operation, straightforward setup, high performance

author: Brian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2020
review_content: UPDATE: As evident by the earlier version of this review, I originally loved this router. 5 stars and fantastic performance. However, about 30 days later, this router decided it no longer wanted to function properly.  It produced a network consistently but my devices struggled to display content, especially video. Very disappointing.This router totally changed the game for my apartment. I have a large apartment but my previous router could barely stay connected in the same room, probably due to the interference from the many surrounding networks. The automatic selection between the two bands in this router means I am getting maximum speeds, and more importantly, a consistent connection in every square inch of the unit. I currently have around 6 devices connected and they all work flawlessly and quickly. Very easy to set up with a nice online interface. I wish I had purchased this router sooner.
title: Perfect Solution for crowded Apartment WiFi networks

author: Wrecks
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: I purchased this for my home about 7 months ago to use with a Spectrum modem. It was easy to set up and seemed to work just fine until... Spectrum in my area is known to go out on occasion. When it does you're supposed to unplug the router, unplug the modem, wait a couple of minutes, plug in the modem, wait a couple of minutes, plug in the router. A few minutes later, voilà! everything works again, right? WRONG! The first time this happened I was on the phone with TP-Link tech support for over an hour. After being guided through many steps of turning on, turning off, holding buttons down, grumbling obscenities, etc, it finally started working. I wrote down the steps and a couple of months later guess what? Spectrum went out. I went through the steps. Not so fast technical genius, we're not going to make it that easy for you! No connection, the lights didn't come on the way they're supposed to, and so on. After going through the steps several times and finally resetting back to factory defaults I got it to work. The third time this happened I had had enough! I unplugged it and found an old Asus router I had and voilà, it just works. How hard should it be to reboot a router? Correct answer: not hard at all. One day TP-Link may figure it out. Or not. Until then, a strong DO NOT BUY! Unless of course, you enjoy being frustrated and wasting time. You're welcome.
title: Frustrating waste of time, do not buy!

author: fernando
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019
review_content: Ok here is the truth about this product.  Save your money.  The signal strength is not what they say it will be.  I have a small home and I bought this product because I work from home and needed the range to do my work.  Needless to say the ranges is NOT as described.  The wifi my cable company provides is just as good and doesn't give me as many buffering as this one.  I would recommend buying a better brand and would not recommend anyone buy this.
title: Not worth it

author: Affan Khan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2019
review_content: I am really impressed. We have tried a few routers in the past even Netgear Nighthawk R7000 (Paid 230 dollars) but none of them even came close to the range this one is providing with a strong and stable connection. We have a two story house with a basement and this router is installed in the basement and we don't have any dead zones in our house anymore. It covers our 3000 Sq feet house and part of the backyard yard with no problem. Now I hope that is last us a few years.
title: How this is exactly what I was looking for.

author: R. Leventhal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
review_content: This router performs as expected with one minor exception.  I've had it in service for a few days now, but when I try to assign a particular IP to a device by MAC address, the router does what it wants and does not follow my instructions.  If that's the only issue, I'm not 100% happy, but it's still worth the price of admission.  TBH, I have reached out to them on their FB support page but haven't heard back yet.UPDATE: After performing a firmware update, the router began to act as expected and properly assigned IP addresses in my LAN as instructed.  100% satisfied customer.
title: Very high quality for the money

author: Mike
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2020
review_content: I must admit when I got this I was very happy. Then about 6 months in - signal strength started dropping. Then wacky stuff started happening like my printer would not find it when searching. It found all my neighbors but not mine and at the same time my tablet would find it. Pick up the router to look at the connections/wires attached and the signal pops back up. Power cycling sometimes helps for a bit. Anyway, a good router should last longer than 7 months. I would have thought with all the 5 stars, this would have been a keeper. Guess not.
title: Died at 7 months

author: littlebirdie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: quick setup didn't work. looked up instructions on how to set it up manually.when it finally got to working, the wired speed was somehow slower than the wifi speed. both were much slower than modem speed.looked up what the problem was, and there's tons of forums where people have the same problem of the wired speeds being inconsistent and slow compared to the wifi and modem speeds.
title: headache to set up

author: Mark D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2020
review_content: CPU usage spikes to 100% regularly. Scouring the internet tells me this is either actually a problem OR simply an error with the way the interface reports the CPU usage. If it's an error, why not release firmware to patch it? I believe they have released said firmware, so I'm led to believe the CPU spikes are legitimate. Which is nuts.Since replacing my super old D-link with this I've had constant packet loss issues while gaming. However it's totally inconsistent, so I can't completely blame the router.WiFi signal is strong. Bandwidth seems fine most of the time. User interface is good.
title: CPU usage spikes. Good Wi-Fi. Packet loss during gaming.

author: Wuren
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2019
review_content: I had a belkins wireless router from 10 years ago which still works fine, but I decided to purchase this one given the feature of parental control. It was very easy to setup. I thought the wireless signal should have been at least same as my old belkins, but in fact it was weaker than my old router. I set up the parental control via their app Tether, but this app didn’t function reliably. One of my computers failed to get back to internet even after I removed the parental control. I tried to login to tether to change it, but login kept failing after many tries. I had to call technical support whose response was very quick and very friendly, they instructed me to manipulate the app and at the end reset the router, but still did not work, finally they had to hang up which I would not blame. The support team r very good, but I think the problem was from the app and the router itself. I had to return it, I purchased it w high expectations but at the end, if I didn’t disconnect this router, couple of my computers would not get into internet. I switched back to my old router which functions very well. Now my computers are back to normal.
title: Not very reliable

author: Tessy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
review_content: I have owned this for over a year and it has worked well. A couple weeks ago i tried upgrading to deco mesh and let me tell you... This has the system beat. Connectivity and app are so much better and I was getting no more than 100 mbps with the deco and this one gives me almost all 400mbps on Wi-Fi. I find that because I have an almost full smart house I have to reboot this every now and then but it has great control and strong signal through most of the house. I bought a couple extenders for the front and backyards but this is great on its own.
title: Better than an overpriced system!

author: Ninacc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2020
review_content: I am light internet user, mainly for web browsing, music streaming and work from home used. The router works as expected for the first month, and on a weekday afternoon, I am WFH and having a zoom meeting with customer, the internet disconnect for no reason, and the internet connection light turns amber. First, I though it might be modem's issue, then I tried to connect LAN port from modem to device directly and it works, obviously it is the router's issue. Do some google search and find similar issue from other amazon buyers for this router, all you can do is power off router to restart, it reconnects after 5-7 times try. Few days later, same thing happens again, and it becomes so annoying with a unstable internet connection given most of the ppl doing WFH, thanks to Amazon's great customer service, I am able to return the device even after 2 months' used. But I will never purchase TP-Link router again.
title: internet disconnect every couple days

author: E. Murphy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2020
review_content: This review is for the TP-Link AC1750 Archer A7 model.I’ve only been using this router for a few weeks now but I am quite impressed by it. I am using it for my IoT devices, which number above 20. That is actually a lot of devices for a router. My cable supplier’s modem limits me to 10 connections, some other routers I tried got me up to 16 then another connected to all 20+ devices, but there was often a lag in some devices.The Archer 7 connects everything without strain and now everything is working as it should. My wife was even impressed as we were just used to sometimes long delays between asking Alexa to change something and that change actually happening. Now lights change just before Alexa can say “OK!”I am using this in a “three dumb router” scenario as suggested by Steve Gibson a few years back. This completely isolates the IoT devices (that you must assume are either subject to or just plain open to exploits) from my need to be secure devices like my PC and tablets. Sure, it may be possible to get one router to keep things separate but I’m just not that smart about network security (and I’m an electrical engineer!) and just want some peace of mind.
title: Finally my IoT devices are working wihout any delay.

author: charliecharlie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2020
review_content: It was super easy to set up - but I got it because comcast kept telling me my slow speeds were due to the wifi router, which is about 5 years old.  I got this one, but was disappointed to find it gave out exactly the same speed as my old one.  So I don't know where the problem lies - I doubt it is with this router - I'm sure it has something to do with comcast, but this was easy, VERY affordable, and if I needed to get a new router, I would get this one.  As it is, I'm just staying with my old one.
title: Excellent router

author: Tom Berry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: This is a solid router. I got it for a home office. The router has a clear interface, and firmware updates are available through the internet. No more downloading a .bin file to your computer, only to upload it back to the router. It is direct, checks for firmware updates, and updates as appropriate.There are some downsides. I tried to use this with a Pi-Hole, and to use it, it requires you to point the router to a DNS which is on your local network. Because they have nerfed the feature among the TP-Link routers, I now have my DHCP server on the Raspberry Pi. That is an unnecessary PITA.Overall, this is a great router for the average user. If you are looking for something with enough control (static local IPs, custom external DNS, VPN Compatibility) this router will serve you well. The addition of OneMesh, and use of a TP-Link range extender means my home wifi is seamless, and switches without a drop in connection as I move throughout the house.
title: A great router, compatible with OneMesh!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2020
review_content: We went back to our old reliable router because it works great. I bought the TP-Link because of the ratings but it couldn't handle multi bands or internet use. It would knock my computer out 5X a day, when my husband logged on and I couldn't get on the internet on my laptop in the bedroom if we were using the bandwidth for our Smart TV. It was horrendous, I almost missed a work deadline that could have gotten me fired. We tried and tried to use it and then ran out of time, to return it. So, we're stuck with a router we can't use and are out. They don't make the routers as good as the old ones, I can't believe I let my daughter talk me into buying this router. Money & Time Waster!
title: Maybe it was our internet but the router never worked

author: Riaz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
review_content: I've had the Archer A7 router for about 2.5 months. About every seven to ten days, the unit turns itself off.Contacting TP-Link tech support took three tries. On the first call from a land line, the CSR claimed that they could not hear me. I then called the support line via my cell phone and again, the CSR claimed that they could not hear me. I waited about 15 minutes and called again from the land line and was finally able to get to a CSR who could hear me, however, that wait was quite long.The CSR wanted me to plug the router directly into an outlet, instead of into the power strip in the media cabinet. It took some convincing to get the CSR to accept that plugging the unit elsewhere would not resolve the issue today. He finally got approval to replace the unit, but that started another issue...When I tried to register my product via the website to get the RMA process going, the registration process would not accept my serial number. I had a picture of the serial number and entered the 13-digit string multiple times, bit the site still would not register the product. At this point, I have asked for more help and am waiting. It would be very hard to recommend this product to anyone. Why? The unit I have is not reliable and TP-Links' customer service is substandard.
title: Unit keeps turning off

author: frenchy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2019
review_content: I have this router for less than 11 months.So far it had been a good router with good performances but  yesterday it died on me.Now I am testing TP-Link warranty.I shall keep you informed.After spending 30 minutes on the phone with TPlink and trying to troubleshoot my router I gave up.No replacement for me.Update:I open on line a case with the support>I received an email from 'Bella" who is in main ,land China.Bella, was excellent and with tow or thee emails exchanges my router is up and running again! ( it lost its Mac address).The router has been up for about two weeks.It works very well and it is very stable.Thank you Bella.
title: Testing the waranty

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2019
review_content: This thing is a little beast! I have a roughly 3500-5000 sq ft house. The FiOs provided router is all the way in the basement corner opposite to anything and everyone in the house. With this router, i am able to stream seamlessly on both bands offered. the 2.4 is good enough but it will jump you to the 5GHz band if needed which is nice! Huge upgrade and all members of the house can be on at the same time doing whatever you choose!
title: Best Bang for Buck!

author: Ray
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
review_content: This router is reasonably priced, simple to set up and provides solutions for segregating different types of traffic and the priority of same between 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz. Some home camera traffic, some remote monitoring traffic, some streaming traffic, then everyday run of the mill web surfing, email and browsing. I have 3 IP cameras running on the network along with 4 Smart TV's. Had too much congestion on just a 2.4 GHz combo access point/router. Installed the TPLINK router and problems solved.
title: Clears Up Congestion On Network Among Streaming and Upload/Download Applications Home Network

author: Castello
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2019
review_content: Horrible router. I purchased this router as a backup when our last router failed and we lost internet everywhere except via a direct connect. We also use Tivo and Tivo minis via ethernet and so we had no television except on one set. This was EXACTLY the reason for picking up a backup router. When our Asus router failed after less than 6 months I hooked up the new TP LInk only to be extremely disappointed that it did not work. Called TP Link tech support and they tried their best to say it was the modem when a direct connect for the desktop computer to the modem was prefect. After 2 or 3 hours on the phone trying to get the family online and watching TV again, tech support (they had me changing various configurations and giving me the run around with no success) then left me with no RMA help.BUYER BEWARE!
title: Garbage that never performed

author: Xun Gong
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2020
review_content: I am not a WIFI expert. I wanted to buy a wireless router which should be stable and easy to use. This product does not disappoint me.1. It is stable. I bought this wireless router for 6 months ago. It never freezes and does not need reboot.2. The interface is very easy to use, through either PC or phone.3. The signal strength is sufficient for a house around 2500 sq. ft.4. It can deliver at least up to 400Mbps internet connection which is my subscribed service.
title: Stable router with high speed, easy to use interface

author: Moth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2020
review_content: Junk. Interface says weak security even when saving correct settings...meaning just for show on server, no real security. Lost connections out of box. Settings are changed by TP themselves within the firmware. Had problems installing..said 32 people had same problem.... They are selling defective subpar products and evidently paying for reviews and awards. After trying to use it for 2 days....lost connection twice, settings changed from within, weak signal, blocks your own computer, JUNK. Do not buy this. It has documented security flaws.
title: Selling defective and snoopy products

author: Prof Daddy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
review_content: My internet speed went from 50 Mbs to 100 Mbs (tested using speedtest.net) just from switching to this Gigabit router. The other important feature for me is that it is a 2 network router. It has a guest network with it's own password. This is useful for multiple users like roommates, etc. It has a lot of other features like Alexa compatibility, integrated USB port to act as Media Server, upgradable, and has app allowing easy management of network.It has good range and can reconfigured to add One Mesh extender for even more range. Best of all not ridiculously expensive.
title: My tested speed went from 50 Mbs to 100 Mbs

author: Kyle Hoffmann
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2020
review_content: First let me say that this router will probably work just fine for most households.For around $60 at the time I paid for it, this is a great little device.  I bought it to replace a 6 year old AC1300 type router that was $175 or more when originally purchased it. As an IT professional normally I would go for something a little more advanced but I just moved into a new place and I was tired of spending money.I will say one thing though - it says gigabit all over it but I was not able to get it to speed test over 300mbps consistently over wired or wireless. I just don't think the CPU can handle it.I would have speed tests spike up to 400mbps or more and then very quickly come back down to average around 250. If I plug into the modem, it's 800 to mid 900s every time. I spent a fair amount of time researching this model and the issue with gigabit internet and I was not able to find any clear cut solution. I found one forum post where a couple of people said they were able to get it to work through a method similar to throwing salt over your shoulder and spinning around clockwise three times. I tried turning off every security and traffic management feature I could find and I just couldn't get it to test over 250Mbps reliably.If your internet is 300Mbps or lower, I think this router will work great for you. If you have over 300Mbps, it will still probably work great, you'll just be paying for bandwidth that I don't think you will ever see on your side of the router, wired or not.
title: Great for a $60 router.

author: PRC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2020
review_content: This stupid company has no technical support number you can call to get help installing their product! I wasted an hour of my life trying to install it but kept getting a vague error "failed" when trying to use a browser to set up the router.  And in order to set up the router, I needed to unhook the old router. So now... as you might guess, I have no internet connection and the only way to get technical support is to HAVE AN INTERNET CONNECTION!!!  What was this company thinking?  I'm returning the product immediately--I can't waste any more of my time trying to install something that is supposed to be so easy to install. And the fact that I couldn't get help other than to re-install my old router just to get an internet connection is ridiculous!! Do NOT buy this product if you don't have a smart phone or your smart phone doesn't have enough storage to install their app because you sure can't install it using the browser window as they say you can.
title: NO technical support you can CALL!

author: johnny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: I used to use the wireless routes given to me by my ISP providers,  but the signal kept dropping, and I was not getting anywhere near what I paid for in terms of MBPS and I had no access to their routers. on the advice of one of their techs I got my own router, this one. First off, it is fast.  I get the speeds I pay for. Secondly, it is super easy to set up. You can change the wifi name and password in 30 seconds.  Third, if you get an extender from TP Link,  it is super easy to set up, and the extender becomes part of your wifi network. Meaning you do not have to switch from your regular routers wifi to the extenders wifi. The last setup I had, it was 2 separate signals, this one is seamless. Lastly you cannot get better than this price. You get so much more!
title: Fantastic

author: L J Max
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2019
review_content: I've had the AC1750 for 24 hours and so far I have hit the reset button three times to get access to the internet.  When I did the initial set up and trying for two hours to get internet working I finally called support.  They had me push the reset button and finally the internet was accessible. As stated above I've had to depress the reset button three times to make the AC1750 work correctly. If you are looking for a reliable wireless router buy from a better manufacturer.
title: Worst Router On Amazon.

author: digitaldan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2020
review_content: This router would not connect a new Iphone SE, an Iphone 8, a Roku, a new HP desktop, or a Dell laptop to the internet. They all saw the wifi network, but nothing would make them connect to the internet. I tried for hours, my wife tried, and the cable technician tried.  We switched back to our old router, and "bingo" connected with no problem. There is obviously something seriously wrong with this product. One ought to be able to hook it up and be running without any fooling around.
title: would not connect to internet

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: We were using an older wifi router /modem that worked great if you hada LAN/ethenet cable hooked up. Good forbid you tried using it on wifi because you could be sitting right next to the thing and your signal would be weak.Instant unproven once we hooked up this archer wifi modem. I'm no computer guy, but it was super easy to hook up and set up. Instantly, videos loaded faster, more devices could be connected to our wifi without slow down.I DON'T KNOW anything about wifi or computer or "bandwidth". Lol. But if you find yourself paying for faster internet and you're not getting those speeds, I'd recommend trying this wifi routerMeasurements (taken about 30 ft from router, behind a wall)Ping 38 msDownload 98.94 mbpsUpload 2455.96 mbps
title: Instant improvement!

author: Coach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2020
review_content: This was a great purchase. I upgraded my old netgear router b/c I needed more speed, better range and move my printer from usb connected to my desktop to the router. It is now available to all the devices on my home network. Setting that up was a bit tedious (you have to set it up in the router - usb connection - and download a print utility from TP Link’s website  service portal) Hint: After the utility is installed you must reboot the router to get it acknowledged in the WiFi network. Our bredroom tv uses a ROKU stick to access streaming and the old router 2.4 G connection was spotty at best. The 5G channel on this TP Link is flawless. Also note: when you go to download the print utility, TP Link does not list the A7 model. I used the C7 utility ... NP.
title: Great speed, range, dual channels and printer now in my WiFi network. Highly recommended.

author: Chris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
review_content: I don’t recommend this router. I bought it because of all the good reviews. I used it for about a year, right up until it just started rarely working. It would go out intermittently every once in a while where it would say there’s no internet signal. I was angry at my ISP until I realized it was not their fault. The signal relay between my ISP and this router was screwed up within 6 months of buying this router. I endured spotty coverage for a few months until finally just got tired of it as it got worse and worse. I would restart router, did hard reset of it, change the configuration...it didn’t matter, it just wasn’t a good product. I hope others have better long term success with this, but I would not buy this again. I bought a different brand to replace with and am much happier right now.
title: Spotty coverage, inconsistent at doing its job

author: Trevor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
review_content: This was a great device for exactly 2 months, no complaints, and never had a problem. After 2 months of use (delivered April 15th, dead June 16th), it just died. While technically not entirely dead, as the power LED still functions, it doesn't do anything.-The reset button does nothing, even after attempting the 30-30-30 rule.-The web-based page that should work even without internet, says it can not connect.-The WiFi shows as "not in range" while right next to it.I'll be leaving it on until the new router shows up (maybe Netgear won't waste my money), but even if it does start working again I won't be using it as I can't trust TP Link to make a working product.
title: Dead After 2 Months

author: Terrell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2020
review_content: I bought this TP-Link AC1750 router in January 2020, seven months ago. It was easy to install and worked just fine until one month ago when it started to drop the wifi signal periodically and then more frequently. I had to shut down wifi and restart it to get it going again.  This continued and eventually the wifi slowed to the point that we could not stream video or use Zoom which was a problem.  I did online troubleshooting and tried reaching customer support and could not.  I decided it wasnt worth my time to pursue support any further not the warranty. So I've just bought and installed a Netgear wifi router.  It was also easy to install, working well and Im hoping for the best long tern.  And Ive thrown the useless TP Link router that Ive only had for 7 months in the trash.
title: Useless after 7 months

author: BoaTransistor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2019
review_content: This is a very economical choice. The router has a good set of features, very good user interface by current standards, and the smartphone app is fantastic. When it's working correctly, the router performs quite well for its price.Unfortunately there are issues here and there. First, the QoS feature needs some adjustment to account for what I assume is overhead. My cable service is 100Mbit down, 8Mbit up. Setting QoS to those numbers will result in the router limiting speeds to about 80Mbit down and 6Mbit up. After some adjusting, setting the QoS to 115 down / 11 up resulted in the router approximately limiting the speeds to the 100/8 connection, with fair queuing among connected devices.Another issue, which is unfortunately a show-stopper for me, is that the WAN connection will intermittently drop out throughout the day. After about 4-5 hours online, the dropouts begin to occur roughly every 60-90 minutes. Packet loss will spike to all clients, wired or wireless, and also on the web frontend's diagnostic ping test. This spike will generally last a couple of minutes at most. Unfortunately this makes the router useless for many applications beyond simple web browsing - VoIP, streaming, and VPNs are particularly susceptible to breakdowns as a result.Sadly this means I'll be sidelining this router for the time being in the hopes that a firmware fix may be forthcoming. In the meantime, I'll be using an older router that doesn't perform quite as well but is more reliable.UPDATE 10/17/19 - Further research and testing determined NAT Boost (TP-Link's hardware NAT implementation) was the cause of the WAN dropouts. Disabling NAT Boost will yield a stable connection, but at the cost of speed. The router can only sustain about 40Mbit/s downloads due to CPU limitations with NAT Boost off.Because I feel the router is not working as designed, I will be leaving the review at 2 stars. If your needs are compatible with the frequent dropouts while NAT Boost is on, or your internet service is limited to less than 50Mbit/s download, you may still find this router useful.
title: Archer A7 v5 - Choose WAN Dropouts with Nat Boost on, or Slow Speeds with it off

author: T. Jessessky Jr.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: I bought this due to Wirecutter’s recommendation. The first one I received worked well for a few weeks, then started to have moments of no signal (about 30 seconds at a time, several times a day). I returned the unit, thinking it was defective, and got a replacement. The second unit I received waited 3 months to start showing the same issue. There is still a WiFi network, but no internet during these brief windows. My hardwired devices show me that it is the router, not my ISP.As someone who works from home and takes video calls, this router will likely need to be replaced with a more reliable alternative. I do not recommend this product.
title: Multiple units showed defects after a short period.

author: tomR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: Don't even think about Netgear or Fios Router things like that. This thing has great coverage so far and the speed is only faster than my returned Fios router. Don't overthink it when buying routers. Simpler is better. MU-MINO or 2*2 or BEAMFORMING are all things that average household like you and me don't need. Unless you've got a few gigabit connections and have 50 devices this thing works great! DON'T OVERTHINK IT! Enjoy watching 4k videos without a buffer and low ping. hope this thing can last!
title: Don't overthink it. This cheap piece of plastic is gonna be more than enough for you.

author: ShoelessMo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
review_content: For the 1st 2 months this worked great.  It has good range and the speeds were good too.  Now,  it will randomly drop from its high speed down to about 1 mps for a few minutes.  It slows down enough to shut down any streaming for until speeds pick back up.  I would not recommend this product.
title: Good range,  poor connection

author: F. E. Belluso
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: trying to program this modem via the internet was hopeless....... the online site was good... after putting in all the info they ask'd for and then at the last program when they were saving all my info...i got the message. ohhhhh sorry something went wrong...try again............ so once again i input the info they wanted...and once again it showed it was saving all my info....and the once again it said....oooohhhhhh so sorry something went wrong....i thinking what the hell went wrong.... so after trying 5 times i gave up.....i finally thru the unit in the trash.......i went down to best buy and bought a. netgear router. and in 5 minutes i was up and running...... using the internet to program the netgear...so my question what is wrong tp-link....
title: on line hookup

author: jwr1945
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2020
review_content: I bought this router in MId-2019 and am just now trying to install.  Almost no detail instruction came with this unit.  I've installed 2 routers before and expected no problems.  It was unable to connect to my Arris 6 cable modem, thus no access to internet.  I re-install old working router and go to TP Link website...it is total BS,,,,no customer support and way to contact them. This is the WORST product support I have ever experienced.  My Advice--DO NOT buy TP Link products!!!!!
title: NO SUPPORT available

author: Keri Carroll
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
review_content: I decided to get this router after doing some research online. My router that I have from optimum was acting wonky and dropping since the coronavirus lockdown started. So I got this one and it seems to have sped things up a lot and no dropping so far! I’ll update if I have any future issues.
title: Great router so far!

author: john h thompson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2018
review_content: Don't waste your money. Stop working after 2 week
title: Junk

author: Christopher J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2020
review_content: Setup was simple, however I wanted it to act in AP mode but i I was unable to get it to work. So i had to factory reset and plug it in from modem to tplink lan port instead of WAN. In the interface it says no internet but it really has internet. Also disabled DHCP on it because my modem was acting as the DHCP server to keep things simple. My wifi singal is alot better now with this, throughout the entire apartment, and the fact that it is mesh makes it even better if i ever need to expland. But I do not like the user interface because it lacks option. I want to be able to setup multiple SSIDS, however that is not possible.I like the fact that you can have a guest SSID, however i dont like the fact that you can not throttle the speeds of it I would recommend it to a friend due to it's low price
title: It works for most peopl

author: anonymous
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: I bought this so I could replace my modem/router combination and have more control over the network features. It took me a moment to figure out the menu options, but I have been able to setup everything I need for DHCP [which some IPS's equipment has locked out] as well as control over who has Internet via the parental controls. I also plan to get a secondary as an access point to expand my WIFI through my entire home as the electrical does interfere which cannot be helped. My entire network is TP-Link, and I would highly recommend them as they have out performed others under my networking conditions.
title: Perfect for any network!

author: Beachnorwegian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2020
review_content: I am so frustrated with wireless routers.  It's as if they all have some poltergeist in them.This model states that although it has two bands,  2.4GHz and 5GHz, only one router name will show on your wifi menu and it will always offer the fastest connection possible.  It also allows you to set a "priority" for any of your devices and so since most of my work is done on my wireless desktop imac, I set this device for the priority.Imagine my surprise then when I checked the "clients" tab on the tether app and found that my imac had been designated for the 2.4GHz and my other two devices who both put on the 5GHz.  They were running the fastest connections, about 200 mbps and my imac dropped to about 78 mbps.  The exact opposite of what a smart connection would do.Two calls to tech support fixed it temporarily but the imac always ended up getting dropped to the slower network.  I'm returning the router soon.
title: Dumb connect

author: Brad Swasey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2020
review_content: I got this to replace my 2.4 ghz Belkin router to maximize the speeds from my ISP. One day later and I was back to my old router.  I would do a speed test and this would go from 112 mbps right down to flatline (a couple hundred  kbps). All of our devices would have connecting issues.  As I'm working from home with kids doing home school,  this is unacceptable.  I hooked up the old router and my speed and lag issues vanished immediately.  I'm returning this for a refund.
title: Loses speed and flatlines.

author: Carol S. Lewis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2019
review_content: We were having trouble with the pull chains on our bedside lamps. My wife's pull chain broke and I replaced her light socket and chain. I started having trouble with mine. I decided we would get smart plugs for our lamps. I bought an echo dot 3 and tp-link mini plug pkg and another additional tp-link mini plug. When we received the echo dot and the mini plugs, we set up the echo dot but the echo couldn't find the mini plugs. We down loaded the Alexa app and the kasa smart app. and another two or three other apps. After entering about a half dozen passwords, rebooting still no connections. I called Alexa support, a man with Indian accent answered and he directed me to type in several codes and visit other web sites, it seemed as if is he was directing me in circles. After about 20 minutes I finally hung up the phone. We decided it must be the router. Since the plug-ins were tp-link we ordered a tp-link router. The router came in and we replaced our old Linksys router with the TP link router. When we set up the wifi it couldn't find Alexa.  After 4 hrs on my wife's Amazon Fire tablet I connected back to Alexa, but  Alexa couldn't connect to the tp-link plugs. In the meantime my Smartcast tv in the living room started having problems with the wifi signal and started buffering and losing Netflix. I gave up! I'm sending everything back to Amazon with the exception of Alexa, my wife wants to keep her.
title: My old Linksys router out performed the new TP-Link router

author: Chet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2020
review_content: I read all the glowing reviews about how easy this was to get up and running. Maybe I'm cursed, but it would not recognize my cable modem. If you don't get the easy path everyone raves about right away, you get a bunch of DHP ISP DNS DHCP WAN LAN MAC CLONE and about 100 other confusing acronyms to WADe through. If I could give this minus 2 stars, I would for the two hours I wasted trying to make it work. I figured it would just be as simple as the reviews and I could just start it up, give it the SSID of my old router and change the default PWD to that which I've been using for the last 10 years on my old routers and be done. Not so. And I'm no rookie. I used to write software for Atari and actually owned a $700 5.25 floppy drive in the early eighties for my 32K machine.
title: Despite calls to my ISP, this would not recognize it was hooked to my modem

author: KG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2019
review_content: I decided to forgo the monthly charge from Comcast for their terrible 2in1 modem+router combo for my 2 lakehouses and bought 2 Arris Touchstone TM822G modems and 2 of these TPLink AC1750 routers.The speed on 5ghz is just as fast as it is connecting directly to the modem (180mbps from xfinity's 150mbps package) and the range is enough to cover the 2,500sq ft houses and the surrounding decks/patios. Even get ~15mbps on the 2.4ghz frequency at the beach 200+ feet away from the router. Great range for the price and the 5ghz frequency has superior range to my more expense Linksys and Apple routers at my other homes. I believe the beamforming makes a difference in maintaining the speed over greater ranges.Routers were easy to setup and change the channels on both 2.4ghz and 5ghz  frequencies as to lesson the interference between the 2 routers due to their close proximities. Overall great router and will likely purchase again when my other routers eventually crap out.
title: great speed and range

author: Alex&Michael Mansell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: This router fits the bill for a mid-range budget device.  I was incredibly disappointed to find that the big box stores don't seem to sell mid-range like this anymore...it's either the $30 Netgear model or the fancy "whole home" setup.  This TP-Link unit from Amazon fits the happy medium, and I couldn't be happier with the price.  Setup was simple, but there are a ton of advanced options in the interface if you want to really tweak and customize your network or setup.  TP-Link also has lovely cloud services which make remote management, dynamic DNS, etc. to be a real treat.  This is my first TP-Link product and I would most certainly purchase from their brand again.
title: Great speed, easy setup, and best value for the money

author: Kristie Antaya
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2020
review_content: I have to say this was one of the easiest set-up's I've had in years. The new interface, programming, the amount of custom options, etc. This router is well worth the money, and is pushing roughly 30% faster than my previous device. It was easily linked to Alexa, and also had a recent update to the firmware. The amount of options you have here and the use of mesh, including the great pricing makes this a huge win. The product also came well-packaged, despite there being a dent on the outside, everything was safely protected with minimal usage of card boards and plastics. Great for the environment. I was also surprised to see that the router has night-modes, and a status monitor for the CPU and Memory built into the unit. Great Job TP-Link, roughly 10+ years of my support.
title: TP-Link leading the way

author: Cory
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2020
review_content: Do not buy this piece of garbage or any other TP Link products. I bought this mid June and over the past week it started dropping wifi and network connections. I have reset it multiple times and it is unusable. I am past the 30 day return by a few weeks and TP Link support is atrocious.TP Link wants to charge me over half the cost of this piece of garbage to send it back to them to troubleshoot. No thanks.
title: TP Link is a Ripoff

author: Mark Davey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
review_content: My old 2.4gz TP-Link router was having trouble with all the video I was streaming. In particular the 4K data, my VR headset and AirTV (yes those are high bandwidth applications), so I decided to upgrade to a dual band router. Big mistake, this router just dumped the WAN connection intermittently  when any load was placed on the router. If I decide to download a large file the WAN interface dropped. My old 2.4gh router just had no problem, but AC1750 could not keep up with the load the old 2.4ghz router could. So I decided to use it as an access point since the WAN interface seemed to be the problem. No any heavy usage on the router just caused the interface signal to drop. So now I have a paper weight. If you want to stream SD this router might work.
title: Totally Unstable

author: CC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: A great router, certainly compared to the undistinguished Cisco/Linksys router it replaced. The TP-Link is super-easy to install, figures out almost all the parameters by itself - vs. the Cisco/Linksys install that was a big nightmare that persisted literally for years. And the TP-Link covers my whole, medium-large house with a good, strong signal. And the TP-Link is so inexpensive it’s actually kind-of embarrassing.I could find a few small faults with the TP-Link: It can be destabilized by very aggressive speed-testing, necessitating a re-boot. It lacks radio-signal beam-forming - but what do you expect for the price?, and I think the newer, replacement model has it nonetheless, and it doesn’t matter to me anyway ‘cause (as above) the signal covers my whole house just fine as it is. And the TP-Link technical support is medium-poor, the people are nice but not really very knowledgeable or good at communicating - but the documentation is pretty good, and the device itself is great, so the tech. support is hardly needed.Overall, a great router. Five stars for me.
title: Great router from TP-Link

author: A. K.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2019
review_content: I have low tolerance for products that fail to do the one task they're built to do. I have a solid 215 mbps wired connection--my ISP has verified the integrity of the signal, firmware, hardware etc on my end. I recently upgraded my old router with this one and it seems like every other day my speed drops to a meager 15 mbps, no explanations given. Refreshing ip, flushing DNS etc does not help. SOMETIMES restarting the computer a few times works,  but this NEVER happened with my old stone aged router. I don't care about fancy features, blinking lights, or cool chassis design. I want a router that relays my full signal strength to my connected devices and this product fails to do so.
title: Regularly drops speed from 215 mbps to 15 mbps

author: Sun n Fun
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: When installing my PC connected to the router but kept saying "no Internet" I called my internet supplier which is Spectrum and asked technical support if they were blocking the signal and they said no. The technician asked me a couple of questions and remotely reset my Spectrum modem and within a couple of minutes I had internet.It is considerably faster and all the problems I had before with my Spectrum router are fixed. So glad I made the changeover.
title: Big Improvement

author: Peter G.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2020
review_content: I bought this to replace an access point that failed on my home network.  Seemed okay at first, but wasn't able to identify which devices were connected to the A7 device through their admin page.  After some digging around in their support forums, it appears this is an old problem for multiple Archer / TP-LINK devices in access mode.  Their support person in the forums insisted it's "not a bug", it's "just how it works."  Absurd answer.  So you have no way of knowing who's on your network with this device or which access point a given device is connecting to.  Made it impossible to figure out best location to pick up devices around the house.  A particular shout out for the lack of customer focus from their forum rep "Carl" who apparently did nothing to get this issues resolved.  Wouldn't buy their products again.
title: Not for use as an access point

author: Eric M
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
review_content: I didn't want to spend a bunch but I just signed up for the Cox gigabit service and needed a new router as my old one just wasn't getting me the pass through I was paying for from Cox. This was pretty much plug and play, super easy, up and running in minutes. The throughput is fantastic as long as you are pretty close. What I mean by that, and YMMV, but for me, if I'm in the same room with the router, I consistently get over 400 MB/sec via wireless to my laptop on download tests from DSL reports. However, if I move to the next room and the signal has to go 10 ft further and through a wall, I'm in the low 200's. Now, am I complaining about that speed...not at all...it's fantastic. I'm in an 1,100 sq ft apartment so this is awesome, just not sure if that speed would drop more if you were in a big house. Regardless, for the money, this is a great router.
title: For the price, this is fantastic!

author: dpidduck
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
review_content: Frustrating POS.I spent 8 hours yesterday trying to get everything connected without success; smart home accessories kept losing their connection, internet keeps dropping, router freezes...just a mess. If you have an Amazon Alexa, don't enable the smart connect feature until everything is connected and working.As you can see from the picture, the CPU is maxed out at 100% and it's that way most of the time. One wired device is shown; there should be three including the computer I'm using. One wireless device is shown...where are the 23 other ones I spent all morning connecting!? On the ARP binding page it shows the same MAC address 17 times with 17 different IP addresses!RESOLVED: This router isn’t compatible with Firewalla.
title: So happy I kept the box!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: This replaced a 4 year old Asus router and the difference is noticeable, particularly at distance.  The old router would reach to every corner of the house but speeds would drop to nearly nothing in some spots.  This pushes a strong signal (over 100Mbps) to every corner of the house (~3000sq/ft).  And for the price?  Yes, please.  You could certainly get faster and more capable routers if you have the need but they'll cost you 4 times as much as this one does.  If you've got a family of 4-6 and you're looking for a good browsing/streaming router that'll cover a good sized home, I'd recommend this.  And you can mesh it if you need to extend coverage later on.  My first experience with TP Link and I'm impressed so far.
title: Great range/bandwidth

author: DB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: My objective: update home wifi to support streaming TV & movies to all devices in the house.Solution:  I first purchased the AC 1200 and it had a strong wireless signal across the house during the day - streaming worked fine and had good quality.  However, in the evening picture quality went down on the most remote devices and we started getting pauses in the stream to those same remote devices.  I then decided to try the AC 1750 and it performed poorly day and night on the remote devices.  However, I then added a Re300 mesh device and it works great all the time now.Recommendation:  If you have a small coverage area (or can centrally locate the router), only want to buy one wifi router, and DO NOT need a USB port on the router for a media drive then go with the AC 1200 as it definitely has the strongest wifi signal and best penetration through walls.  Otherwise, go with the AC 1750 and a Re300 mesh device.
title: tp-link AC1200 vs AC1750

author: DaveC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2019
review_content: Got this to replace the WIFI router that Frontier rents you for $10/month and so far it is working great having no problem feeding my devices the full 500mbps the fiber internet service provides.  If you are going to replace your FiOS router make sure you first go into the router config and release the WAN IP address from it before hooking up the replacement otherwise it will not pull an IP address.  Setup of this device was very painless in my case and the WIFI signal is strong enough to provide acceptable signal to my 2200 sq ft home on both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz.
title: Great replacement router for Frontier FiOS Internet service

author: JS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020
review_content: I tried the TP-Link AC1750 router because it was substantially less expensive than some other popular routers and it got pretty good reviews on Amazon. I also bought a TP-Link RE305 range extender to go with it. The router was relatively easy to set up. I had it plugged in and running in no time. The range extender was another issue. And although this is a review of the router, not the range extender, the only reason I mention it is because I was on a chat session with TP-Link Tech Support trying to get the range extender to work. They were VERY patient and chatted with me for a very long time and found that the solution was a firmware upgrade to the router. So I give TP-Link Support high marks for that. The reason I gave the router such a low overall rating is because the range of the router, even with the range extender, was not at all what I expected. The wifi speed seemed to drop off rather sharply when I got what I thought was not that far from the router. Now, I know that there are many factors that can affect the router's performance, but I was seeing behavior that I thought was not acceptable. So ... I bit the bullet and shelled out the money for a router that cost $200+ more than the TP-Link router. I bought (through Amazon) a Netgear Nighthawk R8000P.  It's installation was similarly easy and I am getting the wifi speeds I expect.
title: WiFi Speeds Dropped Off

author: Bear!
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2019
review_content: It works, which is great, although the performance is limited to about 200 mbps, even when wired. 200 Mbps isn't awful, but I had hopes that for a router that advertises itself as being a "gigabit wireless router" the performance would be better.I found that disabling "hardware acceleration" on 2.4 ghz helped to improve reliability. Wireless coverage is fine, but nothing special. Overall a good router, thus the 4-star rating, but nothing particularly special.
title: Meh

author: Casey Patterson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: Great router! We where using an outdated router and having major internet troubles seeing we have multiple echo dots and echo shows, not to mention we stream our shows and movies and also have security systems and gaming systems that rely on the internet. I also needed a router that could handle my lap top for school and tablets as well. Sense we have gotten this router we have had no connection problems and i can control my router with Alexa or my tether app!
title: Best router for multiple devices and smart home use

author: REBECCA G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
review_content: Wow! What a great router! We just moved, and after literally 14 years (!) of renting a router for 10$/month from our last cable company, we decided no matter what (!) we were buying a router to lower our bills. We found this on Wirecutter as their budget pick - around 57$ at the time we bought it - called up Fios/Verizon to just doublecheck it was compatible, and YES yes it is!  It was super easy to set up - the cable tech didn’t have to do anything - and setting up was a snap. Highly recommended!
title: Totally easy to use and saving serious monthly rental charges

author: Jim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
review_content: I use it in our house. The signal travels everywhere at a high rate of speed even outside in the yard.  We have three TV's with ROKU, 6 Alexa devices, plus 2 tablets, 2 iPhones, three laptops, and a number of devices that are voice controlled by Alexa.  It was easy to set up the router, and I get great speed on all devices. When I have used other routers, I found that the speeds tended to decrease whenever they submited upgrades and much too frequently, their upgrades would made one or more of my devices temporarily inoperable until I figured out how to reconfigure the device.  I have never experienced a degradation in speed or temporary inoperability with the TP-Link upgrades. I am very happy with this router.
title: Happy with this Router.

author: TimBo266
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: I had an old Net Gear WIFI router that barely could reach outside of my house. I have a metal sided workshop behind the house. I could only get Alexa to respond out there if the door was open. I purchased this router with hopes it could reach further and interface with my range extender. Installation went well. I did not need Tech Support at all. I was so surprised at how far this new router could reach. I now can easily interact with Alexa inside my shop with the door closed. I can access my security camera that is about 60 feet away on the backside of the metal building. I had to reset all my devices to recognize my new router. After that all is well and good now. I am very happy with the new WIFI router.
title: Impressive reach

author: Aces&8s
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: The router works great but gaining access to the router settings is king of a pain.  If you could use 192.168.0.1 and gain access directly I would not have an issue with this router.  However, I always ended up having to use the website to log in, and that I am not a fan of.  I should be able to easily connect direct from a PC without having to use their website.  Other than that, this is a solid router.  I never had to use technical support so I can not comment on that.  Good luck.Basically, if you do not have an internet connection and you are trying to configure a network before the internet provider connects you....it is a very long bumpy road.  You should be able to setup a network without the internet.  This however was not my experience.
title: Good Router...Interface no so much

author: Stephen Gregory
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2019
review_content: I already had an Archer C7, which is very similar and replaced it with this A7, using the C7 in bridge mode. (I don't know if the A7 can be used in bridge mode, but it would be easy to set up as an access point.) These are really great routers for a great price. They just keep on working reliably at high bit rates. The interface is very comprehensive, but easy to understand.
title: Great value for a fast, very reliable router

author: David C Hendrickson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Had a faily new MediaLink which the 2.4g when dead on.  So ROKU and Printers were dead too.  I don't need anything fancy, just 2.4g and 5g.  This sets up both with one SSID and it's smart enough to know which is which.  So far so good.  I even set up guest SSID's so I don't have to have guests on my internal network.  Took me about 30 minutes to set up.  Printers are back up and ROKU's are streaming again. My wife is happy and I'm the hero again.
title: Works great and setup was a breeze

author: Chixdigit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
review_content: I was having problems with connectivity and response with my Alexa devices from the crappy “smart router” that Spectrum provided to me for five dollars per month so I decided to try this one to see if it would help the issues. Man, what a difference! There are absolutely no connection issues with Alexa or any of my smart devices since I have switched to this router. I also have excellent coverage. I highly recommend this router if you want to replace your crummy spectrum one.
title: Perfect replacement for Spectrum junk. My Alexa works perfect now!

author: Juice
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2019
review_content: I picked this up to add to my parents home. It improved the coverage greatly. They now have more complete coverage throughout the house. I was also shocked at how fast the router web interface was. I’ve been using a Netgear R6700 with it’s clumsy and slow interface, so this was a refreshing and pleasant surprise. For the price,this can’t be beat.
title: Quickly connects and a fast interface

author: Loveology
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
review_content: TP Link makes some great products, which is why I took a chance on this router. However, it over-promises and under-delivers. I have about 10 devices in my home, which all need access to wifi at any given time. They're common things like my phone, ipad, macbook, echo, and smart lights + smart plugs. I also do a lot of online gaming. I observed this router's CPU maxing out quite frequently, just as others have reported. I also noticed that since setting it up, my internet speeds are slower, and pages + images and elements on pages take longer to load. It will probably be a fine router for someone with only a few devices, but it can't keep up as well as I need it to, and the CPU thing is concerning.
title: Can't keep up with the times - CPU issues

author: Brendan Trieu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: If you are looking to upgrade from an old router this device will definitely be very good. I had an old router I was using specifically for my room since I am far from my main router. I'm able to connect to it quickly and pages load fast compared to the old router I used. I haven't tested the ports to see if they were really gigabit or not so I have no idea about that part.  I think there could be some features that could be added to the web config but I mean it really isn't too bad.
title: Great budget router!

author: Tina H Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2019
review_content: I just moved into my first apartment and had to get my very own router! I also just got CompTIA A+ and Sec+ certified so I felt obligated to get a quality router to avoid judgement. So far I have five smart devices, three computers, an xbox, and a smart TV connected to the WiFi and have yet to experience any lag. The UI is super easy to use, anyone could set it up. It's very user-friendly with helpful illustrations. It also sets up very quickly. When I reboot it, it takes less than 30 seconds to get back up, which is amazing compared to my parents' router. My apartment has walls in odd locations so the router had to be squished against a wall, but it hasn't posed any sort of issue. I'm very happy with it!
title: A great router

author: D. Vega
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: I purchased this item hoping to save money from leasing from the internet company. We also upgraded to Gigablast plan. Once we hooked it up to the "new" modem the internet kept cutting off (annoying). Not knowing what the issue was, I kept calling my internet provider for assistance and they couldn't assist. I took it upon myself to purchase a brand new router to see if this would take care of the issue and IT WORKED! Of course, by the time we figured this out we were past the date to return and was unable to return. :( Now I'm stuck with a router that I paid for that was no good.
title: Do NOT purchase refurbished

author: leo robinson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: Look at the reviews for this router and I must say that this was the best decision I’ve made this year so far. The range you get with this is fabulous and not to mention the WiFi signal strength, 1000 mbps to I believe 1400mbps, then again it all depends on your internet provider but overall I’m truly satisfied with this purchase and see this lasting for several years to come. Also forgot that the app is very user friendly and easy to navigate through and it’s a free app. Highly recommend this router if you love streaming movies, games ,or just your usual browsing the World Wide Web. Hopefully this review helps
title: Best router for your dollars !!!!

author: Scott
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2019
review_content: Very reliable over the past few months.  There has been no need to reboot / restart the system due to loss of WiFi.  The Network Attached Storage ( A 3TB hard drive we connected to the USB port) is always available via Windows on a PC or the File Explorer app on either Android or iOS.  So I can store all my images and documents centrally and access them via any PC or hand held device if I'm in range of my WiFi.  I have complaints.  Great product!
title: Reliable Router and Wi Fi especially for NAS (network attached storage)

author: David Reed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: Bought this during the prime day sale and began to get nervous reading through some of the bad reviews. I, for one, have had a great experience with this router so far. I downloaded the app and had it setup in under 10 minutes. I'm not great with network stuff and haven't done anything fancy with the settings. Immediately I was getting better wired speeds (around 100Mbps) and one floor directly below the router I was getting 75Mbps wireless (small town). Previously I was getting around 70 wired and got a lot of lag while gaming - now gone. On the farthest end of the house the wifi is pretty weak, but still better than it used to be.We will see how it holds up over time - but it was incredibly easy to setup and increased my speed and reduced lag spikes while gaming. I can have two people streaming Netflix and have no problem with my game. All I really wanted and for a great price!
title: 10min Setup and Increased Speed

author: Banditrider
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2020
review_content: When COVID-19 shut down our schools, my daughter and wife (who is a teacher) got laptops and now work/learn at home.  This increased use quickly wore out my old router.  This one had good reviews so I bought it.  Computers/phones go on one channel, while the Roku player/TV's go on another.  I'm not super techie but this works great.  We can stream educational videos and watch TV all at the same time with no slow downs.  Just what we needed.
title: Works great

author: Nikolas T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2020
review_content: This product has a chipset that has a back door that has not been closed by the manufacturer.  This router allows attackers to actively observe your root actions and install software to steal logins and passwords for any website visited including bank details.  Use of this router requires an external firewall stand-alone device.  I puchased two units and both of them were discovered to have the same exploit.  The attack is so aggressive and real time that bank logins were changed and bank accounts hacked within minutes of installing these routers.  Our bank caught the odd activity and notified us.  This all happened the same day the routers were installed.  I then used a known secure machine with little snitch and a host of other active network analyzing software to make new login and password with the bank.  In less than an hour the login had been hacked again.  I then went back to using my old Calix router and again changed the logins with the bank.  This apparently worked.  So still in contact with bank IT specialist, and tried one more experiment.  I used the TP link AC-1750 again, and in less than an hour bank logins were again hacked!  So it is confirmed with bank that this router is not safe for any online banking!
title: These routers are hacked!  Bank info stolen!!!  ALL UNITS SOLD HAVE BEEN HACKED

author: K. K.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2020
review_content: It was a whole ordeal with this router. A simple task turned into 3 hours of high tech work. If you are not tech-savvy stay away.1) When connecting the laptop to the modem directly I got 450mbps speed.2) WIFI link speed 450mbps3) WIFI speed test varies from 150-230mbps which is normally 50% of links speed per tech support4) Spent 2 hours with a TP link tech support and they had no idea about how to fix speed issues let alone speak proper English. I got a headache trying to decipher what she was saying in a thick Chinese accent. 2 hrs sum up- go to TP-link website, register, go to advance settings change the channel. Well, it did not make a difference.5) Returning.I
title: If you are paying for high speed internet do not buy this

author: David T
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2018
review_content: I rarely write reviews, but AC1750 product warrants a negative review.  I am two months into using the product, and the signal strength is terrible, both in the 5GHz and 2.4GHz bands.  Even a few feet from the WiFi gateway, with a clear line of sight, and the signal strength is -57 dBm for the 5GHz band, and -51 dBm for the 2.4GHz band.  I have spent hours on the phone with technical support, and it is worthless.  I wish I had not bought this product.
title: 2 months later and signal strength is terrible

author: David M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: So I was getting tired of my old router, and the process involved in restarting or fixing issues. I’m no tech savvy kind of guy, but I suppose I know enough to get by in today’s culture. Not as bad off as others that trust there ISP to rent a router, no thank you. I was pleasantly pleased with the user friendly interface, and as I placed my router upstairs not having to spend time in the s second floor of the house in SC summer heat. Anyways it was easy to setup and easy to use and setup security protocols, along with restarting or fixing issues. The router came with a free app in which you were able to setup everything from. I’m not sure if the bump is WiFi speeds were from the ISP or from the router itself.
